Matching two healthy townsfolk or two plague-ridden citizens will earn you points, but don't accidentally cross the two and spread the plague! The game is played over 4 "seasons" (rounds) with each season affecting scoring in a significant way. It's a quick-playing game of deduction and bluffing for 3-4 players.

Full rules are available under the Files section of this entry.


Black Plague Blind Date won the February 2013 Boardroomers Game Design Contest in the 3+ Players category. Entrants in the contest were limited to using no more than 20 standard playing cards and 10 cubes.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Medieval, Print & Play

name: Perfidious
description:
PERFIDIOUS is a two player war game, set on a small map where two factions battle for control of the other’s Home Hex. All the armies in the game have their true strength hidden and battles are won based on the claims of the players (but the players can lie to win).

Players must use deceit to outwit their opponent and only by hiding your strengths and weaknesses will they succeed. But be careful; your opponent can call your bluffs and in doing so, may unravel your plans completely!

The base rules are simple and easy to learn but the game can be modified by a collection of optional rules to be mixed and matched at the start of the game by the players.

This game is also completely free to play and can be printed with any standard printer using 8½x11 paper. Some components require cutting so scissors are required for the initial building of the game.

This game is released under the Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 Unported
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Sectorball: 12Touches Football
description:
Our ancestors invented a way to reduce the craving for playing football during the cold winter months. It was the year 1900. The game was coined “Gombfoci”, a rather self-explanatory term, which describes a game played with buttons from coats upon a kitchen table. It spread like wildfire and soon came to be well known in such far off lands as Spain, USA or Brazil. These people changed the rules and by this created a new game called “12 Touches”, which later became an even greater success than its predecessor. (Geraldo Cardoso Décourt’s, in 1928).

This game simulates football, the board it is a small football field and both players control a team of disks (or rings), and move them by flicking or pressing their edges, in order to hit a smaller disc (the ball) with them. The players need to score by moving the ball into the goal.
A match takes 20 minutes divided in 2 halves of 10 minutes each.

The game is turn-based, only the sector ball rule will change this. A turn normally consists of moving one of your buttons. The buttons have to slide on the table, but not by pushing or pulling. They can be moved by flicking or by pressing by the finger. The buttons cannot be lifted up and put elsewhere, only after goals and before goal-kicks, free kicks, penalties or corner kicks.

Sectorball actually means a valid pass in the football game. If you move a button and the ball stops close enough (maximum one button size) to another button controlled by you, then you get another turn.

The game is also suitable for solo play. The player then controls both sides. In this can be simulating whole world championships.

Players can play single matches, tournament based matches, league or swiss system.

We are moving the two games in one box. Same board game, two approaches. East meets West on the same "soccer pitch": Sector Ball Table Football vs. 12 Touches Brazilian.
publishers: Compaya.hu: Gamer Caf√© Kft., Le & Le Games

name: Mash PotatoS
description:
Have you ever played the old bar game, "Bullsh!t"?

Mash PotatoS essentially is exactly that, but with potatoes instead of numbers.

A group of players sit around in a table with the deck in the middle. When it comes to their turn they draw a card and place it in the "bowl" claiming out loud what color the potato is. It then goes onto the next turn if no one yells "Mash!" accusing the played card's claim a lie.

If the accuser is right he would win; if not he would lose his next turn.

No matter what color the potato actually is, the same color can not be claimed twice in a row.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Children's Game, Party Game

name: Chuhan War
description:
Chuhan War is a 2-3 player wargame that simulates the battle between Chu kingdom and Han kingdom during 206 B.C. to 202 B.C. It is a strategic and simple historical game. There are 14 turns and 4 scenarios. Players move their units to attack enemy’s units and occupy the provinces to gain supply points. Each player can draw other kingdoms over to his side during the event phase. It is necessary to spend supply points to recruit units.

A player wins by eliminating the opposing king.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: DreadBall: Skittersneak Stealers
description:
DreadBall: The Futuristic Sports Game is the hyper-kinetic sci-fi sports game of unparalleled speed and ferocity – a fast, fun and tactical miniature sports board game written by Jake Thornton and created by Mantic Games.

Two coaches compete for victory with teams of beautiful miniatures on a stunning sci-fi pitch. The game is easy to learn, yet challenging, with carefully orchestrated plays and counter attacks hinging on positioning and the mercy of the dice gods.

This expansion adds an additional team made up of Veer-myn Miniatures, the Skittersneak Stealers.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Sports

name: Census
description:
From the back of the box:

A hospital census is a report showing each patient’s name, diagnosis, and bed number. Managers have an endless battle on their hands moving patients from the waiting room into appropriate beds.

In Census, each player builds a unique hospital by fundraising, buying different types of beds and equipment, and hiring doctors. Each year the hospitals grow, but the number of patients coming for help grows as well.

Successful hospitals will win awards – and the ability to shut down opposing players’ beds! Poorly managed hospitals will begin to see their patients pile up in the waiting room, and stolen away by other hospitals! Do you have what it takes to keep your hospital running smoothly, outshining your competitors? Grab your Census today and find out!

name: Introspection, The Board Game
description: Introspection is a game of over 1,300 yes or no questions divided into 6 categories: Getting to Know You, Your Family, Your Relationships, Work, Your Psychology and Your Religious & Philosophical Beliefs. With the yes or no cards provided, you predict what your respondent will say, yes or no. If you are correct, you move forward on the board..incorrect, you move your game piece backward. The dice is color-coded which corresponds to the quesion categories. If you roll purple, go to the Psychology questions! Should you land on any of the 26, Life Question Spaces, you must relate a short story from your life to the other players (2-6 players).Some of the Life Questions include, Aloneness, Regret, Love, Intollerance, Jealousy etc.In order to win the game, you must cross the finish line and Move into NIRVANA..but first, you must relate 2 stories, one about enlightenment and spirituality.

name: The New U.S. Merchant Marine and International Salesman
description:
The Game is called: "Game of The New U.S. Merchant Marine Prepared under the direction of the U. S. Ship Board and International Salesman".

Object of the game: the players go on a competitive trip around the world spin, move and try to carry more cargoes than other competitor. The game ends, then one of the players traveled around the world and come back to New York port. The winner is the player who earned the largest amount in cargoe value delivered.

A game projecting the power of the US via the Merchant Marine after WWI. Ships travel a Mercator projection map showing the globe as colonial possessions of the European powers. The German holdings are indicated as "Former German Possessions". The islands north of New Guinea are designated as "Japanese Mandate". Key & scale at the bottom right; the index at the bottom left is of "Ports of the World & Chief Exports", including Australia (Freemantle, Adelaide, Sydney, Hobart). A circumnavigational route around the globe is marked in red with player directions printed near each spot.
Game board 88 x 51 cms, divided into 4 panels, original wooden box, 2 spinners, 6 cast metal ships pieces & original pencil. Full directions are printed on the inside of the box cover. The cover has an attractive lithographed view of New York harbor with a ship in the foreground.

name: Artful Deductions
description: The game comes with seven packets of cards, 26 cards per packet. The front of each card depicts a work of art, and the back contains a question in one of five categories: Language, Science & Technology, Government & Religion, Daily Life, and Warfare. Players attempt to deduce the answer to each question based upon (1) the picture on the front, (2) clues within the question, and (3) the category. Points are scored for correct answers. The game ends when all the questions in a packet have been read.

name: Memory Challenge: Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer Edition
description:
Publisher Blurb:

Can you recall the most famous reindeer of all? Relive the magic of the most beloved holiday classic of all time while playing the world's most popular matching game in this special edition of Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer Memory. The player with the most matches wins. Match your favorite Rudolph characters with colorful picture cards. Fit in with the Misfits! Match a couple of Misfit cards for added reindeer game play action!
categories: Card Game, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Island Emergency
description:
The Islands have been devastated by a huge natural disaster. It has ripped buildings apart, thrown debris far and wide, and endangered the lives of the Island’s inhabitants. As the danger subsides survivors are gradually emerging from the rubble and signalling for help.

You can choose. Will you be a team of willing rescuers on a helicopter, a UFO looking for specimens or a hungry dragon looking for easy meals? Either way players score points by collecting the survivors as quickly as they can but are restricted in their flight patterns by the local air currents.

The board consists of a grid of 9 tiles, representing the islands, each with only 2 arrows on to indicate legal moves off of the tile. As the survivors are randomly generated each turn players must try to negotiate their way to them using 2 moves, no more, no less. If they fail to pick anyone up in a turn then they can claim a chaos card that can allow them in a future turn to twist, swap, or twist and swap islands around to make their path easier and/or to foil the plans of the other player.

Don't be fooled by the apparent simplicity of only having to negotiate 9 tiles - this is a game often demanding some pretty involved thinking out.

The advanced solo option keeps the pressure on by introducing dangers to your survivors such as storms, fire, and disease.

name: Family Business: Blood Brothers and The Moll Expansions
description:
If you currently control the weakest mob (fewest surviving members), you may take the Blood Brothers tile and place it Blood Brothers side up in front of you.

Blood Brothers: Whenever one of your mobsters is added to the Hit List, you must move one mobster already on the Hit List to the space directly in front of your just-added mobster (effectively making them a higher priority on the Hit List). The mobster you move can be one of yours, or an opponent's. If there are no other mobsters on the Hit List then ignore the effect.

When you activate Blood Brothers you must make a choice: either keep the tile Blood Brothers side up, or turn it over to The Moll side.

The Moll: Whenever one of your mobsters is added to the Hit List, you may take a mobster that is controlled by the player that put you on the Hit List and place it on the Hit List in the space behind your just-added mobster. When you activate The Moll, you must flip the tile back over to the Blood Brothers side.

When your mob is no longer the weakest in play, or you are eliminated, you must give the tile to the player with the weakest mob. If there is ever a tie, nobody may control the tile until one player has the weakest mob. When there are only three players left in the game, this tile is taken out of play and is returned to the box.

name: The Double: Football Game
description:
A game of hat tricks, F.A. Enquiries, penalty appeals, and last minute goals.
Home and away matches against all the other players.
The Double is a game of chance, tactics and cunning.
Good players will win the Premiership.
Great players will win the double. The Premiership and the F.A.Cup.
Which will you be?

Players (2-4) represent football teams vying to win the double of the Premiership, and the F.A.Cup. Each player represents either Blue (City), Yellow (County) Green (Rovers) or Red (United) and takes a corresponding coloured token and six sided dice. Players start at the bottom of the league table and a fixture card is drawn. Both players roll their dice with the winner moving up the table 3 places or 1 place if the result is draw. The board is divided into 5 zones forming from the bottom The relegation zone, danger zone, mid table, and European places. Each time a player passes into a new zone a tactic card is drawn which can used and played to affect the results of matches. The home team of each match can re-roll his result dice, but has to take that result of the re throw.
The winner of the premiership has the advantage of choosing the draw for the F.A. Cup and has a one goal advantage on his throw, but tactic cards cannot be used by the players in the F.A. Cup.

name: Althingi
description:
Althingi is a historical game for 3-5 players.

Players compete against each other to become the icelandic lawspeaker by controlling the provinces and thus having more influence during the periodic trials which bring order as well as chaos.

Every turn new provinces are added in contest while players try to gain them through an auction. It will be with that provinces and the wise use of the few action cards you get every turn that you'll fight to win the later trials, which are won by the player with most influence points. At the end of the game, the player with most won trials will be the winner. Or at least will get more chances to be the winner.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Auction/Bidding, Hand Management

name: Mystique Chain
description:
Mystique Chain is a cardgame played with The Mystique Deck.

Players try not to "break" the Mystique Chain by finding cards that share exactly one feature with the card taken before.

The deck is shuffled and 30 randomly chosen cards are placed on the table face up. Then both players draw one of the remaining cards. The card with the lower card number is immediately put to the discard pile, and so are also all the cards not reveald.
The player who drew the card with the higher card number chooses one of the three features of this card (Colour, Suit, Number) and puts the card on the discard pile. (During the first turn, he may not choose a card and a criteria that does not allwo the other player to find a matching card)

Then the other player must find a card that shares this feature, but none of the other two features of the card just discarded.
He chooses a card that fits this criterias, names a feature of this card and puts it to the discard pile. The game continues this way as long as players find fitting cards.

As soon as a player can´t find a fitting card, he loses the game.

name: El Futbol en Casa
description:
From the United States of America (who could imagine) comes the world’s best football board game. El fútbol en casa is truly football in the house. Your house. No, it is not a computer game where you pretend to make bicycle kicks, backheel passes, fantastic dribbles, terrific shots, and remarkable saves. It is not a game where the player with the best hand-eye coordination wins.
It is, rather, a football board game where knowledge of football strategy, tactics, and formations is more important than the ability to quickly punch a button or move a lever.
Why pretend you’re something you’re not? You’re not a football superstar and a computer will not make you one.
Why not play a football simulation game where your brain controls movement and play rather than some software program? You don’t have the physical abilities of the great players but you may have more overall, intrinsic knowledge of the game they play.
El fútbol en casa is a chess-like game of strategy and tactics where, in addition to good and bad fortune (always present in any sporting event), knowledge and skill determine the winner.
You are not a player or a coach. You are the team. You pick the formation. You move the players on your team and pass the ball. You make the tackling challenges and take the shots on goal. You commit fouls, suffer injuries, and get carded. You win. You lose. In short, you experience what a football team experiences.
This is an accurate, well-researched, mathematical representation of association football. All 17 Laws of the Game are incorporated in the play.
In addition to the Basic Game that pits two teams of equal strength against one another, a Tournament Play booklet is included that describes how teams of different strengths can play each other. (You could, for example, play all the games of the World Cup Finals.)
This all-wood game is recommended for players 13 years of age and up. Knowledge of football is helpful but not necessary. Also, many materials are included to individualize your game. (If, for example, you don’t like the color of your team’s kits or jerseys, you can make your own.)

(Designer's explanation)
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: AT-43 Unit Box: Strielitz Kolossus
description:
The Strielitz Kolossus chastise the enemy of the Revolution with steel and fire. With grenade launcher fastened to one arm and a flamer fastened to the other, they make their enemies tremble in righteous terror.

Standing testimony of the success of the Red Blok, Strielitz Kolossus units are irreproachably proficient: what they cannot burn, they pulverize. They reap the infantry and mow through battlesuit units with terrifying casualness.

The Strielitz Kolossus are infantry hunters, comfortable at all distances and against any category of infantry.

This unit box includes:
•Three miniatures: 2 Strielitz Kolossus, 1 Strielitz Kolossus Sgt.
•Two cards: Strielitz Kolossus, Strielitz Kolossus Sgt.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: AT-43 Attachment Box: Storm Golems
description:
This Attachment Box contains a storm golem overseer with nanoblaster and reaper blades, two storm golems with sonic gun, two storm golems with flamer and a storm golem relay with nanoblaster and reaper blades.

With these extra choices, your Therian soldiers will get real leadership and a wider range of special weapons. Flamer or Sonic gun, devastating rate of fire or napalm tidal waves? Adapt your methods to your opponent.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Mystique Energy
description:
Mystique Energy is a card game for 2 to 6 players that can be played with a Mystique deck.

To set-up, shuffle the deck and place it face down on the table. Each player then draws a card without showing it to the other players, looks at it, then places it face down before them. This is their "energy card" and can be looked at during play. Each player then draws another card; this is their "playing card".

The first two players lay their cards on the table adjacent to one another. Players take turns in counterclockwise order placing their card on the table adjacent to at least two placed cards so that the cards fit into an imaginary hexagonal grid, as shown in the image below:


_ _ _ _
| |_| |_| |_| |
|_| |_| |_| |_|
| |_| |_| |_| |
|_| |_| |_| |_|
| |_| |_| |_| |
|_| |_| |_| |_|
| |_| |_| |_| |
|_| |_| |_| |_|


After placing the card, the player draws another card from the deck (if possible) which becomes their new "playing card". The game ends when the last card has been placed on the table, and players then score as follows:


Each player counts the number of cards of the largest connected group of the color of his "energy card".



Each player counts the number of cards of the largest connected group of the suit of his "energy card".



Each player counts the number of cards of the largest connected group of the number of his "energy card".


Finally, each player multiplies these three values. The player with the lowest value wins. In case of a tie, the player among those tied who played his final card first wins.

name: Privateer: The Kilrathi Menace
description:
A Fanmade boardgame, based on the Wing Commander video game from 1993, Privateer: The Kilrathi Menace is a player-driven adventure.

Key Features:
-Challenging Solo and Multiplayer
-Emphasis on Replayability
-Dynamic Universe population
-Dynamic Universe behaviour
-Exploration and other variants
-Multiple quadrants to play in
-Meaningful advancement in multiple factions

Gameplay:
Players travel from location to location, trading goods, taking on missions and catering to powerful factions. Players can purchase and upgrade new ships and weapons to help them in their goals, all the while being hunted by Military or Pirate factions. With a dynamic reputation, actions players take will effect what planets, ships and equipment they have access to.

Goal:
Accomplishing great deeds, or difficult tasks will gain players Fame points, and Victory Points. These points will determine the most notorious adventurer in the game, with the most enduring legacy. The Solo play variants carry a sense of urgency and doom as players seek to save the quadrant, or become infamous before it is run into chaos by the Kilrathi Menace!
categories: Adventure, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Role Playing, Simulation, Trading

name: ASL: March Madness 2013 Commissar Pack
description:
Each year the Kansas City ASL club hosts the March Madness ASL tournament and the club releases a themed scenario pack at the tournament.

In 2013 the theme is Commissars. The Commisar pack features eight scenarios in which the Soviet player can have commissars (rule A25.22).

All eight scenarios in the Commissar Pack are predominantly larger scenarios; the pack has four large scenarios (over 50 squads engaged), three medimum scenarios (over 25 squads engaged) and one small (less than 25 squads engaged). The scenarios have frequent use of fortifications, unique terrain and environmental conditions. The Pack has seven scenarios with fortifications, two night scenarios, two with extreme winter rules, one amphibious landing and all eight have water hexes (although two are ice rules). The scenarios are:

MM25 Futile Bravery. This scenario takes place during the battle for Smolensk in July 1941. It is a large scenario with the Soviets attacking and Germans defending in an urban environment. The Germans are defending a bridge (Russians win immediately when they control any location). The Russian start on both sides of the river and are reinforced by massive numbers (25 squads) of conscripts stiffined by NKVD troops and commissars. There are also two platoons of T-26 tanks. With these number the Russians can (and likely will) launch human wave attacks. One play test saw no less than six different HW attacks by the Russian player. The Germans defent with Good infantry well equiped with MGs and well led. They also get a radio and 105mm OBA. And a few mobile HTs one with an 81mm MTR. The Germans get a platoon of reinforcing tanks. There is a great deal of rubble in this scenario because of the scorch earth activity of the NKVD and more is in the making. The scenario uses Board 60, with its hills and city environment, Board 8 without the hills and most building are rubble and board 23 with the canal as a large railroad embankment. The Germans must used the mobility of the HTs to reinforce where the main attack falls and have the OBA spotter in the right place.

MM26 Gallant Mogilev. This also takes place in July 1941. It is a medium sized engagement between the attacking Germans and defending Russian. The Germans must break through the fortified Russian positions and capture a bridge. The Russians must defend tenaciously. It uses board 64 to represent the suburban outskirts of the city and board 65 with the river overlay. The Russians receive fortifications including fortified buildings, roadblocks, trenches, wire and mines. Plus two immoble tanks. The Germans get good troops, good leaders, an infantry gun and OBA.

MM27 Odessa Madness. This is a large scenario where the Germans must help the Romanians take a fortified villiage strongpoint. The Russians get strong forces with fortifications including pillboxes, fortified buildings, tunnels, trenches, wire, foxholes and mines. The Germans get assult engineers, sappers and OBA...along with Romanians. The battle takes mostly on board 12 with the gullies actually as AT ditches.

MM28 Sonderkommando Benesch. This small scenario has five Brandenburg squads trying to move past a pillbox and Rusiian defenders to exit. It uses board 7 and 40 to creat a constricted peninsula. Giving the Russians opportunity to make the Germans attack the pillbox.

MM29 Sorve Point. This medimum scenarios has the Germans making an attack against a fortified Russian psoitions. The battle is to capture the level two hill hexes of board 61 with limited mobility of using the seashore on one side using board 7 and marsh on the other. The Russians have fortifications of pillboxes, trenches, foxholes, wire and mines. They also have OBA. The Germans have good troops, MGs and leaders with OBA of their own.

MM30 Frozen Vzvad. This is the first night and extreme winter scenario, with 40 attacking Russian squads against 20 German in January 1942. The Germans receive pillboxes, fortified buildings, trenches, wire and mines. The Russsians receive Rocket OBA and the cover of night. The Russians are attacking to capture over 30 buildings on Boards 3, 8 and 7 between the two frozen rivers. The Germans defend the buildings and cannot let the Russians build up a fire base to blast them out.

MM31 Sevastopol by Sea. This night scenario has the Germans landing and taking the high ground against good Russian troops in June 1942. The scenario starts with the Germans almost across board 8 and landing. However they must get past the Russian sentries and capture the crest of the board 58 hill. The Russian have high morale naval infantry. The Germans have the cover of night in this medimum size scenario.

MM 32 Winter Forest. This scenario has extreme winter in December 1942 with the Germans attacking Partisans to capture the Partisan camp bunkers. The Partisans outnumber the Germans. However the ski equipped Germans can outrun the Partisans and attack from multiple directions in the forested boards of 34, 37 and 52. With the forests the Partisans start much of the fortification HIP and have wire to slow the Germans. The Germans get OBA and can use a barrage rule to box in the Partisans. A SSR give the Partisans Commissars for extra rally purposes. Just how useful it will with the Germans closing in form all sides remains to be seen.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: PLAN 4: 2-ELEVEN
description:
You become a bank robber in competition with other bank robbers to see who is the greatest. The winner is the first bank robber to rob 3 banks. Sounds easy? That's what they all think.

In this game, players use action cards to speed up their own progress and slow down their competition. Robbing a bank requires a plan (dealt in card form at the beginning of the game and after each successful robbery) and each plan contains 4 resources needed to make it happen. The whereabouts of the 16 resources are always known but control is decided by... well... you.

name: Undead Apocalypse: War of the Damned
description:
Zombies! vs Vampires! vs Humans! vs Werewolves! in a fast-paced struggle for world domination — with high-quality miniatures!

Undead Apocalypse is a fast-paced, beautifully-designed board game for 2 to 4 players. Each game lasts 30 to 90 minutes and pits factions of Zombies, Vampires, Werewolves, and post-apocalyptic Humans against each other in a fight to the death (or undeath, as it were). Think Mad Max meets Walking Dead with a little detour through Transylvania. We’ve put together an amazing team of artists, production people, and game designers to bring this crazed vision to life—and we hope you’ll join us in realizing the next evolution of the supernatural war game.

After World War III the people of Earth thought it couldn’t get any worse; they were wrong. The nuclear devastation was bad enough, reducing once-great cities to rubble and forcing hardy survivors to scavenge for resources. But soon—whether the result of radiation, toxins, or supernatural wrath—ancient evils long thought mere legend awoke and took hold in the real world.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor, Miniatures, Mythology, Science Fiction, Territory Building, Wargame, Zombies
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Player Elimination, Role Playing, Variable Player Powers

name: Quarq
description:
Quarq is a card game system. You can play an unlimited number of games with a Deck of Quarqs.

Quarq games are simple. The rules for each fit on a single card.

Fundamentally, Quarq is a deck of 72 cards, consisting of

60 Quarq cards, each a unique "3-D" combination of 3 of the 12 suits
12 suit cards, which are used in some games


Quarq comes packaged with 14 games, including

5 adaptations of top traditional card games
4 brand new strategy card games
3 novel stand-up games
2 poker games


...and many more Quarq games added by YOU, the community, at quarq.org.

Quarq games range from
twists on traditional games like Bridge, Hearts, Concentration, to
radically new games that could not be played with a traditional deck of cards, like Psychics, Trade Routes, Conquistaspores. Some are designed for 2 young kids; others are for 15 abstract thinkers.

Quarq games are more radically diverse than traditional card games. They use almost any other mechanic.

As it is a game system, Quarq is also a creative medium.
At quarq.org, players can create new games, or post reviews of existing Quarq games. They earn points for their participation.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Game System, Party Game
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Memory, Player Elimination, Team-Based Game, Trading, Trick-taking

name: Chung Ling Soo Murder Mystery
description: Chung Ling Soo was a very talented stage magician who was shot and killed during last nights performance. You play a police detective who will try to bring in more evidence than the other players. The game board is made up of 12 hex tiles which make up a map of London. You may move your pawns around a maze of streets, back alleys and even make use of the Underground train system. The three interior tiles have police stations, the nine outside tiles have evidence locations. The object of this game is to score the most victory points. Victory points are earned by moving your "police" pawn around the game board to various named evidence locations, acquiring the evidence and returning the evidence to one of three police stations. When you attempt to find the piece of evidence you decide how valuable it will be, the more valuable the harder it is to find. During your game turn you also move one of nine "bad" guy pawns. When moved adjacent to another players pawn you may pay the "bad" guy to attempt to steal various items from the player (money, tools, or evidence). The game ends when evidence from all differently named nine evidence tiles have been turned in by any combination of players.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Mechanised Warfare Rules
description:
User Description

A set of simple fast play wargame rules designed for fighting large scale battles using 6mm and 2mm scale miniatures. They cover the period from 1935 to the present day.

They also have WWII army lists, supplement rules for post 1945 and air to ground aircraft rules.

They have been designed to use a D6 dice and minitures which are multiable based in to units (dependent on scale).
categories: Miniatures, Vietnam War, Wargame, World War II

name: Arcanite Wars
description:
A Card-Driven Action Strategy Game!

The planet Antaeras was a thriving world, full of majestic beauty and alive with a natural flow of magic that extended to all its inhabitants. This magic was its most precious commodity…but would also prove to be its downfall.

The ages-long civil war between the Brotherhood of Steam and the Reptilisaur Empire has now become a three-way battle with the appearance of the Corrupted Legion.

ARCANITE WARS is a strategy card game for two players where you must harvest resources, construct a base, train units, explore the terrain around you, and battle the enemy army. The player who destroys his opponent's Headquarters is victorious!

If you are familiar with the concepts behind the Real-Time Strategy game genre (think Command and Conquer, StarCraft, Age of Empires, etc), then you will easily pick up the flow of this game.

The Core Set comes complete with a set of Terrain cards and three races:

> The Brotherhood of Steam
> The Reptilisaur Empire
> The Corrupted Legion

Each of these races uses two decks: its Race deck (Units, buildings, and Workers) and Event deck (consisting of special abilities and ways to add to Units' strength on the battlefield). Each race has different strengths and plays differently from the others.

Everything you need to play is included - just grab another player and let the battle begin!

name: Conan the Barbarian
description:
"Conan the Barbarian" is an adventure wargame for 2 to 4 players with each of the players representing one of the major factions of Hyboria. Each faction has agents at their disposal with which they attempt to thwart their enemies plans while enlisting the aid of Conan. There are five types of agents: Wizards, Warriors, Courtesans, Assassins, and Thieves. Each type of agent has different capabilities and different strategies for enlisting the aid of our hero.

SPI's planned "Conan the Barbarian" adventure wargame featured a full-color map of Hyboria, character cards, event cards, and counters for every major character. A pre-publication play test kit was released. There was comprehensive background material written by L. Sprague de Camp.

name: Le Vol de l'Aigle: Volume 3 ‚Äì Le systeme complet
description:
Le Vol de l'Aigle III (The Flight of the Eagle III) is a wargame that recreates some of the most famous Napleonic campaigns.

The system is a double-blinded system that uses an Umpire. Players can communicate only through written messages. It uses maps of that time and a simple system to manage units. Combats are solved using a face to face system, simple but precise, with the morale as the main endpoint. Combats can also be solved using any existing operational or tactical system including miniatures.

The present volume 3 does not need the volume 1 or 2 to be played. It includes four booklets (three are over 60 pages) including all the rules of volume 1 and 2, a new edition of the tactical rules The Eagle Fights, 50 pages of data to transfer all the armies of the time between both systems, the special rules of the ten campaigns included: Bavaria and Austria 1809, France 1814 and the eight Peninsula campaigns in Spain and Portugal (around one a year between 1808 and 1814). Seven maps and 52 units sheets are included.

Cherry on the cake, an experimental recruitment module is also presented, with a strategic map, two pages of units, and rules managing every parameter involved in the Administration of War.

The game is available in French and in English.
mechanics: Paper-and-Pencil, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: SimSoccer, The Board Game
description:
You are the head coach of soccer team either World Star Team or Europe Star Team. You are under pressure of the competition with your opponent. Situation in the field is going on by simple simulation mechanic, fast move game and very dynamic in its situation.

Lets proves yourselves as the Great head coach of the team. Foresee the match situation, watch out the dynamic of game and manage team by relocate kicker at the right place - right time. That is the way you can dominate the game in dynamic situation.

You will surprise game can be changed dramatically if you plan well tactically and strategically and put into action at the right place - right time.

name: Mixed Motives
description:
This is a psychology-themed card game for 2 to 6 players.

At the start of the game, each player is dealt two Need cards visible to everyone, a Motivation card visible only to the player, and a hand of six cards containing a mixture of Fulfilment and Action cards. The Need cards specify quantities of Fulfilment points you have to collect in order to satisfy your Needs. However, the Motivation card gives your objective for the game. You could be a Dominator, seeking to fulfil your own Needs whilst ensuring other players' Needs are not met. You could be an Idealist, trying to make sure everyone's Needs are fulfilled. You could be a Victim, making sure that everyone's needs are satisfied except yours.

There are 12 different Motivations, each with a game goal with different levels of difficulty and worth different scores. If you achieve your Motivation and you have an "End game" card, you can claim the points. But beware! It's possible that more than one Motivation can be achieved simultaneously, so another player may claim points too.

The Fulfilment cards allow you to satisfy your Needs or the Needs of other players. The Action cards allow players to manipulate the distribution of Fulfilment cards, moving or discarding Fulfilment or even forcing players to change their Motivation.
publishers: Agreedibus Games, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: City Center
description:
City Center is a map-building / tile-laying game about planning a city. City planners (the players) take turns placing new buildings into the grid. After each round of placement, the new buildings are scored and the next round commences. When the whole city grid is filled in, the game is over and the planner with the most points wins.

As an additional twist, each player has full knowledge of the tiles she'll choose from right at the beginning. Once a player draws her hand of buildings, there are no more draws. She'll have to play all but two of the cards.

The game scales from 2 to 7 players by increasing the size of the city grid and eventually decreasing the number of cards in the hand. For instance, at 2 players, the city will grow to 4x4 and each player will have a hand of 10. At 7, the city is 6x6 and the players have a hand of only 7. Each player gets an equal number of chances to score; sometimes an initial card is played (unscored) to start off the city.

name: Expedition
description:
This game of strategy is a welcome break from gin rummy and can be played with a standard deck of cards.

The main dynamic is deciding what to hang on to, and what to discard (which can be taken by your opponent).

If you like Lost Cities, you'll love this!

Rules at:
https://blogger.standardgames.com/2021/12/expedition-rules.h...

name: Bug Planet
description:
“You’re not paid to survive; you’re paid to produce”

A Mysterious alien planet has been discovered and it is ripe with rare minerals, bizarre physics, and many opportunities for profit; Your corporate masters have sent you on a mission to gear up, start an outpost, and plunder these new resources. But great fortunes such as these always come with great risks, and in this case, it’s a massive population of giant insects that inhabit the world. Balance the terror of certain annihilation against the greedy desires of your corporate sponsors to ravage the land of its precious resources as quickly as you can. Time is short for those looking to out produce their competitors on the planet, because the never-ending hordes of terrestrial life don’t kill you, your boss just might.

Bug Planet is a tower defence worker placement game where two-to-four players can vie against each other in an attempt to control the production of the planet's valuable resources. The game is broken down into a sequence of phases where:

1.) Giant killer alien bugs are added outside of each player's outpost.

2.) Players take turns adding modules to their outpost (such as new weapons, housing, forcefields, and more, while also collecting resources such as minerals, electricity and export points using a worker placement system.

3.) Players take turns activating the modules in their outpost by spending the electricity they have collected this turn. This is mostly done to power up weapons and try to kill the bugs bearing down on them, but also players may mine additional minerals, perform scientific research or reduce the panic in their base (if they have the right modules).

4.) Come nightfall the bugs are on the move. Any bug that survived the day will get a chance to move closer to the player's outpost. The closer they get the more panic they inspire and the more damage they can possibly deal.

Eventually, once it becomes apparent panic has begun to set in at one or more of the competing outposts, your bosses will pull the plug on the whole operation (by way of orbital nuke, since it's the only way to be sure). Be the player who has best fulfilled your corporate mission objectives to be posthumously declared the winner, your spouse will be sent a tasteful plaque!

name: Galactic Incursion
description:
The Galactic Empire is under siege from an extra-dimensional entity known as the Incursion. The Emperor is going mad and amid this chaos, the lords of the various factions (i.e., the players) have decided this is the perfect time to consolidate their power and diminish their rivals.

Galactic Incursion is a card game for 2-4 players that represents this power struggle in which the safety of the Galaxy is second to the ambitions of the few!

Galactic Incursion is available through The Game Crafter as well as a print and pplay version on the Wargame Vault. An Android version is in the works, which will be available in the Google Ap store.

name: Le Feu Sacr√©: A la B√§ionette ‚Äì Twenty-one scenarios for Corps sized action of the Napoleonic wars
description:
A la Bäionette provides twenty-one historical scenarios for Napoleonic gamers based covering the entire period of the wars of Napoleon, from 1796 to 1815. Each scenario comes with historical background, briefings for both sides along with victory conditions, a map of the tabletop and a full order or battle based on extensive historical research.

The emphasis is on providing playable enjoyable games that suit your situation, so the scenarios are broken down in to three types. The majority are suitable for an evening at the club where you want to complete play in two or three hours. The second group is scenarios for four or five hours and the last, smaller group, is for scenarios that could be played over an entire day.

The following scenarios are included:


Caldiero, 1796
Trebbia Parts One and Two, 1799
Hohenlinden, 1800
Austerlitz, 1805
Sokolnitz, 1805
Anklappen, 1807
Medina de Rioseco, 1808
Teugen-Hausen, 1809
Abensburg, 1809
Maria, 1809
Anderklaa, 1809
Znaim, 1809
Salamanca, 1812
Utitsa, 1812
Castalla, 1813
Eisdorf, 1813
Hagelburg, 1813
Mockern, 1813
St Pierre, 1813
Plancenoit, 1815
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame

name: Gener√°lov√©: Dynamick√° bitevni hra
description:
Generálové (Commanders) is a dynamic war game in which the players test their skills on the battlefields of Napoleonic wars. Through skillful planning, careful preparations, commitment and a little luck, one player will emerge victorious.

Generálové (Commanders) differs from other wargames by simultaneous order planing and resolution, by the austere elegance of Chess, and by the incredible variety of combat situations on mere nine battlefield spaces. Infantry, cavalry and artillery clash in a series of fights in which the victorious player usually is the one who positioned his troops more skilfuly and better used unit abilities in a combat. Even a slight twist in another section of the battlefield can influence the outcome. Situation is constantly changing and it is usually not until the last moment one can be sure of victory.

Rules offer a range of optional mechanics and is suitable both for beginners and for seasoned wargamers.
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Secret Unit Deployment, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Nonsense
description:
"Nonsense - the hilarious game of big government spending" board game created by A. Berkeley Compton, approved by Loren Dunton and published by Fair-Games, Inc.

Preparation: each player receives $76,960,300.00, separate 4 DEEDS from card decks, place "directive cards" and "white house clemency cards" in a single pile, face down.

Game play: low roller of dice shuffles "directive cards" deck, has player to the right cut the deck and then deals the first 12 cards face up around the field, starting at space 1. Dealer also places the next 6 cards from the deck face down near the playing field. These are bonus cards and are drawn from if the instructions on the directive card for that turn say to dra2 a bonus card.

Player to the right of dealer starts play and rolls dice to determine which numbered space to advance to and which corresponding "directive card" instructions are to be followed for that turn. Any directive card that says it is to be held by a player is removed from the playing field when the player lands on that space. Any player landing at a space with no directive card next to it does nothing more for that turn. After each person has played, an "administration" is completed, and a new "administration" starts.

Object of game: players roll dice, take cards, follow directions and compete to be the first to declare bankruptcy by spending all their money and earn the title "Certified deficit spender".

name: literumi
description:
Literumi is a 4 player partnership trick-taking game, similar to Bridge or Spades, but with a word-making twist, like Scrabble or Bananagrams.

Success in Literumi requires critical thinking, careful planning, deliberate teamwork and a quick wit.

At first, teams bid with the number of words they think they can make. The winner of the bid gets to call trump, but they have to complete their contract to make any points. Then teams take tricks, to get as many letters as possible. Finally, both teams have two minutes to turn those letters into words. The more words you make, the more points you get.

name: Pong Tactics
description: Pong Tactics is a strategy card game that adds new gameplay mechanics to the classic drinking game beer pong. 10 cups are set up on either side of an 8 foot table. One Formation card is selected to determine the formation of the 10 cups on both sides of the table and then the cards are set aside. Cups may be filled with water or beer (if players are of legal drinking age). The remainder of the game is Action Cards. These cards impact the normal beer pong rules in various ways, such as changing the shot, number of shots, cards in hand, blocking shots, determining the end of the game and much more. The game is played by teams of two players on each side of the table. Each player on a team takes one shot at the cups on the other side of the table; if they make the ball into a cup, it is removed and the player takes a drink either from their own drink or the cup. The goal is to remove all of your opponent's cups by making all the shots. The Action Cards can aid your team or hinder your opponent in achieving the end game goal.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Party Game
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Take That

name: Stations Manned and Ready 2nd Edition
description:
Stations Manned and Ready II is a downloadable set of tactical naval miniatures rules for ship models of 1/2400 or 1/6000 scale (though other scales can be accommodated). Like the first edition of the rules, these rules are set at a squadron level, allowing relatively large battles to be fought on a normal table in 2 to 4 hours. In the 2nd Edition all the separate parts that were in the 1st Edition have been combined and the combat system revised in order that it follows a consistent structure.

The period covered by the rules has been backdated to ca. 1885, and the data sets available expanded even further than before. The data in the system is compatible throughout so ships from all periods could be matched against each other, though this may not be recommended.

Ship data is presented in sets for nations and time eras. The data sheets are fully prepared for you, so there is no need to fill out separate sheets. The only proviso is that when using smaller vessels you may have print several copies and the names will have to be entered individually by the player. Ships from cruiser upwards all have individual sheets. All data sheets take account of revisions of armament at various times.

Time scales are 6 minutes for a game turn, combat is regulated by the use of 5,000 yard range bands, which provide gun penetration values and torpedo hit modifiers. Armour protection is converted to an armour class on specific areas of the ship, taking account of the armour type and date. Damage represents those hits that cause significant damage to the target, and critical hits cause degradation of the combat effectiveness of ships. Command and crew quality are important and ships are commanded and crewed by men of mixed ability, generated using systems which players will recognise from other A&A titles.

The chance of critical damage is now keyed to the "size of the bang" involved, and the number of guns firing (in the case of ships). More guns means a more chances of causing critical damage, and larger shells/bombs mean a higher chance that critical damage will occur. Higher chances also mean that the damage effects may also be more extensive, because we have expanded the way in which the critical damage system works.

Play follows a sequence using initiative. The winner of initiative chooses which side will move a squadron first. Movement then alternates between the two sides. During Movement the slowest elements finish their movement first, so the order is all submarines, then all ships, finally all aircraft. The winner of initiative then shoots with a squadron first, and then play alternates. Combat actions ignore the type of element involved.

Movement takes into account the manoeuvrability of ships of different sizes. Gunnery takes into account the crew skill of the firing ship, interference by shooting from other vessels, the size of the target and the number of guns firing. Hits will cause structural damage and may also cause critical hits, which will degrade the combat effectiveness of the vessel. As ships get more damaged, there is a possible effect on morale, which may cause formations to withdraw to lick their wounds.
categories: Miniatures, Nautical, Print & Play, Wargame, World War I, World War II
mechanics: Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation, Variable Phase Order

name: Bulwark: The Winter of Death
description:
From publisher description:

More Heroic Co-operative Deck-Building!

So, you've faced down goblins and fire lizards at Fort Briggs and think you're pretty tough? Well, try the Winter of Death on for size. More cards, more options, more opportunities to take a thrashing from a card game.

This expansion rounds out the basic Bulwark set with the following:


A new hero - Wiola Wildborne, the huntress.
2 new enemy armies to face - the Fallen Elf's Vengeance and the Winter of Death
3 new locations to defend - the Citadel of Xajorkith, the Sylvan Heights and the town of Holtvaros.


The starter set of Bulwark is split into two products - this expansion and the base set.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Variable Player Powers

name: Bulwark: The Messianic Uprising
description:
From publisher description:

Heroic Co-operative Deck-Building!

No-one knows what dark secrets were whispered into the ear of magecraft's most promising student in generations. Whatever they were, they led him to reject the wisdom of his teachers and take short-cuts to power - ones that left him far less, or perhaps far more, than human. He is consumed with the desire to destroy the mages he felt were holding him back, at the head of an army of brainwashed followers.

You Are Not Ready To Face This

The Messianic Uprising is a challenging Foe deck that can run you out of Wounds without even putting any into your deck. Almost every card interacts the the others, leaving you with very little room for error. Worst of all, the Arcane Messiah himself becomes harder to kill and more dangerous the more of his minions are around.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Variable Player Powers

name: Luck of the Draw
description: Luck of the Draw is a real time dice and card game that takes place in the Wild West. Two rival Posses are having a shootout at high noon and will settle the score once and for all! Roll your dice to take a shot while simultaneously turning over the top card of your Shootout deck. The Shootout deck can be a blessing or a curse! It’ll determine the direction of your shot, whether the backup comes in, or if one of your Posse members can get behind cover! The first player to eliminate the opposing Posse wins.
categories: American West, Card Game, Dice, Print & Play

name: Battles of 1866: German Armies
description:
From the Avalanche Press website:

Battles of 1866: German Armies

As war loomed over Germany in the early summer of 1866, Bavaria aligned itself with Austria against Prussia and armed for war. The Bavarian chief of staff, Ludwig Freiherr von der Tann, met with the Austrian leadership and suggested that the Bavarian army march into Bohemia. There they would form the left wing of the Austrian North Army, and hold off the Prussian First Army at Jicin while the Austrians dealt with the Prussian Second Army.

Von der Tann’s bold plan might well have given the Allies victory, but the Austrian commander, Ludwig von Benedek, turned him down and Bavaria pursued a separate strategy. By the time Benedek changed his mind and called for the Bavarians to advance, it was already too late.

Battles of 1866: German Armies is a downloadable expansion set for Battles of 1866: Frontier Battles. It adds the armies of Bavaria, Hesse-Kassel and Nassau to the game as well as the Prussian Cavalry Corps and First Army artillery reserve. There are two scenarios included: a meeting engagement between the Prussian and German armies and a Prussian assault on a prepared German defense. This module is not playable separately; it requires ownership of Battles of 1866: Frontier Battles.

German Armies is a .pdf download. The playing pieces are not die-cut and mounted, nor is the scenario book printed. Instead it comes as a series of .pdf files that will need to be assembled into the game's components.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Post-Napoleonic, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Area-Impulse, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: Examplary
description:
Get rid of your hand before everyone else!

Play the letters and topics by giving matching examples.
You've gotta G in your hand, and the topic is Bugs, so say "Grasshopper!" and play the G!

Now the letter is G, and you have Fictional People.
So say "Gandalf!" and get rid of your card!

But think quick before someone changes the topic--there are no turns!

name: Math Battleship Game
description: This page does not exist. You can edit this page to create it.

name: Classic BattleTech: Historical ‚Äì Brush Wars
description:
From the publisher: The Ronin Wars. The Andurien/Magistracy invasion of House Liao. The Anton Revolt and subsequent Marik Civil War. Against the empire spanning conflicts of the Fourth Succession War, Clan Invasion and FedCom Civil War, historians all too often forget such important conflicts, relegating them to the category of "low intensity warfare." Yet it is these very conflicts that tend to shape the internal politics and culture of each faction, often with more profound impact than the largest wars.

The Historical: Brush Wars campaign sourcebook details the actions involving every line unit in the most important "low level conflicts" of the early thirty-first century. Maps and full regiment listings convey additional details, while ample campaign rules provide a framework allowing players to replay detail of each war.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Variable Player Powers

name: Dice Farm
description:
Dice Farm is a dice-rolling, card-drafting, farming game.

Players start with a small number of workers (dice) in their color, and roll them to determine what cards they can collect/use based on those dice.

Do you go for agriculture, animals, technology or a balanced strategy to end up with the best farm at the end of the game.

Additional goals can also earn points for the things like the biggest wheat crop, the most cows, etc...

name: Minus Pocus
description:
The world mightiest magic schools face to prove themselves. The better students will fight between fireballs, ciclopean walls and terrific bunnies. A fast game for all ages of frenzied and mathematical fun.

Three spell cards are show between both players at every moment. They show a number (from 1 to 80) and various magical effects.

The players take ingredient cards from a common deck, containing numbers and operations and try to throw the spells by getting the exact number on it, making sums, subtractions and other operations with their ingredients. The game is won when a player knock out all the mages on the opposing team.

Website is in spanish but you can download the english rules inside. The game is not language dependant.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Math, Print & Play, Real-time

name: BattleTech: Domination
description:
Disclaimer: This is an unofficial, unauthorized, non-profit, fan-made game and is in NO WAY associated with The Topps Company Inc., Catalyst Game Labs, Piranha Games, or Harebrained Schemes. It is a pure labor of love! Battletech, ‘Mech, and MechWarrior are registered trademarks of the The Topps Company, Inc. I do not claim any credit for the artwork used in the game. All fan artwork used with permission of the artists. Screenshots obtained from MechWarrior Online, developed and published by Piranha Games.


BATTLETECH: DOMINATION is a deck-building card game for 2 players set in the BattleTech/MechWarrior universe. Both players start with a small deck of weak cards and strive to build a deck that dominates their opponent with an army of powerful BattleMechs, combat vehicles, infantry, and advanced technology. Support, Resource, and Attack cards also generate powerful effects to help you achieve dominance on the battlefield. At the end of the game, the players score points for each LosTech card in their deck while subtracting points for any Overrun cards in their deck.

BTD v4.1 is the the current version of the game as of 12/10/2016 and contains a total of 205 cards.

LINKS TO GAME CONTENT:

BattleTech: Domination v4.1 FULL CARD SET - 8.5x11" DIY Print Ready
BattleTech: Domination v4.1 QUICK PLAY RULES


THANK YOU to the artists who gave me their personal blessing to use their amazing artwork in Battletech: Domination: Florian Mellies (SpOoKy777), Alex Iglesias (FlyingDebris), Anthony Scroggins (ShimmeringSword), Kristian Borg (Punakettu), Chris S (colourbrand), Joakim Olofsson, and Lordred.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Word Whimsy: Bonus Cards
description:
Six bonus cards that expand the base game. No question cards, only answers.

Cryptozoic made these available to retailers: "Hobby stores that order Word Whimsy through an authorized distributor will receive these promo cards directly with their order (while supplies last, so act fast!). Stores will receive one promo pack for each game purchased to reward their loyal customers."

name: Pearl Harbor Attack Thunderfish Torpedo Strike
description:
Tired of small gaming counters, sluggish play processes, or the mindless arcade play of many computer war games? Want more realism, direct action play, and observable battle results without losing the lively historic qualities. Historians and gamers will find the game pace, play method, and varied outcomes to be fascinating. Parents, teachers, and students will recognize the great advantage of learning while playing.

This game is part of a larger "Re-enactment Guide" for the attack on Pearl Harbor.

In this game, you make duplicate copies of the battleship target illustrations and the numberd "Special Factors" cards. Then follow the simple attack procedures against each battleship. Damage scores will vary depending where the torpedo hit occurs plus a random number variation. Hence, player can expect a different outcome each time they play the game. The game can be plyed solo to in small groups.

Play as the IJN torpedo bomber force armed with the secret shallow water Type 91 Mod. 2 "Thunderfish" torpedo as they attack American battleships in Pearl Harbor. The attack that ended the battleship era. Game variables include, increasing anti-aircraft resistance, aborted & recycled attack attempts, torpedo stuck in mud, and a variable math expression to calculate damage/flooding calculations. Final game score can be matched against the historical recorded or tallied in other ways (percent damage and/or number of hits).

Games will be mailed in a large envelope.
Printed Game Parts Include:
•Rules of Play

•Illustrated "Graphic" Activity Diagram

•Pearl Harbor Map (letter size paper)

•Battleship Torpedo Target Illustrations (Gray scale prints on legal size 20# paper format) USS Nevada, USS Arizona, USS West Virginia, USS Oklahoma, and USS California

•Special Impact Overlay Transparency

•Score Sheets

•Special Affects/Randomizing Number (print & cut) Game Cards

[Game Parts, Target Illustrations, and Score Sheets are Copyrighted but can be reproduced for non-commercial use by the individual purchaser for years of play in your home or in your school classroom]

name: PEARL HARBOR ATTACK 800KG AP BOMBER STRIKE
description:
Want more realism, direct action play, and observable battle results without losing the lively historic qualities? Tired of small gaming counters, sluggish play processes, or the mindless arcade play of many computer war games? Historians and gamers will find the game pace, play method, and varied outcomes to be fascinating. Parents, teachers, and students will recognize the great advantage of learning while playing.
In this game, you make duplicate copies of the battleship target illustrations and the numbered "Special Factors" cards. Then follow the simple attack procedures against each battleship. Damage scores will vary depending where bomb hits occur plus a random number variation. Hence, player can expect a different outcome each time they play the game. The game can be plyed solo to in small groups.

This game is part of a larger Pearl Harbor Re-enactment Guide. This part of the game based upon the high level bomber attack on Battleship Row, Pearl Harbor. Forty-eight high Level bombers, in ten arrow formations, carrying and dropped the secret "Dragon Tooth" 800kg armor piercing bomb against the inboard battleship on Battleship Row, Pearl Harbor. Fouled by smoke and sun glare, they managed to make a dismal six hits on American battleships. Although, only six big bombs hit American battleships, one No.80 bomb struck and penetrated the USS Arizona's forward powder magazine causing a violent explosion. The game can be adapted easily for solo or team play. Can you do better?

Play Commander Mitsuo Fuchida's attack on American battleships in Pearl Harbor. The attack that ended the battleship era. Game "Special Factors" features include, anti-aircraft resistance, Shoot Downs, Damage Aircraft, Aborted Runs, Smoke differential, Powder Magazine Hit, Near Miss Damage, and a variable Math Expression Calculating Bomb Hit Damage. Final game score can be matched against the historical recorded or tallied in other ways (percent damage and/or number of hits).

Game will be shipped in large envelope.

Printed Game Parts Include:

>Activity Rules

>Illustrated "Graphic" Activity Diagram/Guide
Pearl Harbor Map (Gray scale coloring on letter size paper)
Battleship Target Illustrations (Gray scale prints on legal size 20# paper format) USS Nevada, USS Arizona, USS West Virginia & USS Tennessee, USS Oklahoma & USS Maryland, USS Pennsylvania, and USS California

>Score Sheets

>Unique Bomb Plot Overlay Transparency

>Randomizing Number (print & cut) cards



Game Parts, Target Illustrations, and Score Sheets are Copyrighted but can be reproduced for non-commercial use by the individual purchaser for years of play in your home or in your school classroom

name: Let's Play Two! Baseball Game
description:
Let's Play Two! Baseball Game is a free, print and play baseball game released by Hot Stove Games in 2002. The game is designed to replicate what Henry Waugh's Universal Baseball Association Game may have looked like from the book, "The Universal Baseball Association Inc. J. Henry Waugh Prop." by Robert Coover. This allows you to create your own baseball league where players grow old, become all-stars or simply fade away from the league. From rookie to retirement you follow their careers and act as commissioner and God of their universe just as Henry Waugh did in the book.

The game is played by rolling three six sided dice to simulate a baseball game. Batters can hit for power, strike out, walk, etc. based on their roll. The unique thing about this game is if you play a full season the rules have you "re-rate" players based on their seasonal performance to continue play to the next season. This way, you create a living, breathing baseball universe with your own champions, hall of famers, and heros!

name: Piles
description:
Piles is played using a standard 52 card deck, by four players in teams of two. Team members are opposite each other. The dealer deals out 10 cards for each player, one by one; the remaining 12 cards are placed in the middle of the desk, arranged in a 4x3 rectangle called “Castle”. The player left to the dealer starts play placing one card on the Castle; the others will follow in clockwise order. The color (red or black) of the first card played by the opener assigns the color of each team for that game: e.g., if the opener chooses to play a 3 of Hearts, he and his partner will be the Reds, and the other team the Blacks. Goal of the Reds is to score points by capturing black cards, and vice versa for the Blacks. Cards are to be placed on the Castle, on top of those already on the desk, forming piles controlled by the card on top of it. Each card has an intrinsic value that follows the natural order, starting from the Ace (1) up to the King (13). In the Castle, each card can have from 2 up to 4 neighbors, i.e. cards adjacent either horizontally or vertically. The total value of a card on the Castle is equal to its intrinsic value increased by 1 for each neighbor of the same color and decreased by 1 for each of the opposite: e.g. a red 10 having 3 red and 1 black neighbors, will have a total value equal to the intrinsic value of a Queen.

Rules of the game:
1 - it's alway allowed to place on top of a card another card of the same color
2- a card of the opposite color can be placed, changing the control of the pile, if the card to be placed has an intrinsic value higher than the total value of the card on top of that pile
3- a player can pass the turn. In that case, the opponent at his left will pick at random one of his cards. That card will be added to the piles picked up at the end of the game, possibly contributing to the score.

End of the game and scoring:
A game is over after 10 turns, when the players run out of cards. Each team picks up the piles topped by the cards of their color: all the cards of the opposite color inside the controlled piles are captured and used for the final score. In the final scoring, an Ace is worth 9 points, a King 4, a Queen 3, a Jack 2 and the remaing cards 1 point each. The Red team will sum up the values of the captured black cards, and the other way around for the Blacks.

Two players game:
The game can also be played by two players, under the same rules. In that case, when the two players run out of the first 10 cards, the dealer will deal out the remaing and the game will go on as usual.

name: 5 Kingdoms
description:
5 Kingdoms is a card/tile laying game where the object of the game is to score the most points by controlling a combination of five territories called realms. Players draw, manage, and place land cards in patterns according to their type. In addition to placing land cards players must also place five kingdom tokens on the land cards in order to create point scoring realms.

There are six different land cards: deserts, forests, hills, lakes, mountains, and swamps. Each land type is placed in a particular pattern and scored in its own fashion. Lakes are the only land cards that cannot be claimed by a kingdom token to score points.

In basic gameplay the kingdom tokens do not have any special value causing only the claimed land cards to be scored at the games end. During advanced play each of the players five kingdom tokens has a special ability that can effect kingdom token and land card placement or scoring. The five advanced kingdoms are cloud, fire, gold, iron, and water.

5 Kindgoms does not require a playing board or score counter and is limited only by the flat surface it is played on.

Contents:

96 tile cards (16 cards of each land type)
25 double sided kingdom tokens
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Pattern Building, Tile Placement

name: Rawen TCG
description:
Rawen's land has been a place of war for hundreds of years. Twelve empires, twelve powerful gods — all longing for the same thing: limitless might.

Everything started with a Cataclysm and the appearance of the New Ones, who ruthlessly squelched the Old Ones — except for those who escaped into other planes of existence, specifically four parts of the world that managed to survive the catastrophe: the Big Continent, also known as Askalar where most of the empires lay; to the North, Iceland, the Isle of the Mages; in the south, Fireland, the home of Demons; and in Oceania, Bale, the Life Tree's territory.

The fight has not ended after the New Ones victory. The balance of forces varies, and it takes only a little to break the fragile balance. Fellowships are made, then breached in moments, but the stakes are much bigger than the power over Rawen. The New Ones fight not just for victory; they are seeking themselves. A secret part of their essence, which they can hardly remember. They were born on another world, which they gave up in exchange for survival. In the depths of their minds, a name pulsates about which neither their new dependents nor The Old Ones might know: Earth. The War of the Gods started in the far past of Rawen, but it affects the future of the whole universe.

In the Rawen Trading Card Game, the Gods of Rawen wield their power through their Warlords. As they expand their territories, the armies of the opposing Gods frequently battle one another. Your goal is to defeat the enemy warlord with the help of fighting units, heroes, and summoned spells. Successful attacks by your army weaken your enemies, and thus weaken their God, too. If the enemy warlord ever has as many wounds as health points, the warlord dies and you win the battle.

In game terms, each player chooses a warlord and a class, then creates a deck of at least 45 cards, with the warlord card, class card and primeval energy cards not counting toward this total. The game is turn-based, and in the main phase of your turn, you may act in any order, placing cards from your hand onto the battlefield, attacking with your units, activating a special power, and so on.

name: Oracle
description:
From the designer:

The Universe is ending. Legends and Myths throughout the galaxy talk about a way to survive. The Oracle promises eternal life to the species that possesses it. The object of the game is to find the Oracle and hold it until the end of the game.

Players journey from planet to planet searching for useful items to aid them in their quest.
They will engage other players with diplomacy cards as well as facing them in player versus player combat.
Different weapon types include energy, physical, mental, fire, sound, and acid.
One on one combat starts at long range. If neither player has died combat progresses to medium and then short range.
Expect to be destroyed. There is no player elimination. Another agent of the species steps in to take the place of the deceased character.

There is a lot of variation in the initial setup. Replayability is built into the design.
After the Oracle is discovered, the universe begins to deteriorate. Planets start disappearing.
Resources become scarce and combatants are pushed together.

Oracle is an exciting fast-paced game that you will find yourself playing multiple times a session.
mechanics: Hand Management, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: RE: Your Brains ‚Äì The Card Game
description:
All a zombie wants is a brain to munch.

Too bad the humans don’t want to give them up. We have all seen it before, the zombie hordes march against the panicked humans. The humans eventually entrench and rally then start blowing away the poor hungry masses of undead. But what if there was a different way? A more civilized way of resolving this tired old conflict? What if we could negotiate instead?

RE: Your Brains is based on the hit song by Jonathan Coulton.

Players take on the roles of the Zombie and the survivor negotiating the brain eating situation. The zombie just wants a hot meal and is trying to convince the survivor to open the door and be that meal, meanwhile the Survivor just wants to go about his life in peace and would love to convince the zombie to go bother some other poor fool, or better yet just stop shambling around all together. To do this players take turns making arguments based on a set of cards in their hands. The only limitation is the mood of the card played, the content is entirely up to the players.

RE: Your Brains is a fast playing two player game that is as much fun to watch as it is to play and you will often get help from the peanut gallery as you try to debate, cajole, and threaten your way to victory.

There are three aspects to playing RE: Your Brains.

1st is the rock, paper, scissors mechanic. There are three types of arguments to be made, Logical, Emotional, and Aggressive, ranging from values of 2-8. Logical arguments get a +2 bonus against Emotional arguments and -2 penalty against Aggressive, Emotional arguments get a +2 bonus against Aggressive and -2 against Logical, and Aggressive arguments get a +2 against Logical and -2 against Emotional. The bonus or penalty applies to the card being played, not the card on the stack. As long as the value is higher with the applied bonus or penalty (or neither if they're the same type of argument), you can play that card in response.

2nd is the roleplaying aspect. Every time you play a card, you must make an argument of the type of argument you played. Hence, if you're the zombie, you might make an 3 value Emotional plea of "We've always been such good friends, and I would hate to have you be ripped to shreds by some other zombies. Let me eat your brain, and I'll turn you into a zombie so we can be friends forever!" and as the survivor you might reply with a 2 value Logical argument which is actually a 4 against the previous 3 emotional and say something like "One would think if you were truly my friend you would defend me from these other zombies, or at the very least stop trying to eat my brain."

3rd is the trick-taking mechanic. To win the game, you must win 5 arguments Each player starts the argument with a hand of 5 cards and uses those cards to make their argument. When they can no longer beat the argument on the table (or if they choose not to), the last person to play a card wins that argument. You may play two cards of the same argument type to overcome an existing argument. If a player completely runs out of cards and has no more to respond to their opponent's argument, they lose.

name: Quink
description:
Quink is played using five pieces each of five different colors on a 7x7 board. At the start of the game the pieces are arranged in cross formations on specific board spaces, with each cross containing one piece of each color and the center of each cross being a different color.

A move consists of a player moving a piece orthogonally any number of empty spaces. There are five special spaces which when landed on let the player make another move with the same piece or a piece of the same color, counting it as part of the same move.

The object is to get the five pieces of each color in a connected group. The game can be played as a solitaire puzzle or by multiple players; the designer suggests playing with two by trading off setting up boards for the opponent (the goal being to solve the opponent's puzzle in fewer moves than they solve yours), or any number by each trying to solve the same puzzle in the fewest moves.

name: Flipside
description:
2 player game played on the spaces of an 8x8 board. Materials: 4 chess pawns, 2 black and 2 white. 64 bi-colored reversi pieces.

piece = a bi-colored reversi piece

Set two like color pawns diagonally adjacent to each other onto two of the four center squares on the board.Set two pieces at each row and column along the outer edge of the board .

Black moves first, then play alternates. On your turn, move a friendly pawn in a straight line orthogonally or diagonally ending the movement on an empty square. Then take a piece from the outer edge of the board, flip it to your color and move this piece in a straight line orthogonally ending the move on an empty space. The piece last moved and the pawn last moved should now be in line of sight of each other.

When both players pass in succession the game ends.
