The player with the most pieces in his color on the board at the end of the game is the winner.

The inspiration for this game comes from Walter Zamkauskas Amazons
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Enclosure, Grid Movement, Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

description:
12/21/12 is a pure chance of the draw game card game targeted at those looking for some crude and low blow jokes. The humor ranges from telling off your boss to pedophilia.

This base game was designed in mind with the most basic mechanic of drawing a card to either gain, lose, or steal points from the other players. You can add mechanics to this game with each expansion which features their own single mechanic. These expansions for the most part can also be played separately from the base game but we recommend getting all your favorite mechanics together and mixing random amounts of cards from each set for a different game each time.

The Mayans we assume predicted the end of the world with their amazing sense of prediction that didn’t see the end of their civilization coming thousands of years before hand. Oh well! It’s that time now and only you can figure out exactly how you will spend your last day on earth and if it will be more epic than any of your friend’s!
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: War in the Welsh Marches
description:
War in the Welsh Marches represents a battle between a Marches Lord and Welsh Raiders on land between two castles in the frontier territory of the borderlands between England and Wales in the 12th century. Movement orthogonal; capture by short leap. Aim to capture the opposing chief or to enter three men into the opposing castle square.
Leather board and wooden gaming pieces.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Pattern Recognition, Square Grid

name: AT-43 Unit Box: Star Troopers
description:
The star troopers are the regular White Stars troops… Naturally anything regular in the armed forced of the U.N.A. would be extraordinary anywhere else. The star troopers training cycle is designed for the mass production of professional soldiers. The star troopers are gathered in large units whose efficiency is due to both the quality and the number of its soldiers.
The star troopers are the ideal complement to steel trooper units. They drown the enemy is a hailstorm of bullets with their assault rifle. And when the MG starts playing, the hailstorm becomes a hurricane.
For further tactical potential, one of the star troopers can be promoted Sergeant.

Contents:
• Box of 8 miniatures.
• 2 cards : Steel TacArm Sgt, Steel TacArm
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Night Shift
description:
Night Shift is a Solitaire board game with Survival Horror themes. It describes the efforts of three different characters (an FBI agent, a security guard, and a mercenary) as they seek to survive a night of Lovecraftian horror as monsters and madness descend upon a storage facility nestled between the sea and a spooky wood.

The game is played out on an 8x8 hex grid and simulates the escape of a character through a simple set of movement and action rules. Enemies actions are controlled by a simple set of A.I., unique to each enemy, while the scenario to be played can be determined randomly and can be modified slightly according to preference or dice roll. The main driving force of the game is a narrative table, aptly called the Horror Table, which produces results that apply mechanical changes to game play as well as describe the nature of the dark events befalling your character. Couple with a search table, Night Shift creates an environment rife with spooky stuff.

This game was originally created for the 2013 Solitaire Print and Play contest.

name: Centerpiece
description:
Centerpiece is a roll-and-move game primarily for 2 players, or 4 players in teams. It's described by the designer as "super-charged Monopoly," but it's most similar to Mario Party without the mini-games. The game board is printed on map paper, which allows it to fit inside the small box. After unfolding the board, the colorful box top becomes the "centerpiece" of the game board. Players take turns rolling two dice off of the box top; at least one die must end up on the game board itself, and neither can roll farther than the board's border, or the roll is invalid. They then move the sum of their roll. Every space has special effect that triggers either when landed on or when leaving the space. The goal of the game is to collect feathers, represented by paper money, in order to buy puzzle pieces. Puzzle pieces can be purchased when the player lands on two of the corner spaces, and passing the Start Together space generates an income of 25 feathers. Feathers can also be gained and lost in various ways.

Aside from rolling off the box top, the main distinguishing feature of the game is that each player's pawn is represented by a pair of stacked poker chips. When landing on the Banana Split garden space, the poker chips are split up, and are subsequently treated as separate pawns. If they ever occupy the same space, other than the Banana Split space, they are recombined. Split pieces give more options when moving, and some spaces reward the player for having their chips either combined or separated.

As in Monopoly, rolling doubles allows the player to move again, and rolling snake eyes sends the other player's chips to the Bird Cage (identical to Monopoly's Jail space).

Description from Kickstarter:

Super-charged Monopoly. Dice fall off box, the game travels in. White and black poker-chips get pulled apart and put together.

To play simply learn to drop the dice off the box, and keep them on the game-board. The very first corner space states, Divide Your Game Parts. What made that work, are five No/Rest circles added to select spaces. They take away the choice, of which game-piece to move. Before I adding those circles, catch-22's would happen. A different space states, Exchange Your Bank of Feathers. It allows a player to come from behind at anytime.

The inside of the box works great as a game-bank. Each time around the board Eagle, Duck and Seagull feathers are rewarded. The goal of CENTERPIECE, becomes a RACE to purchase nine-puzzle-spaces one at a time. Have a bank of two-hundred feathers, have game-parts together. Then land on the Start Sun space, or Bidgecage space to WIN. Players keep score, with black and white pawns, under the box, at the games center. Who's best at finding the best price for a numbered puzzle-space, while staying out of the Birdcage corner space. For example to Rent A Horse, to get to the Half-Price space, or not.

All together there are twenty-eight game spaces. One last example of a game-space states. Roll Doubles While Here, and spend three-turns at the Birdcage corner. Your game pieces, if divided, would be joined again. Rolling doubles while in the Birdcage, lets a player leave early.

Because the game-board paper was designed for new maps, it folds forever. ( It was the most expensive part of the game.)

CENTERPIECE = fast-paced FUN!!! Tested on family and friends. People will ask what's the fun all about? Copy-righted in 1992, a ten-year renewal was also completed. Old-school face-to-face battle with new IMPROVED format.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Damage Report: On Fire
description:
There’s a strange smell in the air, smoke is drifting out of the vent down the corridor…oh no, the ship is on fire! As you reach for a fire extinguisher and a few crystals to fuel it, ZAP! A crazed robot hits you with its stun baton and you fall to the floor. How did things get so out of control on the ship?!

Damage Report: On Fire introduces two brand new tools – the stun baton and the fire extinguisher. Additionally, there is a new fire game mechanic that spreads deadly flames around the ship. Can you survive with these new challenges while still keeping your ship’s systems online?
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Real-time, Science Fiction
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Modular Board, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Phase Order

name: Get to the Quarantine Zone
description: Get to the Quarantine Zone (QZ) is a part card game / part board game RPG set in the mid 1800's in a place called Cherry Creek, Colorado. The mining town it is set in was quite wealthy and bustling with business until one day people started getting sick. After the sickness, many died. After they died, many got back up and started eating the living! It wasn't long before word spread that this was happening all over the country. Quickly, everyone left town as fast as they could heading toward a "Quarantine Zone" they heard of in Boulder, Colorado. You and a small group of other survivors got the last wagon in town and headed to Boulder. It wasn't long before the wagon broke catastrophically and you were all stranded. You set up a basic camp and decided to make missions into town to get supplies and parts for the wagon. Once fixed, you will be ready to Get to the Quarantine Zone.
categories: American West, Card Game, Dice, Zombies
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Role Playing

name: Ironburst
description:
Ironburst is a tactical combat board game using detailed metal miniatures and modular hex-based maps. It plays quick and has simple rules with good tactical scalability. Set-up is fast and so are battles.

The goal is to complete objectives: gathering resources, building, or eliminating specific enemy troops, etc. Players gather resources located on the board to build and repair units and to buy special Event Cards.

The miniature line and the game were developed together, so the miniatures are designed to fit the game mechanisms and vice versa. More specifically, each miniature has multiple moving parts that can be removed (if they are destroyed) and rotated (to aim, to indicate that a weapon has already fired, etc.). Thus, these modular miniatures allow players to do bookkeeping and track game events directly on the battlefield instead of using paper. The moving parts are magnetic and can be swapped in and out to allow players to customize their forces.

To allow the moving parts to take the stress and friction of repeated movement, Ironburst miniatures are cast in a special zinc alloy called ZAMAK, which is not as soft as tin (and much lighter), nor as fragile as resin, while keeping a good amount of detail.

name: DeZpair: 24 horas de deZespero
description:
In DeZpair: 24 horas de deZespero, a band of mercenaries tries to rescue the survivors of a zombie-infested city before the military "cleans up" the place with a nuclear bomb. You have 24 hours to swipe the city clean of people before the bomb explodes!

The game uses a modular board made of tiles to model the city search and zombie attacks, with custom dice used for character skills. Players use the dice to fight the zombies, search for survivors, and loot anything that the previous citizens left behind before joining the undead horde. The tiles show how many zombies are in a location, and the game unfolds through the exploration of these tiles.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Enclosure, Modular Board, Open Drafting

name: Bolt Action: Pegasus Bridge
description:
This awesome set contains everything you need to recreate the daring raid that paved the way for the Allied D-Day invasion.

The Mission

The mission, in the opening minutes of the Normandy landings, was to capture the Bénouville Bridge and the nearby Ranville Bridge in order to prevent German reinforcements from reaching the beaches, where Allied forces were pouring ashore. 180 men, led by Major John Howard, landed close to their targets in gliders. Using the element of surprise, they were tasked with seizing the bridges, and more importantly, hold them against the inevitable German counter attack. Bénouville Bridge was later renamed Pegasus Bridge, in reference to the shoulder emblem worn by the British Airborne forces.

The Battlefield

Using the contents of the battle set, you can really set the scene for this pivotal battle. The centrepiece is a laser-cut model of the bridge itself, accompanied by models of the Cafe Gondre, as well as a pill box, a gun pit and even two telegraph poles!

Next come the forces themselves - for the defenders, 20 German infantry, backed up with a 5cm KwK 39 anti-tank gun and MG42 machine gun team. The attackers are a 10-man British Airborne squad plus a 2-man PIAT team, and an exclusive model of Major John Howard, which is only available in this set. You'll also get decal sheets for both the sides to help you prepare your forces for battle.

Last but not least the box includes a scenario booklet that describes how to set up and fight the battle for Pegasus Bridge. (Remember, this is a supplement for the Bolt Action game, so you'll need a copy of the core rules too!)

Box Contents:

Laser-cut Bridge
Laser-cut Cafe Gondres
Resin Gun Pit
Metal 5cm KwK 39 anti-tank gun and 3 crew
Laser-cut Pillbox
Metal German MG42 MMG team
2 laser-cut telegraph poles (on the Cafe sheets)
20 plastic German Infantry and plastic bases
Major John Howard and plastic base (exclusive new model)
10 man British Airborne squad and plastic bases
2-man PIAT team and plastic bases
Scenario booklet
Decal sheets for the Paras and Heer
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: ASL Comp: Bandenkrieg ‚Äì Hell Behind the Eastern Front
description:
North of BORISOV, RUSSIA, 4 April 1943: Operation Lenz Sud had commenced in hopes of finally reducing or eliminating the growing Partisan force near Borisov. As the German forces began the push the partisans were ready and awaiting for an ambush. The Partisans were not trained soldiers and the tactics of the partisans were simple and the challenges put on them by their leaders were less than would be expected from a military unit. Surprise and ambush were their best tactic. Their spot chosen lay on both sides of the Narotch stream. Having capturing a German field gun earlier and using their long hidden anti tank gun—a leftover from the retreating Russians in 1941—the ambush was prepared. Mines were placed, demolition charges were planted by explosive teams smuggled behind German lines and now the wait began. One Partisan survivor remembered: “We would ambush the Germans on the Narotch stream bank. We knew the Germans planned to come to the aid of the guard from the other side of the stream. Our commander, Sagalchik, was also a guide, as he had lived in Miadel for many years and was familiar with the area. When we arrived everything was quiet. Suddenly shots were heard. We lay down and awaited the Germans. When we received the sign to attack we ran to the houses where the Germans and Lithuanian sharpshooters were. The battle lasted a few hours and the Germans dispersed.” Within an hour the fight was over leaving the battlefield in partisans hands. The Germans suffered 40 dead and over 50 wounded. “Lenz-Sud’ was off to a bloody start.

Bandenkrieg: Hell Behind the Eastern Front is a historical module depicting combat that occurred during an anti-partisan operation, Operation Lenz Nord, near Borisov in Byelorussia in April 1943.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Happy Feet Two: Hold on Erik
description:
From the box: Young Erik (from the film Happy Feet Two) is sitting on top of a wall of ice. On your turn use one of the fish pushers to carefully poke out one of the blocks. Got one? Good!

As the game continues it gets harder to find blocks that are easy to push out. And, on someone's turn (we hope not yours!) Erik will come tumbling down.

Contents:
Wall frame
44 blocks
Erik figure
2 fish pushers
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Invictus
description:
Invictus – Latin, meaning “unconquered”.

2 player abstract game played on the spaces of a 9x9 board.
Each player has 18 dice pieces, one set black the other white.

Setup
Place the 9x9 board between the players.

Next, players turn 3 of their 18 dice pieces so that the top faces show all ones then 3-twos, 3-threes, 3-fours, 3-fives and 3-sixes.

Now Black sets his dice pieces onto any space of the second and third rows of the board that are closest to him, then White does the same.

Object
Player with the highest score at games end, wins.

Play
The fifth row of the board is known as the Divide and divides the board into two territories.

One player plays black the other white.

Black moves first, then play alternates.

On your turn you must take one of two actions:

1.Move a die one space either forward, left, right or diagonally forward, never backwards onto an empty space.
2.Capture a die one space diagonally forward, like a pawn in chess performing a capture.

When any friendly dice reach an opponent’s first row, they are removed from play and used in scoring at endgame.

Captures
A friendly die may only capture an opponent’s die of equal face value or less, the captured die is returned to your opponent if its face value is greater than one. On receiving the captured die from your opponent you must turn that die so that the face value of the die now reads one less, then place this die onto an empty space on your side of the Divide.

Any captured dice that have a face value of (1) are removed from play and kept for scoring at endgame.

The game ends when a player moves all of his remaining dice onto his opponent’s first row.

If any of your opponents dice are past the Divide and in your territory at endgame they will be added to your opponents score.

Score
Add up all of the top face values of your dice that reached you’re opponents first row, any captured dice and any of your dice that were within enemy territory.

Highest score wins!

name: Inferno
description:
This simple roll-and-move game takes a sarcastic look at the career of a firefighter. Players move from the Academy to Retirement. Cards played along the way represent Fire, Rescue, Station and Administration.

The goal is to reach Retirement first.

name: Columna
description:
2 player game, played on the spaces of a 7x7 board.

One player plays black the other white.

2 pawns, black and white.
A supply of black and white stackable pieces.

THE WIN – There are two ways to win, one way is if on your turn you manage to form an unbroken orthogonally adjacent path, connecting your pawn, your stacks and your opponent’s pawn. The second way is if you control the most stacks of 4 pieces high at endgame.

STACK - A stack is one or more pieces of either color.
The color of the stack's top piece determines its owner (e.g., a black top piece makes it a black stack).

Stacks cannot be greater than 4 pieces high.
Stacks of 4 pieces high cannot move.
Stacks cannot split.

MOVEMENT – Pawns start out on base tiles on opposite corners of the board and move along the outer edge of the board. Pawns may move to any point along either side of the board, so long as they do not jump over their opponent's pawn and so long as they do not occupy the same side of the board between base tiles.

Stacks move orthogonally along empty spaces(no jumps).

Stacks move equal to the number of pieces within the stack. (e.g. , a stack of 1 moves one space, a stack of 2 moves two spaces and a stack of 3 moves three spaces.)

Board starts out empty, then pawns are placed on the base tiles.

TURN - Black moves first, turn then alternates.

On each turn, each player must take one of the following actions, which constitutes a valid move:

•Move your pawn and drop a single piece onto any empty point that lies between your pawn and the target point as long as all the points between your pawn and your target point are also empty or
•Move your pawn and drop a single piece on top of a friendly or enemy stack that is less than 4 high, also the stack most be in line of sight of your pawn and any stacks in-between your pawn and the target stack must have less pieces than the target stack, or
•Move your pawn and then move one of your stacks.

The game ends when neither player can make a valid move on their turn.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Enclosure, Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: Hexopolis
description:
Hexopolis is a fast-paced, intense strategy card game that includes tactical elements thanks to a dynamic board and zombies controlled by all players. Expect to be kept on your toes with cutthroat moves and counter-moves.

The game is won and lost by activating ingredients on the table; two different ones to win, two identical ones to lose.

Players start by creating the board from a set of hexagonal tiles around a tile marked as the Altar set in the middle of the table. Then, they draw five cards and play their move in turns.

The different actions from the cards include summoning zombies, moving them to specific tiles to bring ingredient cards from one's hand to the table, or sacrifice zombies on the Altar tile to activate or deactivate ingredients already on the table.
Cards can also be combined into advanced actions that bend the rules (steal cards, cancel actions, etc.).

Rules are in English and French. Cards are bilingual.

Comes as a printed-on-demand box or as a PDF file.
mechanics: Hand Management, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Open Drafting

name: Cavern Crawl
description:
In Cavern Crawl, players take on the role of one of 4 adventurers to explore the caverns, fight monsters and collect loot. It can be played either cooperatively or competitively.

Players start on the same "Start" card, and have slightly different attack, search and defense abilities depending on their character. On their turn, they first draw a map card and connect it to the already placed cards, expanding the caverns and creating more opportunities for battles and loot.

Combat and gaining coins works through dice rolls. Players have to beat certain defence scores of the enemies in their roll, and they gain the associated rewards if they're successful. This can also include treasure cards which provide bonuses and extra abilities.

Players can pool their dice rolls together if they are on the same space, to make it easier to gain rewards or defeat monsters. In this case, the rewards are split.

Players can also attack each other for the chance to steal coins from their opponents.

The goal of the game is to be the first to find 10 coins and make it back to the entrance. Each character has an additional secondary objective which provides an alternative winning condition.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Dice, Exploration, Fighting
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: X-Live
description:
User summary:

A solitaire card game based on the concept of rhythmic video games.

The player has a band of five dancers from a selection of 11, numbered 1–5. The dancers are put in a line, where each dancer is either in the front row or back row. From a shuffled deck of notes also numbered 1–5, five cards are lined up. Each turn, the cards of the lest represented colour will "fall down" (are slid down a bit) and must be "caught" by the team of dancers. However, in order to achieve a "perfect rhythm", a note must be caught by a dancer with the same number, if caught by a dancer with a number at most 1 more or less than the note is "good" if the note and the dancer are of the same colour; anything else is a "fail".
Before each catch, the player can only move one dancer one step, either from back row to front row, or sideways, in which case they swap places with whoever was beside them. However, moving sideways to a spot where no dancer is is not counted as a move, and will also cause the dancer who now ends up in the same column as the moved one, to move in the opposite direction, a so-called "cross move".

Being in the back row gives the dancer one extra turn to catch the note. Also, apart from the current row of falling notes, the player will have another row of notes above it, enabling the player to plan his moves one turn ahead.

The final score is decided by the number of perfects and good rhythm catches. Also, before each game, the player chooses which song to dance to; each song having a special effect on the game. Each dancer also has a special power to activate once per game.

name: Crash_Em_Thrash_Em_Warbots
description:
/Intro_Start

Welcome to the Crash 'Em Arena. It is in this simulation that players compete in a mechanized brawl by controlling their assigned Crash 'Em Bot. This is done by inputting /Programs (/Program cards) into their Bot to initiate commands for movement, attacking an opponent, or even hacking their systems in order to sabotage their plans. Once enough points are awarded, usually through beating on opponents, the combatant who earns those points first is declared the victor!

Let the games begin.

/End_Intro
mechanics: Action Queue, Grid Movement, Open Drafting

name: Invasion Z
description:
Invasion Z is a Zombie Survival Game. The story is about an outbreak of Zombie-like creatures after a Meteor disintegrates in the atmosphere raining a strange color into Buenos Aires City. This rain causes the population to get sick and then die, only to become the dreaded ghouls that crave for the flesh.

Gameplay has 5 basic steps:

1) MAINTENCANCE: Operatives untap all the used items and Profile card, and Mission penalties are applied to the main Counters.

2) OPERATIVES STEP: Heroes move around the board, hunting zombies, rescueing people, finding useful items and trying to avoid the inevitable fate that awaits them.

3) ZOMBIES MOVE: All zombies move closer to the base in the center of the board.

4) EVENTS STEP: Depending on the levels of the Event Counter one or two events might happen. A special die is rolled and the event takes effect.

5) ZOMBIE STEP: Depending on the levels of the Zombie Counter one or two extra zombies will be added to the Zombie Roll. Usually 1 die per rescuer is roll (between 3 and 4 die total) plus any extra die added by the Zombie Counter placing zombies in the suburbs of the map. A 6 rolled is a miss and do not adds any zombie.

The objective of the game is to rescue the 8 survivors that stand hidden on the locations of the outer ring of the board and then return to the center tile to be retrieved by the rescue team.

The Heroes lose if at any time there are 3 zombies on the central location tile.

The Items deck works as a counter that will increase the difficulty as the game progresses with some "bad luck" cards that can be a devastating force against the heroes.

There are several ways of losing the game and only one way to win so usually players will feel very rewarded when they win as it´s usually on the edge of oblivion.
categories: Fighting, Horror, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Zombies
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Browns Island
description:
Print and Play this game***




Motukoreaite is a rare and expensive commodity. You are scientists and have been sent to an island to recover this precious mineral. Unfortunately, your hot air balloon crashes, with parts and equipment spread over the island. With your balloon badly damaged and your team separated, you must work together to survive and get off the island. Little do you know the island is not unoccupied. A roving creature senses your presence and hears your movements. Sometimes it will take what you are searching for; sometimes it will affect your well-being.

Finding lost equipment will help you explore the island more easily. Each player can carry only a limited number of items, though, so you may be forced to leave something valuable behind so that you can carry balloon parts. To win the game, you must keep track of your team's health and get to the balloon crash site with the missing parts before the creature does.

Browns Island consists of a modular board. Players start with a set of four cards, which are played to gain lost equipment as they move around the board. Some equipment gives them added advantages to collect parts for their crashed balloon. Players also try to avoid a roving creature. If the creature discovers a part from your balloon, players lose happiness tokens and must try to take the items back by using their gained skills (via action cards) and found equipment.

2 - 4 players with a SINGLE-PLAYER variant.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Super Gol
description:
Juego de cartas de fútbol táctico.
Cada jugador forma su equipo, y después juegan el partido.
Cada jugador tiene unas habilidades, y para hacer jugadas hay que lanzar dados.


Super Gol (or Supergol) simulates a football (soccer) game. It was sold in an initial set that included a manual, a play mat, a balloon, a pair of dice and a few player cards to mount a couple of teams. Additional players were also sold.

Each player forms a team with 11 players and 5 on the bench, which can not exceed 100 points (each player had a cost).

To play, each player throws or one or two d6, to which they add the ability value.

name: Swift Swords Underworld
description:
Explore the Dungeon, defeat the Vault.

Multi-player competitive/co-operative card game for 2-8 players, where players gather clues to allow them to enter The Vault. Along the way they can attack monsters or other players, gain loot and gold and grow stronger. Once the Vault Clues have been discovered the Vault Monster must be overcome to win the game. Players can go it alone, or bring in allies to achieve victory. Over 500 cards makes every game a new experience.

PNP version available from Drivethru. Hardcopy at Game Crafters.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Exploration, Fantasy, Print & Play
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Team-Based Game

name: The Trilateral Conspiracy
description:
The Trilateral Conspiracy is a mid-level traitor mechanic game that typically takes about 90 minutes to play. One player (by random draw) is assigned as the Protagonist and is the leader of a group of Heroes trying to expose the Conspiracy. Another player will secretly start the game as an Agent, posing as a Hero. Agents win when the Heroes lose. All other players begin with a Resolve score between 1 and 9. They start out on the Hero's side, but if and when one of the nine "Conspiracy Expands" cards is revealed in the game, they will switch to an undercover Agent if their Resolve is equal to or lower than the number of Conspiracy Expands cards revealed thus far. Consequently some players who start as Heroes may choose to play as if they were already Agents right away, others will be Heroes to the end, and some may hedge their bets and try to play both sides.

There are eight locations on the board that serve as potential centers of the Conspiracy. The main goal of the Heroes is to identify which location it is, and then successfully infiltrate it enough to get the information they need to expose the Conspiracy. The way to figure out which is the correct one is to infiltrate three other locations known as the Halls of Power. If successful, each one will eliminate half of the possible locations and all three together will pinpoint it. The twelfth location makes all of the other infiltrations easier.

On their turn, players will typically do three things. They will move to a location, play a card on that location if they wish, and then they can either use that location's power (to do things like draw or trade cards) or they can try to infiltrate it. The purpose for playing cards is to make a location easier (or harder) to infiltrate. The cards range from -5 to +5 and each location starts with one random card on it. If a player chooses to try and infiltrate a location, they shuffle the cards on top and then reveal all of them. If the sum of the cards is equal to or greater than a certain changing difficulty number, they succeed. Otherwise they fail and may face a penalty.

Successfully infiltrating one of the Halls of Power lets the person doing the infiltration discover one of the leaders of the Conspiracy which in turn narrows down the possible locations of the Conspiracy. However only the infiltrating player gets to see the card and they may or may not tell the truth about what they saw. Once the Heroes have an idea of which location is the center of the Conspiracy, they will try to infiltrate it. If successful, they may take a card from their hand and place it underneath that location.

The game typically ends when the Protagonist feels the Heroes have played enough cards under the proper location and calls an end to the game. At that time the cards under the Halls of Power are revealed and the true center of the Conspiracy is determined. Then the cards under there (if any) are added up and if the total does indeed meet or beat a certain difficulty (called the Exposure Level), the Heroes win. Otherwise the Agents win. The Agents also win if the deck runs out of cards or if the Protagonist is killed in a failed infiltration. The Heroes can alternately win if the Exposure Level ever drops to 0.

name: Viking Horde: Papercraft
description:
Viking Horde: Papercraft is a paper-craft fantasy Viking warship game for two or more players pitting opposing fleets against each other for naval supremacy.

The goal of the game is to manoeuvre your fleet to strategically engage and sink enemy player ships in order to claim mastery over the Nordic seas.

Played either on the floor or sheltered areas outside, Viking Horde: Papercraft features a one-ship-at-a-time mechanic making for a fast and engaging player turn rotation, even with huge ship fleets. The game employs on-hand measuring devices, namely player's feet, to gauge movement and attack distances, and makes use of a custom paper-craft dice set to resolve ship vs ship combat and other aspects of the game.

Core game mechanics include:
- One ship activation per player turn, allows for an engaging game for all players right to the very end.
- Directional wind mechanic to tactically enhance ship movement.
- Ship crew members, with class based abilities and roles.
- Ranged and Melee based combat system though use of D6 outcomes.
- Removable shields attached to the sides of each ship to track damage.
- Modularised ruleset (expansion packs and optional rules can be swapped in/out at the groups discretion).
- Floating loot provides random power-ups, events and penalties.
- Ship movement through on-hand measuring devices for simplicity.
- The paper-craft kits for the game come pre-cut and assembly is glue free.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Variable Player Powers

name: Armies of the Dead
description:
Each player starts with four dice of each of six types (d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, and d20), and the first to lose all twenty-four dice loses the game. Each battle is different according to the terrain dice thrown, which determine how many and which dice may battle, if any are modified/doubled, and how many actions each player may take per turn. Each type of die has basic abilities (resurrection/banishment, mimicry, split attacks, join-forces, re-roll opponent die/dice, re-roll own die/dice), and all but the d4 have special abilities activated by rolling pairs (or more) of the same number.

The player with initiative (usually lower total roll) takes one, two, or three actions (based on the throw of the terrain dice) before the opponent has a chance to respond. Actions include one die attacking another or activating abilities, or activating abilities and then attacking an opponent's die (most common).

There is a balance between thinking through the possibilities and over-thinking what your opponent may do, particularly in the selection of which dice to roll at the beginning of each battle. Each battle will consist of different combinations of dice, resulting in different abilities interacting, keeping the game fresh and interesting throughout.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Bulwark: The Steppe Bandits
description:
From publisher description:

Heroic Co-operative Deck-Building!

When a gang of bandits gets too big for its britches, it dreams of conquest, of over-running an established kingdom and living an easier life. A pipe-dream, naturally, but such gangs can wreak havoc in their attempt.

More Options

The Steppe Bandits is a Foe deck that interacts significantly with Heroism cards, and can sneak up on you with ambushes.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Variable Player Powers

name: Shine
description:
Theme - Shine is a biblically based deck building game. In Shine, you are a person who has recently become a Christian. Though saved and forgiven, you still struggle with sin. Your goal is to remove sin from your life and grow in spiritual maturity. To do this, you will spend time in God’s word, prayer, and use your spiritual gifts to minister to the lost and the hurting. It is not as easy as it seems. Satan prowls like a roaring lion. You will face various temptations, but through it all, God will never leave you or forsake you.

Game objective - The object of this game is to build a deck, called a Life Deck. This deck represents a player’s spiritual maturity. Each player starts off with spiritual fruit, and a lot of sin. As the game progresses, players try to remove sin from their life decks and gain various cards, including more spiritual fruit. Character cards that represent people in need and sets of fruit cards are worth victory points. Sin cards are worth negative victory points. The player, with the most victory points at the end of the game wins.

Game play - As a player you have the choice to pray or to shine.

If you choose to pray, you start off by using one of your spiritual gifts. Spiritual gifts allow a player to gain a specific spiritual fruit card. There are 9 different kinds of fruit cards and they are the resource used in Shine to gain other cards.
- You may use the abilities on scripture cards that take effect during prayer.
- You may remove a card from your deck, usually sin.
- You may also place any number of cards from your hand into your discard pile.
- To conclude your turn you draw cards until you have 7 cards in your hand.

If you choose to shine, you start by using one of your spiritual gifts.
- You may play and use the abilities on scripture cards and character cards that you gained during previous rounds.
- You may trade a fruit card with any card in the fellowship pool. The fellowship pool allows players to trade fruit cards.
- You may trade in 2 fruit cards to gain a new fruit card. When you trade in a card it is removed from your deck.
- You may play fruit cards to gain new scripture and character cards.
- To conclude your turn draw cards until you have 7 cards in your hand.

When a player draws the last card from their life deck, the current round ends.
- Each player shuffles their discarded life cards and places them under their life decks.
- Then each player draws the top card of their temptation deck and does what it says. Temptation cards force the player to draw more sin cards and have stronger effects if a player has sin that they have not dealt with.

The game ends when all of the temptation cards have been drawn. Character cards and full sets of 9 fruit cards are worth positive victory points and sin cards are worth negative victory points. The player with the most victory points is considered to be the most spiritually mature and is declared the winner.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Memory, Open Drafting, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Gladiators
description:
Gladiators is an innovative deck-building game of bloody combat and thrilling gambling. Players use customized decks to play out fast, exciting battles while others bet on the outcome. Winning bets earns you the cash you need to improve your deck.

Players represent gladiators in a Roman arena. Each round they have a chance to buy better weapons, techniques, and armor to help them defeat their foes — with each purchase making a better (and more expensive) version of that card available. Then, they'll challenge one of their opponents to a one-on-one throwdown.

Fights are fast, exciting, and surprisingly tactical. First, players reveal three cards from their deck. Based on this information, all other players bet on the outcome. Players then pick those cards up, draw two more cards, and secretly divide them all into two hands: one hand to be used for its fighting power, the other for the special abilities on the cards. They'll then play out a quick best-of-three combat, simultaneously revealing cards, comparing their powers, and, when necessary, deploying hidden tricks.

When the dust settles, the winning fighter collects a victory chip, and the spectators who bet on him win coins that they can use to improve their decks. Players win the game by besting all of their opponents in combat.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: A Simplified Wargame
description:
From the beginning of the rules:
"THIS is an attempt to devise a game based on the principles of war—a game, mind you, not a study. There must not be a single umpire about. The rules must cover all questions on what may or may not be done, and decide losses; and yet they must not be too long or too complicated. And the paraphernalia used in the game must be simple."

A Simplified Wargame is an operational level wargame with specific historic theme. Published in Field Artillery Journal (Sept.-Oct. 1922), the game is played on a point-to-point map, drawn up at random by the players, representing a road network. Units secretly allocate military units to a number of forces represented by pins on the map. The contents of each force is hidden from the opponent. Turns are plotted and carried out simultaneously with any battles resolved using bidding mechanics. The goal is to capture the enemy capital.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Polder
description:
Polder is a game inspired by this same Dutch word, which describes the terrain gained from the sea since XII century. To do so, they pumped the water out with windmills.

The goal of each player is to be the first one to form a continuous canal that connects the windmill with the polder or center of the board.

Pieces shall be grouped by size out of the board. Next, each player chooses a windmill from the board and takes either one of these actions: place a piece on its ring, turn around a whole ring -just a quarter-, change a piece of the board for a new one.

In case of a tie, the player with more small windmills in the canal to the center wins.
mechanics: Modular Board, Network and Route Building

name: Fire and Discipline: 1:10 Scale Rules 1740-1850
description:
Miniature rules designed to simulate tactical warfare during the period 1740 - 1850. While the rules can be used for European battles, the focus is on non-European conflicts such as those which occurred in India and the America

SCALES:
One casting equals ten men but up to 13 men in some organizations
One turn equals two minutes
One inch equals ten yards with 15mm and 20mm+ castings.
One centimeter equals 5 yards with 15mm castings and 20mm+ castings.
A stand represents an infantry company, firing platoon; a cavalry troop or gun section.

name: The New Electronic Perfect Match Game
description:
FROM THE BOX:

Haven't you always wondered who your perfect match is? The New Perfect Match Game is the fun way to find out. The game is played by couples who are asked a series of questions with four alternative answers supplied. These questions cover topics ranging from sex to politics and the arts. Each partner decides on their favourite response and uses the electronic Perfect Match device to check their compatibility and advance along the board. the first couple to reach the Perfect Match Heart Light are the winners. Who will be your Perfect Match?

Contents:

2 Electronic Perfect Match Devices.
288 Question Cards.
1 Die.
4 Position Markers.
Perfect Match Game Board.

The players are divided into couples. Each couple takes a position marker and places it in the start square. Remove the perfect match cards from their perforations and place them in their marked positions on the game board.

The Perfect Match Cards:
These cards are divided into two categories: pink 'Girls' cards and blue 'Guys' cards. As the game proceeds, question cards are taken from the 'Girls' pile if the playing couple lands on a pink square or From the 'Guys' pile if they land on a blue square. Each card contains one questions with four alternative
answers marked A,B,C or D.

Choosing the right answer:
If the couple lands on a blue square, one of the other players picks up a 'Guys' card and directs one question on it to the male partner. He must choose the alternative which he feels is most appropriate to him. His partner must try to anticipate his feelings or attitudes on that question and choose the same alternative. Couples should be open and honest in their choice of answer. Similarly, if the couple lands on a pink square, a 'Girls' card would be taken and its question directed towards the female partner. She will choose and answer and her partner should try to anticipate this response.

Questions marked 'BOTH' are designed to test compatibility, with each partner choosing their own favourite answer in response to the question asked.

Using the Electronic Perfect Match device:
These devices are in the shape of four hearts joined together. Each heart is labeled A,B,C or D, representing the four alternatives on the Perfect Match question cards. When a question is asked and each partner has silently decided on which alternative to choose, they each hold up their device with the chosen representative letter uppermost. They must not allow each other to see their choices. The two devices are then pressed together. If the electronic tone sounds, a perfect match has been achieved for that question.

Dare Cards:
Scattered throughout both packs of cards are Dare Cards. If one these cards appears, the couple must perform whatever is required of them according to the instructions on the card. Their performance is adequate (as indicated by a show of hands) then the couple may roll the die again and continue their turn. Be warned - if you are too easy on others then there is no challenge to perform well. If you are too tough, then your opponent will be equally tough on you. So be fair!

Playing the game: Each couple rolls the die once and those with the highest score start, moving their marker the corresponding number of squares. One of the other players then reads the first question to the starting couple. If the couple achieves a Perfect Match, they roll the die again and advance the corresponding number of squares along the board. Remember, a couple can only roll the die and advance after they have successfully answered a Perfect Match question or performed a Dare task. The couple continues in this way until they are unsuccessful in either a Perfect Match question or a Dare performance, in which case the control of the game is handed over to the next couple (moving clockwise).

Winning the Game:
The first couple to reach the Perfect Match Heart Light and then successfully achieve a Perfect Match from their Choice of either a Girls or Guys question will be declared the winner.


Special Note


Should the electronic tone stop working use a nail file or a similar tool to lever apart the two case sections of the blue device. Carefully removed the battery, replacing it with one of identical type. Be sure to position it positive side up. When pressing the case sections back together, locate the letter "A" on the plastic cover over the battery position.

Based on the formerly popular 1980s Network Ten (and much later Seven Network in 2002) Australian TV dating game show of the same name.

name: Fragile Agile
description:
Two to four player deck builder about developing and testing software.

With help from your pool of talented developers you seek to develop stories, forging them into the epic you aspire to construct. However, even the best developers make mistakes, and therefor bugs do occur.

Building up your software development factory helps you keep your processes under control. Or you can just hope to get away with your low quality product and heap all the misery on to your unsuspecting customer.

Every player starts with a draw deck containing money, developer and epic cards, from which you draw a hand. During your turn, you can use cards to recruit new developers, special programming or testing tools, fix bugs, outsource or build towards completing your epics.

When you complete an epic, you can hand it over to another player. The epic is tested for bugs. Bugs discovered during the test will cause damage to your epic or the other player's deck.

Your final score is determined by the value of the epics you have successfully handed over, the bugs in your deck and being the first player to finish three epics.

name: Up and Down
description:
Up and Down is played with one or two Mystique Decks.

Setup:
Shuffle the cards and divide them into equal high face down piles for each player.

Each player takes the top 4 cards of his pile and places them face up in front of him.

Game rules:
The player with the highest card (card number) starts by playing this card. If there is a tie (when playing with two decks) the player with the golden card start.

After playing a card, players always refill their hand by placing the top card of their pile face up next to their other face up cards.

Starting with the second card, only cards fitting the following criteria can be played:

The card shares the colour or the suit of the last card played
The card number (1-5) is higher/lower than or equal to the number of the last card played (at the beginning of the game it must be higher or equal)

If a player does not have a fitting card, he must pass. But if he can play a card, he must.

If all players successively have passed, the direction (higher/lower) is changed.

In the rare case that all players still have to pass again, the player with the highest card begins as if a new game would start.

End of the game:
As soon as a player would be allowed to refill his hand, but has no more card in his draw pile, he wins the game.

name: Bureaucrazy
description:
Welcome to Bureaucrazy. In this country, its unfortunate inhabitants need to spend days picking up and stamping forms for any activity they want to do in their lives. The players play the role of agents who try to help their clients to complete a series of simple tasks like buying a house, drive a car or work. But do not think it will be easy, because usually Burocrazy does not help its citizens: the offices only operate during certain hours, there are endless queues, and forms and signatures expire quickly, forcing you to restart the process the next day! Good luck and lots of patience will be needed to not go crazy in the process!

Bureaucrazy is a worker placement game, with an approximate duration of 45 minutes. Holds 2 to 5 players. A match lasts 5 turns, in which players try to get the highest possible amount of money in order to be the winner at the end of the game.

name: Lynx
description:
Word game played on an empty newspaper crossword grid. Players take turns to add words to the grid, scoring the length of their word multiplied by the number of other words it crosses.

Listed in Parlett's The Penguin Book of Card Games as an original game.

name: En Prise Chess Cards
description:
En Prise is a card game of chance and strategy that plays just like chess - for two to four players. No separate board or pieces are required as the cards themselves represent squares of a growing board that takes shape as the game progresses. A deck consists of 64 cards. Each player uses 16 cards, matching the pieces and pawns of a standard chess set. They can choose one of four colours (white, black, red and blue).

Cards are dealt, face-up, into shuffled 'Battleplans' from which cards are played, in the shuffled order, into a central playing area. Each card represents a square of a chess board. A square can be occupied (card face-up) or unoccupied (face-down). On each turn, a card is either placed as a piece/pawn or empty square; or moved according to traditional chess movement rules – but they can only move within the board squares already created. When a card is placed (a new square), it must be connected to an existing square of the board. When a card moves, it is swapped with the destination card so the growing board is preserved.

Kings can be placed on any turn where there are at least six empty squares on the board. If a player chooses to do so, all opponents must use their next turn to place their King. The aim of En Prise, like chess, is to checkmate opposing Kings. When a player is checkmated, their board cards are turned over to become empty squares on their next turn. The winner is the last remaining player.

Variations described in the rules include En Prise Casino, En Prise Alliance, En Prise Memory and En Prise Blind.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Grid Movement, Memory, Modular Board, Player Elimination, Tile Placement
publishers: The En Prise Card Company Ltd

name: AT-43 Unit Box: Med Tec
description:
A unit box with MedTec miniatures.

Rules for the MedTecs are in Operation Frostbite but Rackham released a PDF for them as well.

The MedTec building in this box allows a player to bring back into play one dead figure from any unit in contact with the MedTec upon activation. The medic and nurses in this box act as regular medic figures.

Box contents:
-2 nurse miniatures
-1 doctor miniature
-1 shelter miniature
-3 great walls miniatures
-1 reference card.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Maidania
description:
2-players strategy game MAIDANIA: “UA for EU vs. Dictator”

This “revolutionary-intellectual“ game is dedicated to the so called „Euromaidan“, pro-European Union protests in Ukraine these days.
The patriots struggle in Maidans in Kyiv and in other Ukrainian cities against the riot police "Berkut"– for justice and democracy.
One player plays for all "berkuts" and other plays for all protesters.

You can play for the leaders of Ukrainian opposition (Yulia Tymoshenko, Vitaliy Klitschko and others) and also for “casual” Ukrainians: a doctor, a student, a driver, –∞ worker etc.

The protesters try to reach crossword-like walls of the game board in order to place there their tents with the democratic and patriotic slogans: FREEDOM, DEMOCRACY etc.The “berkuts” try to make the protesters “silent” and “paralyzed” by jumping over them. Both "berkuts" and the protesters move in all directions but jump only vertically and horizontally.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Fighting, Political, Print & Play, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Role Playing, Square Grid, Variable Player Powers

name: The Peter Pan Game
description:
In the darkness of Neverland, moored in the Mermaids Lagoon lies that cannibal of the seas the Jolly Roger. Captive aboard are Wendy, Michael & John. Peter Pan has set out to help their escape, his battle with Captain Hook, and his villainous crew about to begin. Neverland is only for the brave. Those who dare to tread its pathways and cross its rivers should beware, evil deeds are planned tonight.

The game is based on the original Hodder and Stoughton publication of Peter Pan and Wendy from 1921 which uses the illustrations of Mabel Lucie Attwell. The game takes extracts from the text and uses those original illustrations to capture the atmosphere and adventure of the book in an exciting game. The pieces and the packaging have been tastefully designed to make the game a collectors piece for children and parents to treasure today and throughout their lives.

The player playing Peter Pan must set out to clear the mushroom clearings of pirates so the children can make good their escape. The player playing Captain Hook sets out from the Jolly Roger in an attempt to capture Peter Pan. His 6 pirates guard the mushroom clearings, making difficult for the children to escape. Players playing Wendy, Michael and John must find a way to the underground home.

The game boils down to a roll and move with a card mechanic to throw some curves into the game. When Peter Pan and Captain Hook clash it becomes a dice duel between the two.

The game includes a game board, hand crafted Peter Pan and Captain Hook pawns, 6 wooden pirates, 3 wooden children counters, 50 adventure cards, 30 pirate river cards and three wooden dice.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Divinity
description:
Divinity is a cooperative turn-based card game for 2 to 4 people, in which each player assumes the role of a deity trying to forge the universe as it is eaten away by powerful disasters of mysterious origin. As players work together, the universe either succumbs to the calamities or is saved by the grace of the gods!

The goal of the players in Divinity is to accumulate points by creating various objects in their galaxies. The divine cards are used by players to achieve their goal, while calamity cards are force-played through to game, undermining the players' efforts. Depth is created through the interaction of all these cards, creating new situations every game and requiring players to consider card abilities carefully in order to master the game.

When the game ends, players add all their points together to judge the fate of all they've built. Players must play wisely, as both divine and calamity cards can cause the game to end. Control of both points and when the game ends is critical to success.

Divinity is inspired by cooperative games heavy in strategy and planning, as well as light and chaotic party games. It's made to be quick to set up, easy to learn, but full of endless wonder. Why not try being a god today?
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: –ú–ê–ù–ï–í–ê–†
description:
A game for two players, similar to Chess, but the board is bigger, and there are also a lot more pieces.

Components:
One 13 X 12 squares board(totally 156 squares)
74 pieces in two colours(37 pieces each side)

Pieces are divided in three groups:
- Infantry
- Cavalry and
- Archers

Every player has the following pieces:

- INFANTRY UNITS -
1 Leader
9 Heavy Infantry
11 Light Infantry

- CAVALRY UNITS -
4 Heavy Cavalry
4 Light Cavalry


- ARCHERS -
4 Infantry Archers
4 Horse Archers

The object of game is to capture the enemy Leader. If the Leaders are the only pieces left on board it's a stalemate and the game is ended a draw. If one player cannot move any piece, or cannot move Leader to a safe square, that player loses the game.
Players play one after the other like in chess(black goes first), but they can play not just one, but also two (and in special condition three) moves per turn.

Each player on his turn can move any two pieces he has (but cannot move the same piece twice like a prolonged move). If he plays with a two units of a different type (e.g. one Infantry and one Archer), he can move even the third piece but that piece must belong to remaining unit (e.g. If a player moved one Infantry and one Cavalry, he can also move one Archer).

Player cannot move and take pieces on the same turn. When taking pieces player can do it with only one unit (and so he loses maneuver advantage of playing with more pieces). The only way to take two pieces on the same turn is that you take one piece with either Infantry or Cavalry, and if there was any piece within range of your Archers, you can take that piece as well.

Leader and Heavy Infantry are Invulnerable to Archers, but they cannot move on the square which is targeted by Archer.

name: 3rd Millennium Chess
description:
"3rd Millennium Chess does for chess what Christopher Columbus did for the world." - Shannon Rene Gardner, designer

3rd Millennium Chess, AKA 3MChess, is a chess variant played on a wrap-around cylindrical 8 x 14 board. There are two other differences from conventional chess:

1. Each player begins with a row of eight pawns on each side of the home rank. Pawns move away from the home rank.

2. Each player also begins with four knights. A knight can share a square with an allied knight, and a knight can carry an allied knight.

name: Damier g√©ographique: les alli√©s
description:
Damier géographique is French game from the WWI-era.

This game is a variation on the classical game of checkers, with a World War I theme.

2 teams of 2 players compete on a map of Europe that is overlaid with a checkerboard pattern. Each team has an equal number of pawns that represent armies. One team represents Germany and the Austrian Empire. The other team represents France, the UK, Russia and their allies.

The board is divided in a western and an eastern battle zone. At the beginning of the game, one player of each team plays in each zone. In the western zone, each player has 36 pieces. In the eastern zone each player has 24 pieces. The battles are played simultaneously, but separately (pawns cannot move from one battle zone to the other). When there is a victor in one zone, his remaining pieces go to his ally in the other zone.

The movement rules are those of the game of checkers. Each players moves in turn. Armies move one space diagonally and capture by jumping over an enemy pawn. Each country has one or two squares that are marked as fortresses. Armies promote to 'generals' when they can occupy an enemey fortress. A general moves as a king in checkers.

A battle in a zone is won by capturing all enemy pieces in that zone. The team that wins in both zones, or wins in one and draws in the other is the winner of the game.

name: Beyond Leipzig: Conflict of Nations
description: Beyond Leipzig takes John Prados' popular game design from Beyond Waterloo and applies the system to the greatest of all the Napoleonic campaigns in 1813. Beyond Leipzig is a two-or multi player strategic level simulation of the Napoleonic Campaign of 1813. Players take the sides of France or its opponents, a coalition of Allies. Where most games on this period focus in on the famous Battle of Leipzig, Beyond Leipzig takes in the full scope of the military, economic, and diplomatic possibilities inherent in the 1813 situation. The Allies must re-defeat Napoleon, still reeling from his disastrous failed invasion of Russia. The French must avoid that outcome and secure their empire in central Europe.

name: Arcane Legions: Servants of Thebes
description:
Cleopatra's fell necromancy and the Dvergar's ingenious golem technology have combined once more to produce a monstrosity the likes of which have never before been seen by man. Exhuming the long-dead bodies of the great Sphinxes of the desert, the Queen of the Egyptian Imperium has created massive hulks of undead flesh and steel whose sole purpose is to kill the living!

In Arcane Legions, players each field "bases" of variable sizes (Sortie/small and Formation/large) with individual figures inserted into starting positions on the base. The goal is to control victory point areas and inflict losses on the opponent. Movement and battle resolution are conducted through a unique formation management mechanic that allows players to move figures around on the unit bases to increase either movement/melee/ranged combat at the cost of losing capabilities in the other areas.

Contents:

2 painted miniatures:
1x Tomb Guardian of Anubis
1x Tomb Guardian of Ostris
2x formation bases
4x formation unit cards
categories: Ancient, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game

name: Good Luck
description:
Find pirate’s treasure! We have gathered in a desert island of wrecked pirate ship to find treasure. To take more gold and treasure each other in frantic, pirates still remain on the island. Who could take the treasure most avoiding pirates? Good Luck~!

[Goal]
To get the most treasure tokens.

[Game Play]
The game contains 48 Gold cards, 4 Pirate cards and 1 Treasure Box card. In your turn, draw a card from top of the deck and give it to any player(including you). Rules to give a card are as follow.
1. You can give a card up to 7 times. (In case of 6~7 players, up to 5 times.)
2. Do not look a card when draw. Choose a player and then open a card in front of him/her. You can also choose yourself and open in front of you.
3. Give cards to at least 3 people including you before your turn ends. You can give to more than 3 people, but you should be included.
If a special card(Pirate or Treasure Box) appears during you are giving cards, your turn ends immediately. Pirate takes your treasure token and Treasure Box gives you the tokens taken.

[Game Ends]
The round ends when 4 pieces apper among the 5 special cards, and the player who has the most Golds gets treasure tokens. The game ends after 3 rounds.
Compare each other's treasure tokens, and decide the winner.

name: U.S. President: Viribus Unitis
description:
Viribus Unitis is a competition version of U.S. President game. It differs mainly in its map. Unlike U.S. President with its modified map of the USA, Viribus Unitis is played on modified language/ethnical map of Austria-Hungary around the year 1910.

(Viribus Unitis means "With united forces" in Latin and is known as personal motto of Austrian Emperor Franz Joseph I.)
Like in the U.S. President game, Viribus Unitis is Easy-Fast-Fun game with pyramids about the last 12 weeks of fictional election campaign.

As far as the game mechanism is the same, tactics differ a bit, because in Viribus Unitis all players put their pyramids simultaneously in all twelve rounds.

For competitions are available free pdf files with tables to write down all moves and follow the track easily.

The map for Viribus Unitis consists of ten main ethnic (language) groups of Austria-Hungary in 1910 and The City of Vienna as the eleventh district.
There is no tricky district in Viribus Unitis (unlike Florida state in U.S. President game) and the game is meant for 3-6 players and 4 sets of pyramids.

Player need to secure at least 51 votes to win the game. In case of a tie, the one who secures votes in Vienna, wins the game.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Educational, Expansion for Base-game

name: Conflict WW2
description:
This is a set of rules intended to link existing board into one massive, yet playable war. Players can use
their own WW2 board games, using their own email to contact each other.

Players match up with those who own the same board games.

Any board game, including solitaire games can be used.

This is a FREE set of rules for download. Send me a PM for the links to the rules file booklets. (PDF)

Tactical, Operational, and Strategic games are fine.

Players can use Vassal or PBEM methods to play their games.

Note this game is NOT played on BGG forums or using BGG email addresses.

Mike Raymond Send me a PM for the links to the rules file booklets. (PDF)
Author

name: Advanced Tobruk System Basic Game II: Stalin's Fury
description:
The original ATS BG II is back in Stalingrad and uses a new 12" × 18" board (card, not paper) and standard ATS sized hexes. An updated BG II rulebook and play aids provide everything you need to play—just bring your own counters from the ATS collection—and begins you on the path to system experience at a low cost.

An Expansion for ATS. First released edition does NOT include counters needed for play. Counters needed from a previous Complete Game with Russian/German units, or available direct from Critical Hit.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Struggle for Wake Island
description:
"Struggle for Wake Island" is a point to point movement wargame for 2 players. The Japanese player has ten turns in two invasions for a total of twenty turns to capture the Island.

The Marine player must simply hold out and cause as many casualties on the Japanese as possible. By the use of trackers to record fleet strength and air craft factors helps in keeping the counter mix low for the ground forces.

Many optional variants including construction workers and if the VMF fighter squadron is airborne or not on the first day of the action. The goal is for a fun fast game in total time of less than two hours to play and only a few pages of rules to deal with.

name: Newton's Noggin
description:
Isaac Newton did much more than sit under apple trees and use his head to catch falling apples. Many regard him as one of the most influential scientists in history. His seminal work, the Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica, which is Latin for "Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy", laid the foundation for classical mechanics.

In Newton's Noggin, 2-4 players manipulate ideas inside Newton's head to formulate the concepts necessary to write the Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica. Problems will need to be solved or worked around. Other players' ideas will impede your progress. The player that contributes the most ideas to Newton's masterwork wins the game.

Players begin the game with 30 ideas represented by wooden cubes in the player's color and six basic Think Cards. Players must use the limited number of cards they have to place and maneuver ideas on the board to form Concepts - various geometric shapes - that make up the Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematical. Players will need to manage their hand size and contents in an effort to obtain the most valuable Think Cards possible without exceeding their hand size. Think Cards played to manipulate ideas do not count towards the player's maximum hand size, but careful management and planning is required because the cards used by a player during their turn return to their hand over time in subsequent turns.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Pattern Building

name: Stalagbite!
description:
Stalagbite! is a game for 2-4 players where you take on the roles of dwarves heading into the deep caverns beneath the Lost Mountains in search of Gold and Glory. Dwarves hammer at the rock formations looking for gold, gems and crystals, but they risk uncovering hazards such as rock falls, deep pools, jagged pits and the primordial horror known as the Stalagbite!

While each player is in theory out to win the game by collecting the most gold, player’s dwarves also earn Hero Points by killing monsters and rescuing comrades. The player with the most points, in both treasure and glory, at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Traders, Raiders & Runners
description:
Traders, Raiders & Runners is a strategic board game of competitive cargo route management. Players take turns placing cargo-carrying Merchants and armed Runners to complete cargo routes and earn gold. Raiders, or pirates, can be used to intercept and steal from Traders.

Each turn the cargo being shipped along each route will change randomly, altering the rules for placement and rewards for completed routes slightly.

The first player to accrue 20 gold wins.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Nautical, Pirates, Print & Play

name: Operation Nam: A Solitaire Game of Tactical Combat in Vietnam
description:
OPERATION NAM is a solitaire game of Tactical Combat in Vietnam. The player assumes the role of a commander of combined forces in Vietnam. As commander, you are responsible for securing your Area of Operations (AOR) by successfully conducting various military operations in order to locate and destroy the enemy. Although there are many units available to you, they may often times be limited to you by political, logistical or geographical obstacles.

Game features Units with colorful graphics that include SEALS, Green Berets, PBRs, Hueys, Cobra Gunships, Leaders, Infantry Squads, Tanks, AFVs, Mortars, Artillery and Airstrikes.

Mission Actions and Combat are resolved on a tactical level.
If you are a Vietnam War enthusiast, you will enjoy this game!

Operation Nam can be found at www.berserkergames.net.
categories: Adventure, Modern Warfare, Print & Play, Vietnam War, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Open Drafting

name: La Bataille de Vimeiro
description:
The battle of Vimeiro on August 21st, 1808 opposed Wellesley's British army to Junot's French army.

The British victory at Vimeiro made the French position in Portugal untenable. The Convention of Sintra was signed on 30 August and the French were transported back to France, with full honors.

Portugal would be free from the French until March, 1809.


La Bataille de Vimiero is not an official Clash of Arms game although it is produced with their approval.

name: Nova Suecia: The Last Letter Home
description:
Nova Suecia - the Board Game© is a board game about colonization, trade and survival in the New World. The players take on the role as governors of the Swedish colony Nova Suecia in the 17th century Delaware. They must cooperate to build a viable economy in the fragile colony since no player can control all parts on his or her own. The colonists need food, the colony needs money and the resources must be manufactured into tradable goods. The players must also, secretely, allocate common and own resources to the budget to prevent the colony from falling to internal and external threats. Each player must thus find a way to get the upper hand in this cooperative act of balance to emerge as a winner in the end. If they fail and the colony of Nova Suecia falls, all players lose!

Game mechanisms include

1. Player balance: The players grow by one district per turn and are thus always equally strong.
2. Game balance: The game has a delicate balance between wealth, food and production. If one area grows on behalf of the others, the game will fall and so will the players.
3. Bidding: All card drawings are followed by biddings where judgement rather than luck determines the outcome.
4. Production & Trade: The players build and develop the game together.
5. Taxation: The players must secretly choose how much to pay for common expenses, thus introducing free-rider and prisoners' dilemma challenges
6. Interdependence: The players must both cooperate and compete to survice.
categories: Economic, Farming, Industry / Manufacturing, Print & Play

name: ATS: Desert Fox
description:
The Advanced Tobruk System (ATS) revisits North Africa with a new collection of scenarios revolving around Rommel's 1941 offensive.
Six geomorphic desert terrain mapboards, 10 sheets of colour overlays and 3 desert escarpment mapboards provide plenty of new places to wage war. Four sheets of full-size ATS counters, with new artwork, fill out the British, German and Italian armies of the day. Also included are 4 sheets of AFV cards, colour enhanced playaid cards and the usual Battlefield Walkaround booklet.

This is not a complete game, as players will need to provide their own ATS rulebook, standard game markers and one or more ten-sided dice.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Fabrica de Software
description:
Fabrica de Software is a game designed for IT Managers to simulate software development concepts. Also possible to see some Project management, Scrum, SOA, and other software development concepts.

In this game, each team will produce software. They need to have resources, programmers and time to make the desired software. Each software requires a certain amount of time, some resources, and programmers to be completed. Teams receive money according to software complexity. The team with the most money wins.

name: Forgo
description:
Two players face off in this unconventional turn-based, patent pending board game developed by late Hungarian inventor József Vadász. Exercising one’s spatial reasoning skills, this innovative game rewards a fine balance between carefully planned strategy and tactics.

The game is played on a hexagonal board with several rows of holes. Each player has two pieces. One piece contains five holes and is long enough to cover five holes in the board; the other piece contains three holes and covers three holes in the board. Players take turns inserting a peg through a hole in one piece/board and then pivoting the piece into a new position. A player loses when one of his pieces is unable to make a move at the beginning of his turn.

name: Liberty Match
description:
Liberty Match was inspired by Go Fish. It can be played with 2 to 6 players. It is played with American Standard Playing Cards, which is a deck of cards inspired by traditional playing cards.

THE DECK

The 58-card deck has 4 suits (Faith, Declaration, Revolution, and Unity) with 14 ranks: The 1st - 10th Amendment, A Gentleman, a Lady, a Patriot, and a Foundation. There are also 2 Jokers, which are actually a king and queen. The suits are in 2 colors: Red and Blue.

Faith is represented by a Blue Triangle, (The "All-seeing Eye of the Creator" - like on the back of the $1 Bill)
Declaration by a Red Pentagon
Revolution by a Red Triquetra (Trinity Knot) with a coiled "Don't tread on me!" style snake in the center.)
and Unity by a Blue Circle with 13 stars.

The deck was designed to have a theme of American history and patriotism. Since America was founded by declaring independence of a royalty-based ruling system, the face cards and suits were changed. The Amendment cards have portions of the actual text of the named Constitutional Amendment printed on the card, and that text is used in the playing of "Liberty Match".

HOW TO PLAY

The dealer deals between 5-7 cards to each player (depending on how many players there are). The remaining playing cards are placed face down to form a stock. The player to dealer's left starts.

Once a pair is made (even if dealt a pair from the beginning) it is to be laid down, face up, on the table in front of the player.

In each turn, a player asks for a rank of card that they already have in their hand from a specific other player. If the asked player has that card, they must give the asking player that card. If the asked player does not have that card, they reply with "Catch a Liberty" - then the asking player takes the top card from the deck on the table.

Before play can continue, the asking player must read the text from one of the other cards in their hand - just the text, not the name of the card. (Players cannot continue to read the same card repeatedly, unless it is their last card.)

If the asking player is given the card they asked for, or if they draw a card that matches one of the cards they are holding, they can continue to go. If a player is told to "Catch a Liberty" and is unable to make a pair, the next player may go.

When a player has no playing cards left, they must then draw a playing card from the stock until all playing cards run out. The game continues until all the playing cards are played even the stock. The winner is the player who then has the most pairs in front of them.

Example of a turn:

Player 1 asks Player 3 if they have the 1st Amendment. Player 3 hands Player 1 a 1st Amendment. Player 1 lays down the two 1st Amendment cards, then reads "A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be infringed."
