(the text from the 2nd Amendment.) And then asks Player 2 if they have any 4th Amendments. Player 2 says "Catch a Liberty". Player 1 draws a card and then reads "Excessive bail shall not be required, nor excessive fines imposed, nor cruel and unusual punishments inflicted." It is now Player 2's turn.

There are 2 Jokers the "King of Tyranny" and "The King's Queen" - these have the 4 suits from the standard - or French Deck.
categories: American Revolutionary War, Card Game, Children's Game, Civilization, Educational, Game System, Memory, Political, Trivia
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Betting and Bluffing, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Memory, Set Collection, Team-Based Game, Trading, Trick-taking

name: Bob's Brain
description:
Our hero Bob has a problem. He needs to do something — but what? And how does he deal with the fallout of what he does? In Bob's Brain, a party game and social experiment of psychological upheaval, the players are different "voices" in Bob's head, each seeking to influence his actions in problem-solving. One player presents problems that Bob faces; the other players come up with solutions, then derive the problems that might come from their answers.

Due to set backs this game has not been published but if you are a psychotherapist and want to try it out at work I will sell one off copies at cost to get people using it in counseling. It has been a very good tool for me in my thirty years in social work.

name: Mystique Pillars
description:
Mystique Pillars is a game for The Mystique Deck, in which 2–6 players compete to play all the cards from their hands onto four growing pillars of cards. The game is played in two phases:

Open draft phase, in which everyone gets to see which cards go into whose hands.
Building phase, in which everyone takes turns either:
…playing a card onto a pillar by matching two attributes with the topmost card of that pillar, or…
…drawing the top card from the deck, and covering the topmost card of a pillar with it — no need to match anything.

name: Time-Travelling Robot Bakery
description:
In Time-Travelling Robot Bakery, you are a programmer who works with robots in a bakery, and it's your job to make sure the robots are working as quickly as possible. These robots are capable of time travel, mind you, so as you battle for ingredients and supplies, it's possible for your opponent to go back in time and get to them before you do. If you can bake a cake with your robots before your opponent can, you win!

In the game, players program four robots to move around a modular board and to try to gather ingredients for a cake. The robots are added to the board one by one, as they duplicate via time travel, creating a parallel algorithm of growing complexity. Coordinating the movements as you add more and more robots to the picture is key to solving this puzzle-y game fastest. The game board is created from double-sided cards, allowing for varying gameplay each session with different options on the different sides of the cards.
mechanics: Action Queue, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Dead Man's Hand: The Stranger
description:
Three scenes and rules and card for a new gang found in Wargames Illustrated 315 p. 66-70.

The rules allows you to make a gang where a Stranger leads a gang of citizens. The magazine also came with four cards to use with the gang.

The three scenes makes and act where the Stranger must lead the citizens against the Bad guys who terrorize the town. When the job is done the stranger rides into the setting sun, if he survives.
categories: American West, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Business Mogul
description:
In Business Mogul you play as the leader of a rising corporate empire, competing with your peers to amass the most power. Game play is centered around building an economic engine, and uses a bidding mechanic where players must balance bids to get the good stuff and to avoid the bad against the actions needed to build their empire, while saving high bids as much as possible to convert to cash at the end of each season.

The game has a fixed number of turns - six seasons of five rounds each - and total play time tends to be about 2-2.5 hours for 4 people (the game is designed for 3-5, with a solid 2-player variant), on par with a feature movie. In every round there is one card per player up for grabs - every player gets a card every round. The cards on which players bid are businesses that are used to build up your economic engine, extra actions to be saved until needed most (and they let a player do some things outside the normal rules of play), special agenda cards that give score a bonus at the end of the game (how much depends on how well the conditions for the given card are fulfilled), and bad events (which are to be avoided if possible).

Players are bidding pick order rather than on a particular item. Each players uses a set nine of bidding cards (getting them all back at the start of each season), which represent how the player is dividing their attention that round between trying to get the best of the available items and getting other stuff done. Each bid has a specific action that it allows (lower bids have more powerful actions), and bids saved for the end of the season are worth extra money - the higher the bid the more it’s worth. These additional aspects associated with each bid, the action and the end-of-season cash value, make for exciting, meaningful choices every round.

Business Mogul supports multiple valid strategies, though the highest final score usually goes to the player that dabbles in additional strategies beyond their primary one. The key to winning is being tactically smart about balancing pick order vs action vs end-of-season-payout, paying attention to the state of other player’s empires and the bids they've already used in the current season, and executing a strategy that adapts to the flow of items up for bid.

There are some fairly common game mechanics/attributes that Mogul specifically does not have:

- It has no player-to-player aggression - the bidding each round is the only point of direct competition.
- It does not have random action outcomes (that is whether or not a given action succeeds is not determined by dice, card draw, or anything like that).
- It does not have any kind of territory control.
- It has no resources / production beyond money and end-game score.
- It does not require memorization of what’s been played; aside from a single hidden card each player gets at the start and the particular bid a player is making in a given round, the state of the game is fully revealed.

name: Hail Caesar: Germania
description:
This 56-page sourcebook, written by Neil Smith, chronicles the devastating blow suffered by the Romans in the Teutoberger Wald at the hands of the Germanic tribes led by Arminius in AD 9. The battle, also known by the Romans as the Varian Disaster, saw the Germans ambush and destroy three Roman legions and their supporting troops, ending Roman territorial expansion across the Danube.

This book provides army lists and special rules for the Germanic tribes, and scenario rules to describe both the battle and its aftermath.
categories: Ancient, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: San Guo Sha: Guan Yu Stamp Edition
description:
UNAUTHORIZED PRODUCTION



The information that BGG has on this item indicates that San Guo Sha is an unauthorized reproduction of BANG! with just a few differences, published in China and distributed in several coutries of the world.




It's a limited edition (20000 copies with unique numbers) for collectors. It contains the base game plus all official expansions (Battle, Wind, Fire, Woods and Mountain).

In the 2011 Guan Yu Stamp edition, two characters were changed:

Zhou Yu (WU, from base game): the second ability now gives out the card before the damage is dealt.

Zhu Rong (SHU, from Fire exp.): the second ability allows a point duel only with the direct victim of her Strike (not with shackled players).


Legends of the Three Kingdoms (a.k.a. San Guo Sha) is a card game based off the Chinese classical novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms, which shares many rules with Bang!, the differences are as follows:
1. The Monarch (Sheriff) may get an additional skill related to their kingdom allegiance; players routinely have two powers.
2. Weapons may have their own additional powers.
3. A card to let a player borrow a weapon from another.
4. A card to cancel the effect of other cards.
5. Peach (Beer) may be played by any player when someone loses their last life; there is no exemption of using Peach when there are only 2 players left.
6. The game proceeds counter-clockwise.

name: Radio-Sende-Spiel
description:
This is a simple roll and move game with the objective of touring wartime Germany and being the first to reach the final (100) space.

However, the primary objective of the game was to encourage both patriotism and obedience to wartime rules, specifically the prohibition on listening to foreign broadcasters.

When landing on domestic transmitter spaces, the players must carry out certain actions: sing a ditty, send a message, make a weather report or sing a military song. But if they land on a foreign transmitter space, they must exclaim "I have committed a criminal offense", pay a pfennig into the pot and go back to start. Worst is if they land on London's transmitter, when they must shout "God punish England!" and pay 5 pfennig into the pot as well as start over. The pot is taken by the winner.

The title "Radio-Sende-Spiel" translates in Google Translate to "Radio Broadcast Game".
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Racing, World War II

name: Anima Tactics: Frederick Adler
description:
Frederick Adler is a brilliant strategist and has controlled the Empire's intelligence service , the Hand of the Emperor, since the reign of the last Emperor. Despite being a cold and remorseless monster of a man, his loyalty to the throne is fanatical and unwavering. He wholeheartedly supports the Empress with his extensive network of covert agents.

Dark Empire Prowler — Lv. 45

At 4 | Dm 4 | Df 9 | Ar 2 | LP 13 | Re 10 | Mo 8/12 | AP 3/4

Imperial Resources: Imperial Agents (male and female) may spend an additional 5 levels on upgrades. This doesn't actually increase their cost.

o — Order of Assassination (Subterfuge, Effect, Reactive)
When a friendly Dark unit within Adler's Control Zone makes an attack they roll an additional die keeping the highest result.

o — War Sacrifice (Subterfuge, Effect, Reactive)
A friendly unit within Adler's Control Zone gets +X Attack until the end of the turn. X equals the amount of LP that unit sacrifices for this ability, up to 3 LP.

o — Disposable Agents (Special Effect, Reactive)
This ability may only be used once at the end of the Maintenance Phase. A friendly unit within Adler's Control Zone gets Shield Lv. 1 and Berserker Lv. 1.

ooo — Kortana (Ki, Attack)

+ 2 Damage / -2 Armor. Adler has Critical Mastery for this attack.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Miniatures

name: Space Frontier
description:
Space Frontier is a game of space exploration for 2-4 players. Players compete to spread their influence across a region of uncharted space. The game takes roughly an hour to an hour and a half to play with 2 players with each additional player adding about a half hour.

Each player controls a command ship and its supporting fleets. The command ship is a mobile factory, research lab, and ship carrier. Players will use it to construct the fleets that help spread their influence far and wide.

The modular space map is built from randomized tiles each game as players explore. The random map generation ensures no two games of Space Frontier are exactly the same.

Players gain influence through missions, research, trade, or conquest. Players can be as cooperative or antagonistic with each other as they wish. Thus, games can be played and won where military might reigns supreme, or without a shot being fired.
categories: Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Modular Board

name: Rock Science: Bandit Booster Pack
description:
A stand-alone game that integrates with Rock Science or Rock Science: Festival.

320 new questions to Rock Science. Of Bandit Rock (Swedish Radio Station). In Swedish. Boost your original game or play instantly with the included special rules.

Challenge your mates and see who is the most rock for real! Three difficulty levels and smart betting allows the beginner to give the uber nerd a fair fight. Perfect for pre-party or a hard-packed evening.

Meet the heaviest rock stars, remember the songs and hear the wildest stories.


320 new questions about the myths, rock stars, songs and albums.
Play directly with the supplied Booster Pack Rules.
Bandits host reveals juicy details about rock stars ... and themselves!
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Singing

name: Mission: Farm
description:
The board game Mission: Farm is an original strategy game for everyone, inspired from... the modern rural life!
Welcome to the remote village of Farmaria! Are you ready to live the ultimate rural experience? Make the best investments, expand your farm, increase your income and your fame and be the greatest farmer of all ages! But beware for... environmental conditions and opposing farmers are coveting your fortune! Can you cope with them?

A modern strategy game with the element of intense competition that develops the players' perception of commercial transactions and good management of opportunities.

σœçγχρονης αγροτικŒÆς ζωŒÆς! ΕπιστροφŒÆ στη φœçση λοιπœåν!

name: GridZone Football
description: It is a fast-paced game of 7-on-7 football, based on a fictional sport, where field position translates to points. The goal of this game is to provide a football-like game experience that enables sustainable league and career play. This is accomplished through smaller rosters and streamlined statistics.

name: Monopoly: St. Mawes Edition
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μœåνος (alone or single) + polein πωλε·øñν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from St. Mawes, in the United Kingdom.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Reading Roundup
description:
Howdy y’all! It’s a reading race through the southwest! Pick your cards, gallop around the board to round up all your words, and giddy up home before the other players to win! Game features the top 25 building block words.

Teaches 25 key Kindergarten words.

name: Meerkats
description:
2, 3 or 4 players

Materials

A hexagonal board with 5 hexagons per side, 64 stones in four colors, 16 red, 16 yellow, 16 green and 16 blue.

You will also need a small drawstring bag.

Definitions

Group – A set of like color connected stones, a single stone is also considered a group.

Rules

The board is placed between the players and starts out empty.

Place 4 stones 1 each of the 4 colors (red,green,blue,yellow) in a bag and then the youngest player draws a stone and passes the bag to the next player.

After all the stones are drawn players look at their stones without revealing them to the other players.

All stones will remain hidden until the end of the game.

The color of drawn stones corresponds to the color of the stones that belong to that player.

The remaining 60 stones are placed nearby.

The youngest player starts by dropping a stone of any color onto an empty hexagon, then turn moves clockwise.

From now on, each player on his turn must drop 1 stone of any color onto an empty hexagon and then move a different stone already on the board to another empty hexagon.

Restrictions

• A stone may not be dropped onto a cell that has no adjacent empty cell.
• A stone is moved in a straight line either orthogonally until another stone in its path or the edge of the board blocks it.
• Stones cannot jump over other stones.

The game ends when a player is unable to take his turn.

Players then reveal their hidden stones, the player with the largest group in her color wins.

If two or more players are tied when comparing their largest groups then look at their second largest groups as a tie-breaker.

When playing a 2 or 3 player game the rules are the same as above with but one exception, leave the undrawn stones in the bag.
mechanics: Enclosure, Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: Ender Dungeon's Last Crawl
description:
Ender Dungeon's Last Crawl is a light game with simple mechanics meant for casual gamers or even as a gateway game. Players each become 1 of 3 heroes sent by the king to exact revenge upon the local terror, Ender Dungeon.

You and your friends will delve deep into Ender’s caves by rolling dice and slaying wave after wave of the boss’ ferocious minions. After 45 to 60 minutes of fierce battle, the surviving heroes will finally come face-to-paper-face with Ender Dungeon himself.

Can you slay the fiend and save the kingdom?

This is a light game with very light mechanics. Players fight against progressively more difficult monster decks. Fighting takes place by rolling dice in an attempt to roll higher than the monsters.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval

name: Knights of Arthur: A Game of Knightly Adventure in the Age of King Arthur.
description:
BACKGROUND: Kinghts of Arthur is an adventure game where the players assume the role of a Heroic Knights in the age of King Arthur. The Player Knights are young, eager Knights anxious to prove themselves in order to become a Knight of the Round Table. In order to accomplish this, the Player Knights must seek out adventures and quests to improve their attributes and receive a grant from King Arthur to join the Knights of the Round Table.

Game-Play
Each Player creates their own Player Knight Character composed of the following Attributes: Virtue, Resolve, Chivalry, Stamina, Combat and Defense. Each Player Knight takes their turn individually, using a Player-Knight Counter to represent themselves on the Map. Each Player's Turn consists of the following actions:
SEQUENCE OF PLAY
1. Move, Heal wounds or Stay Put. Party may move, Heal or remain in the current location.
2. Encounter Check: Roll on the Encounter Table for each area entered to determine if an Encounter occurs.
3. Resolve Encounter. If an Encounter occurs, roll on the Reaction Chart to determine the Encounter’s reaction. Resolve the Encounter to conclusion, including combat.
4. Conduct Knightly Action: The Player Knight may conduct one of the following Actions: Enter Town/Castle, Shop, Seek Entry to a Castle,Resolve Quest, Acquire a Ship, and several other actions.
5. Attribute Improvement: Player Knights may Trade in earned Valor Points to Improve their Attributes.

Combat is resovled on a Battle Mat representing a Castle and surroundings. The combat system is man-to-man and has the feel of skirmish fighting, but, resolved quickly without slowing the game.

Knights of Arthur is full of Arthurian Themes from various sources, but, especially from Sir Thomas Mallory's Le Morte D'Arthur. As a Knight, you will perform many Knightly duties including completing quests, dispatching bandits and brigands, participate in battles and sieges, rescuing damsels and possibly serving them. There are Tournaments to participate in and Monsters to slay!

If you enjoy books like Le Morte D'Arthur or movies like Excalibur, you will enjoy this game.

Knights of Arthur can be found at http://www.berserkergames.net
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Role Playing

name: Way of the Ninja: Capture the Shoguns Enemies!
description:
The Shoguns enemies have escaped! As a Ninja, you are tasked to capture them back. But beware! Your rival Ninjas are on the same task! It's an all-out war to gain the Shoguns favor! Who will win?

The objective of the game is to acquire victory points by going from locations to locations and defeating as many hidden enemies as you can and reach the end of the game by defeating all bosses hidden inside the Enemies pile while preventing your life from reducing to 0. At the end of the game, the player or team of players with the most number of victory points wins!

name: Monsters of London
description:
From the box description:

London, 1890:
In the fog veiled streets of the city monsters are on the loose – what a nuisance for the good and hard working citizens! Queen Victoria is not amused and prescribes a bounty for every captured beast.
Become a monster hunter, catch the monsters and earn loads of money!
______________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Monsters of London is a dice-driven card game for 2-5 monster hunters.
Capture monsters and collect coins by rolling dice and pressing your luck to get the right combinations, or just steal from your opponents.
Use your monster's abilities in cunning combinations and win this fast paced game as the richest monster hunter of all times.
______________________________________________________________________________________________________________

The game was designed and developed as Design Bachelor Thesis project in 2014 by Patricia Limberger and Felix Leder.
The first edition's 36 exclusive copies were hand manufactured.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: Tiger Attack!  The Battle of the Bulge, Ardennes 1944
description:
A relatively fast, very playable point-to-point game at roughly regiment/combat command/brigade unit scale and 1-day per turn time scale, using my simple Dark Crusade combat table and system, plus Disruption and fortification. U.S. starts with 19 units, Germans with many more. Playing time is a couple hours.

Special Peiper, Bayerlein, and Abrams leader counters and a Skorzeny 150th Brigade Brandenburgers unit are included, as well as the 2 historical Tiger tank battalions. (Some offensive-shocked GIs were reporting any panzer as being a Tiger tank.)

Fuel is unlimited for the Americans and crucial and weather-dependent for the Germans - vs. Allied airpower. My Patton's Prayer rule (for better weather) from my hex-and-counter Tigers in the Ardennes is included, as is a rule for the chance of a "blonde and beautiful" U.S. Army nurse diverting Bayerlein's attention, as occurred historically and possibly decisively on his/Panzer Lehr Division's way to Bastogne.

Map and units can alternatively be used with Major Battles and Campaigns combat system.
categories: Dice, Print & Play, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Banquet
description: In this two player card drafting game, both players compete to get the most points from their single row of animals. However, each animal has various effects that can cause you to rearrange your row for more points or to interfere with your opponent, among other things. When both players have 6 cards in a row in front of them, all game ending effects from animals are applied and the player with the most points wins.

name: 300 fets de llengua
description:
300 fets de llengua ("300 language events") is a word/linguistics game on the history of Catalan language. It consists in 300 round cards, each one containing a brief note on a historical event related to the Catalan language and a challenge for the players. There are 10 different kinds of challenges: to create anagrams, to find words, to define words, to identify acronyms, to guess word meanings, etc.

In a game, 30 cards are selected at random: these will be the challenges to the players; and each player begins with 300 points. The game is played in turns. In a player's turn, he/she draws one of the 30 cards and reads the brief historical note and the kind of challenge. Then all players bet points to solve the challenge, before actually knowing the challenge (they just know its kind). After deducting the points bet of each player, the active player reads the challenge and the players try to solve it. All players having solved the challenge receive double the points they bet, while the higher better receives three times the points bet; the players not having solved the challenge receive nothing. After the 30 challenges have been played, the player with most points is the winner.
publishers: Departament de Cultura. Generalitat de Catalunya

name: Ratnapura
description:
Welcome to Sri Lanka in the late middle ages. This small island to the South of India is well known for its gemstones. And welcome to Ratnapura, the city of gems and the seat of king Parakkamabahu II. The royal treasurer died and the king is looking for a suitable successor to take care of his vast collection of precious stones and to grow the king’s richess. Any suitable candidate has not only to know everything there is to know about gems, but also has to be a cunning business man who understands how to manipulate the market so that he can triumph over all the others.

In the game of Ratnapura the players have a hand of gem cards which they play in order to win tricks. The trump values of several of the suits are determined at the start of the game and can be influenced by the players by winning “grand tricks”. Changing the value of those suits is crucial for improving your chances of winning tricks, but all the other players will try to do the same. A number of special suits can be used to secure especially valuable tricks or to dump worthless glass marbles into other players treasure vaults.

Ratnapura uses a specially prepared deck for all player counts and thus plays as well with 2 players as it does with the full complement of 5.

Cool Factors:
- A trick-taking game that actually plays equally well with 2 or 5 players;
- Adjustable trump values.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Deduction, Dice, Medieval, Number

name: TKG ARENA: Rise of the Magi
description:
As champions battle it out in the different arenas of the Elemental Kings for power and glory, a new force emerges among these ranks.

Powerful magic-users known as the Magi armed with arcane powers of more than one Elemental King provide mercenary offers to their new hosts. As alliances come and go so will the tides of battle ...

This is an expansion to the original TKG ARENA: The Elemental Kings, featuring:

The Elemental Oinks - a magical currency that is a measure of one's monetary and magical capacity at the same time crucial to the new concept of DECKOUT cost.

The Charge Bar - a mechanism focusing elemental energy that can translate into useful effects in battle.

The Rise of the Magi Battle Framework - This new Battle Framework re-implements the former The Elemental Kings Framework for even more intricate spell play and embedment.

Are you ready to rewrite the rules yet?
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Action Points, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: Dem Gems
description:
Dem Gems is a quick play micro game and the theme of Dem Gems is rather abstract, you're collecting gems in a stoney looking labyrinth as a small coloured cylinder.... Basically you are there to collect as many gems as possible in an ever changing maze while you try to avoid holes, bombs and other players.

The cards are narrow domino cards which are first shuffled and then 8 of them are laid out face up to make a 4 x 4 square board. The remaining cards are then dealt out equally face down to the players, any remaining cards are put to one side. Each player puts their piece at a corner (not on the board yet) and rolls the die to determine who goes first.
You roll the die and you MUST move your piece that number of spaces even if it means losing gems! After you have moved you then place one of your cards from your hand onto the board to change the layout. This can be to your advantage or to sabotage another player.

Keep track of your scores with a notepad and pen to make it easier and once all players have played their cards and had an equal number of turns you count up the scores. The player with the highest score wins.

name: Anima Tactics: Damaris
description:
Publisher Blurb:

Mercenary, executioner, murderer ... there isn't an infamous title that Wolfgang hasn't taken to heart. His great physical prowess isn't the only reason that he has become part Gaul's personal forces. The blood of the Naga runs through his veins, making him able to poison his enemies with just a touch of his skin.

Dark Church Mystic — Lv. 35
At 4 | Dm 2 | Df 8 | Ar 0 | LP 12 | Re 11 | Mo 8/12 | AP 3/4
Summoner Level: 1
Affinity: Light, Dark
oo — Dark Power (Magic, Effect)
A unit within Damaris' Control Zone gets +2 Attack until the end of the turn and Doom Lv. 1. Effect 16 (only if used on enemy). Limit: Once per turn.
oo — Spirit Link (Magic, Effect, Reactive)
When a friendly unit within Damaris' Control Zone is destroyed, you may use this ability to have them remain in play until the end of the turn instead of being removed immediately. The destroyed unit gets Intangible and can't be damaged in anyway or removed from the game until the end of the turn.
o — Life Link (Magic, Effect, Reactive)
When a friendly unit within Damaris' Control Zone is destroyed, another friendly unit, also in Damaris' Control Zone, recovers 1 LP for every 5 levels of the destroyed character.
o — Death Link (Magic, Effect, Reactive)
When a friendly unit within Damaris' Control Zone is destroyed, all enemy units within Damaris' Control Zone each take 5 damage. Effect 15.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Miniatures

name: Infantry Attacks: Sinai-Palestine
description:
From the Avalanche Press website:

While the campaign in Flanders turned into a bloody struggle in which hundreds of thousands died for a few feet of shattered earth, the Allied Powers sought new fronts on which they might have more success. A series of major offensives in Ottoman-ruled Palestine began in the fall of 1916. After some early failures the Allies steadily moved forward, their advance culminating in the capture of Damascus in October 1918.

Sinai-Palestine is a stand-alone game in the Infantry Attacks series, our World War One equivalent to the long-running Panzer Grenadier series. Units are companies and squadrons, and the sixty scenarios represent actions from the campaigns in the Sinai Peninsula and Palestine between 1915 and 1918, with the Ottoman Turkish army on one side supported by German and Austro-Hungarian detachments, and the British on the other supported by Australian, New Zealand, Jewish, Arab, Indian and West Indian forces.

The pieces are the fantastic, tile-thick laser-cut type seen in Kursk: Burning Tigers and Korean War: Pusan Perimeter. They're just plain fun to handle, and have no scorching or soot like some laser-cut game pieces. These are the best wargame counters ever made.

There are six semi-rigid mapboards, the same type found in Panzer Grenadier games. They are fully compatible with the Panzer Grenadier boards — you can play scenarios from either series on mapboards from the other game system.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Fields of Fire:  Miniatures Rules for Modern Combat
description:
Fields of Fire is a miniatures game for combat from 1975 to present. This Origins-award-winning game allows players to command units from platoon to battalion size.

Originally designed for 1:285 scale miniatures, minis up to 20 mm may be used if the player prefers. Game is scaled to where one miniature equals one vehicle.

The heart of the game play system is the play charts. This game takes most of the math out of miniatures play--without sacrificing accuracy.

Rules include information on playing with all types of modern units, from infantry to helicopters, tanks to artillery, APCs to fixed wing aircraft.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Team-Based Game

name: Tithe
description:
In feudal times, the different taxes levied upon the citizens were essential to maintain the prosperity of the kingdom and to overthrow other lords who taxed to much. Tithe is a fun card game in which four different kings struggle to raise more gold and to take power in the kingdom.

Tithe is a quick and easy game designed by Pablo Bella, for 2-4 players ages 8, lasting about 30 minutes.

In the game, players have hidden identities, and try to gain the power of the crown for their families. There are four kings in the game that make a deck of kings, and determine the predominant color in the course of the game.

In addition to the kings deck, there is a character deck. Players draw cards from this deck, and each round players will play character card to try to win the trick. Each character has a color (of the family), a strength value to measure victories in trick that are played and a value in gold (victory points).

When everybody plays one card strength and families are compared to determine which player wins the trick. This continues until all character cards from the deck have been played. But beware! It is not the player who wins the most tricks that wins the game, but the player that accumulates the most gold!

Tithe is a very quick and simple game, available in Spanish and English version and totally free for all Dizemo fans.

name: European Illuminati
description:
European Illuminati is a expansion set of eighteen new cards for the game Illuminati. It adds European based background cards to the basic game.

First published in TSRs British magazine, Imagine (Issue 6 - Sep 1983), where the reader would need to constuct the cards by cutting out or photocopying the page of cards from the article.

The new cards includes; The Samaritans, The Vatican, Lions of Longleat, Irish Sectarian Army, The GLC, The Old School Tie, Dr Who and many more.
categories: Card Game, Novel-based, Political, Science Fiction

name: A Peloponnesian War
description:
A Peloponnesian War is a game simulating the Peloponnesian War between Sparta and Athens in ancient Greece. Each player represent one of these two important cities and will try to orientate as much areas as possible to its side. The focus is on influence rather than on real wargaming and it is useful for pupils studying the ancient Greece at primary school.

Each turn represents six months roughly.
The map represents Greece in the V century BC and the surroundings, divided into areas, each with its relevant name, connected by lines, which represent the connections between the areas (see 5).
The game scale is based upon Orientation Counters, which show the side which controls the area.

It is part of the Dice Less Serie from Lumaca Games!
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Point to Point Movement, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Kingdom Death: Monster ‚Äì Snow the Savior Challenge Scenario
description:
Snow the Savior is a single-miniature expansion for Kingdom Death: Monster. She was not marked as promotional, so will likely be available for purchase in the future.

This release was supposed to include a one shot challenge scenario.

The miniature of Snow the Savior shipped in Wave 1 of Kickstarter fulfillment, but the game content mentioned in the campaign was not included. Game creator Adam Poots mentioned that the content would be printed and released on their website eventually. For now, it is available in PDF format on the Kingdom Death website.
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Horror, Mature / Adult, Miniatures
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing

name: Um Himmels Willen
description:
Um Himmels Willen (For Heaven's Sake) is the game of the crazy cards. The rules are simple: Play a card, comply the task and score the points. There are three kinds of tasks:
*A trivia question: Ask the question to another player. If his answer is correct, both you and that player gain points.
*A puzzle: Make a certain card combination to score points.
*A dexterity challenge: Complete some action that requires balance or sleight of hand.

Based on a unique concept, Um Himmels Willen garantees fun, tension and variety for gamers of all ages.

Um Himmels Willen is very interactive and contains also a special variant for Teams.

Original description (German):
Tante Lise hat gerade ein Farbenpaar ausgespielt, Oma Frieda der kleinen Hanna eine Quizfrage gestellt und Papa Ferdi versucht 10 Karten auf seinem Körper zu verteilen, während er eine Spielkarte auf seinem Kopf balanciert.

Um Himmels Willen ist das Spiel der verrückten Karten. Denkbar einfach sind dabei die Regeln. Karte spielen, Aufgabe erfüllen und Punkte kassieren. Aus drei Kategorien können die Spieler eine Aufgabe wählen: Quizfragen, Knobel- und Geschicklichkeitsaufgaben.

Eine Quizfrage stellt man einem beliebigen Mitspieler. Kann dieser die Frage richtig beantworten, bekommt auch der Fragensteller Punkte. Man muss also kein Quizmaster sein, um Punkte zu bekommen. Die Mitspieler richtig einschätzen zu können, ist viel wichtiger. Bei den Knobelaufgaben gilt es Kombinationen mit den verschiedenen Eigenschaften der Karten zu bilden: Farbe, Buchstabe oder Zahl zu Drillingen, Wörtern oder Straßen formen und Punkte kassieren. Die Geschicklichkeitsaufgaben fordern Balance, Fingerfertigkeit und Spontanität von den Spielern. Aber auch eine gute Beobachtungsgabe kann hilfreich sein um Punkte zu machen, gibt es ja noch diese „Geheim“-Karten. Passt man nicht gut auf, landet so eine fiese Karte schnell auf dem eigenen Punktestapel. Oder man verpasst eine Blitzaufgabe und kassiert Minuspunkte.

Interaktivität wird bei „Um Himmels Willen“ groß geschrieben. Ein Großteil der Aufgaben bindet mehrere Spieler mit ein. Jeder kann immer mitmachen, ist aber nicht gezwungen dazu.

Durch das einzigartige Konzept wird für alle Altersgruppen Abwechslung, Spaß und Spannung geboten.

Für 3-6 Spieler, ab 8 Jahren.

Eine spezielle Team/Familien-Variante ermöglicht es auch größeren Gruppen Freude an "Um Himmels Willen" zu haben.

Für 2-6 Teams, ab 8 Jahren.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Party Game

name: Viking Raiders: The Fortified Medieval Harbor
description:
The Fortified Harbor was an extension designed for Vikings and supposed to be released in 1991. It was never released due to technical issues. General design was almost completed, but the translucent film used for the black line drawing had slightly stretched when passing in a copy machine, probably under the influence of heat. Duccio Vitale didn't have the money to redo all four maps and the project aborted.

17 years later, Buxeria got access to the original files and was able to restore them. The 4 maps that make the complete Fortified Harbor and the various counters intended for the game are now available for sale but the various booklets which were supposed to be provided originally were never written.

name: QUBQST
description:
From The Game Crafter page:

Can you conquer the catacombs?

Now with BIGGER BAG! Easier to select cubes at random, and enough room to store all the game pieces as an alternative to the game box ***




QUBQST (cubequest) is a dice rolling, dungeon crawling game, that takes classic elements from early fantasy role-playing games, and mixes them with simple to pick up gameplay, and retro computer game style graphics!

QUBQST plays like a casual computer game - generate your catacombs, take your party of characters (Warrior, Wizard and Thief) through, encountering creatures, traps, secret rooms, items and treasures, until you reach the Golden Cube, your final destination in the catacombs!

Only by defeating all of the creatures on the Golden Cube, can the party win, calculate their score, and see how they rank - will they be Hopeless Heroes, Average Adventurers, or Catacomb Conquerors?!

Play alone to beat your best score, or with others either co-operatively, or to beat each other's scores!

THE CHARACTERS!
Warrior - no special skills, but strong and great in combat, and can go into a beserker fighting rage!
Wizard - weak in combat, but can cast classic spells like Invisibility, Shield, Heal and Fireball!
Thief - can sneak past creatures, steal their treasures, disarm traps, and detect secret rooms!

THE CREATURES!
The classic creatures in the catacombs range from Kobolds to Cockatrices, Goblins to Gelatinous Cubes, and Banshees to Balrogs!

THE TREASURES!
Collect Gold Pieces and Gems, find the Vorpal Sword, the Holy Cross, the Spellbook and more to help you on your quest!

THE CUBES!
QUBQST has 36 cubes (dice) in total!
10 Catacomb Cubes (including the Golden Cube) - caverns, chambers and corridors to explore
9 Combat Cubes - used to determine the results of combat
8 Creature Cubes - the different creatures that dwell in the catacombs
4 Cache Cubes - Gold Pieces, Gems, Normal Items and Magic Items
3 Character Cubes - Warrior, Wizard and Thief, used to show their Hit Power and test their skills
1 Casting Cube - shows how many Casting Points the Wizard has
1 Contraption Cube - shows any traps that are triggered
categories: Dice, Exploration, Fantasy, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Network and Route Building

name: Hellfire Pass
description:
THE SITUATION

The time is 0515 hrs, 15 June 1941

The British offensive, code-named Operation Battleaxe, began at 0515 hours, June 15th, 1941. The aim was to overrun the Axis frontier positions, defeat the Axis armored reserves, and then drive west to relieve Tobruk. The attack came to grief in large part because of the deadly fire of German 88s well-emplaced in several key positions, but most famously at the key defile of Halfaya Pass, forever after known as Hellfire Pass.

THE GAME

Hellfire Pass is a World War II simulation of the British Battleaxe offensive on 15-17 June, 1941. Operation Brevity is also included as an introductory scenario. This game marks a long-awaited, new chapter for the fast-playing, operational-level system enjoyed by many in Beda Fomm – a classic Frank Chadwick game design. The popularity of the game system is its blend of simple gaming mechanics that delivers fast-paced, nail-biting action suitable for solitaire or competition play.

Fans of Beda Fomm will be pleased to learn that the original game system has been retained, while also evolving and elaborating on it to best capture the protracted nature of the battles in this game. Both the Brevity and Battleaxe offensives were examples of protracted combat where both sides were challenged to sustain their efforts in the field while also maneuvering aggressively over a wider landscape. New rules covering Supply, Repairs and Regrouping, and Morale Recovery represent additions that speak to that need to sustain operations in the face of losses. The game also reflects the greater availability of certain weapons – primary AT guns.

Now available for preorder from Consim Press

name: Seal Team: Vietnam ‚Äì A Solitaire Game of Naval Special Warfare in Vietnam
description:
SEAL TEAM: VIETNAM is a solitaire game of Naval Special Operations Combat in Vietnam. The player assumes the role of a commander of a US Navy SEAL Platoon in Vietnam. As commander, you are responsible for securing your Area of Operations (AOR) by successfully conducting various military operations in order to locate and destroy the enemy. Although there are many units available to you, they may often times be limited to you by political, logistical or geographical obstacles.

GAME OBJECTIVE
The objective of SEAL TEAM is to successfully complete a number of missions and destroy enemy forces in order to gain Victory Points (VP) for the US Forces. The player can choose to play a short game (4 Missions), an average game (6 Missions), a long game (8 Missions) or a full Tour (12 Missions). Once all Missions have been resolved (successfully or not) the Player totals his VP and compares this with the Victory Determination Table to determine the level of success.

GAME FEATURES
SEAL TEAM features many colorful Counters and Large Hex Map. Missions include RECON Patrols, Ambush Patrols, Snatch and Grabs, River Patrols and Ambushes, Raids, Search and Destroy and Phoenix Operations. SEAL Counters represent individual SEALs. Vehicles include PBRs, Huey Helicopters, STAB Boats, and AH-1 Cobra Gunships.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Open Drafting

name: The Baseball Game
description:
From the box: The Baseball Game is a computer generated, mathematically pure game that enables you to replay Big League baseball games by transferring the performance records of Big League players from the playing field to playing cards.

Each Pitcher's card is divided into strikes, balls or spaces where the Batter hits the ball. Each Batter's card is divided into four columns that match the Ground Ball, Fly Ball, Line Drive and Long Drive spaces on the Pitcher's card. Simply go to the matching column on the Batter's card and roll the dice to find if the Batter is out, hit safely or reached base on an error. After the Batter hits the ball, each play is completed by referring to the simplified Fielding and Base Running Charts on the playing board.

This game is licensed by Little League Baseball.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: Fierce Battle! Rommel's Corps
description:
Fierce Battle! Rommel's Corps is one of "40 Series". 40 Series is simulation games having the concept of "using 40 playing pieces and taking 40 minutes to finish".

The theme of Fierce Battle! Rommel's Corps is "Operation Crusader" launched from 18 November 1941 by the British Eighth Army. In this operation, British Army succeeded in the raising of the siege of Tobruk that had been besieged by the Axis Army.
One person commands the British Army, the other person the Axis Army.

name: Corporate Chaos
description:
Corporate Chaos is a new independent card game. You and your fellow 'corporate drones' struggle to keep your job. You also don't want to get promoted or else you will become part of the soulless corporate machine. Try not to get too stressed out though or you'll burn out.

Each player (drone) is given a tracker for his/her HR Warnings, Career, and Stress levels. If any of those trackers reach 5, that drone is out of the game (sort of).

Each round (workday) goes like this. Each drone chooses 1-3 cards to play from his/her hand of 7 cards and places the face down on the table. Once everyone is ready, the drones take turns revealing his/her cards. Everydrone adds up his/her productivity for the day. The drone with the highest productivity gets "praise from the boss" and has to draw a career card (which will most likely increase the career stat) and the drone(s) with the lowest productivity gets "yelled at by the boss" and increases their HR Warnings stat; all other drones are safe for the day. Everydrone draws back up to 7 hand cards and the game goes until there is only one drone left.
mechanics: Hand Management, Take That, Variable Phase Order

name: Exchange
description:
Exchange is a quick and casual game for 2-4 players to enjoy.

Players must collect three-of-a-kind for each suit, and then empty their hand to win. Reversible effect cards allow players to choose not only which card to play, but also how that card will effect the game!

Exchange is light-hearted, with a low skill curve making it a great choice for players of all ages.

name: Countermine
description:
A precariously balanced game of strategy

Be first to make five rows of five. But be alert, because every row you make changes the board and gives your opponent the chance for a counter-attack.

This is a pure strategy board game for two players. The board is a uniform grid and the players have equal pieces. The variety and replay value come from the many levels of threat and bluff in how you place your pieces.

name: 97 Cent Space Battle
description:
ALERT ALERT ALERT ALERT ALERT ALERT

“Admiral, sensors have picked up three Nickel Class Cruisers dropping out of warp.”

“Scramble the Centurions. Have the Dimestroyers set up a defensive perimeter around our HeadQuarter. If it’s a fight our enemies want, we’ll pay them back in kind.”

Welcome to 97 Cent Space Battle, where starships look suspiciously like coins and space combat is fought in two dimensions (unless the ships fall off the table).

In this game you’ll flip, flick, and spin your ships in an all-out assault on your opponent’s HeadQuarter.

The game itself is a free rules download. You'll need some table space and 97 cents for each player (1 quarter, 3 dimes, 6 nickels, and 12 pennies).

97 Cent Space Battle is played in two phases. During the deploy phase, the fleets warp to the combat area. Players flip their coins onto the table. The outcome of each toss (heads or tails) determines whether the ship made a perfect warp and can activate immediately. Just flick your ship at an enemy to blow it up.

During the assault phase, players take turns activating their surviving ships, until a player loses his Headquarter or his fleet is destroyed.

name: Super Mini Adventure
description:
A Competitive Card Game to Slayer Monsters and Mess with Other Players! In Cute Pixel Art!

In Super Mini Adventure, players lead parties of powerful heroes and delve deep into the dungeons to slay foul monsters, all in the name of honor, glory, and shinning loot! But wait! For the biggest danger comes not from the monsters, but your fellow adventures! Watch out for their back-stabs and sabotages, as everyone frantically competes to slay the monsters and claim the prizes. Let the slaying begin!

The goal of the game is to earn Coins by defeating Monsters. Players do this by forming up to two adventuring parties of Heroes, assigning 1 Champion and 1 Companion role to each. Players then attempt to defeat the monsters by matching up to their stats (STR, MAG, and DEX), all the while playing different Hero cards and utilizing abilities to block other players from making the kill. At the end, when all the Monsters are defeated, the most courageous (and cunning) player with the most Coins wins.


Super Mini Adventure is a Take That! style card game. Players play out combinations of different Hero cards to defeat monsters, while utilizing the different abilities on those cards to gain the upper hand. Construct combos and chain abilities, to set yourself up not only for the kill, but also to block and prevent your opponent from doing the same. Simple to learn, but with deep layers of strategies that will have you coming back for more!
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Take That

name: Hackronyms
description:
Hackronyms is a fast-paced word game for 2-6 players where players race to finish or pass increasingly complex sentences.

Players have around five seconds per each acronym card on the table to create a complete sentence. An example of this might be "LOL" or "Lionel offered lemons." Completing a sentence allows that player to receive a point and add an acronym card to the end of the row--making the sentence more complicated for the next player to handle. The next player then needs to say a complete sentence for the next combination of letters. Using the previous example, if "GG" was added after, a sentence could be "Lucy only likes good games."

Failing to complete a sentence causes that player to lose a point and the round to end. Players finish a number of rounds corresponding to the number of players playing.

Action cards add to the mix causing cards to be shuffled, turn order to be reversed, players to be skipped and so much more.

name: Escape Pod
description:
The Captain signals... "RED ALERT"
Moments later you and your crew will gather together and defend yourself from the alien menace. The only option is to escape the ISS Powhatan and destroy the ship before it enters Celeritas orbit. Continue the story. Save the crew. Win the game.

Escape Pod is the first in a trilogy of co-operative games about leading a doomed crew to their rescue. Each player assumes the role of a member of the ISS Powhatan, a supply ship in the Junxti system. When the ship is boarded by hostile aliens, the crew must work together to gather supplies and prepare the escape pod. Finally, you must activate the self-destruct system and escape to the planet below!

Gameplay consists of players taking turns. At the beginning of their turn each player rolls dice to place aliens on the board and then navigates the ship using their action points. Players can search rooms to reveal item cards that will assist them in their efforts. When a player comes into a room with aliens, combat ensues utilizing an 8 sided die with the outcome influenced by weapons the player may have. Certain rooms such as the fuel tanks and the transporter rooms can be "activated" to accomplish the goal and allow the players to escape!

Player characters include; Captain, Security Officer, Transporter Chief, Damage Controlman, Quartermaster, Chief Engineer, and Sensor Operator. Each character has a unique ability to assist in the players winning the game.

name: Five Men in Normandy .30 Cal edition
description:
A skirmish war game for WW2 battles. Playable with any miniatures already in your colletion though better suited for 15mm and up.

If you have been on the look out for a skirmish game that gives you plenty to work with,
which gives you a fully featured world war 2 campaign experience from the perspective of a small "band of brothers",
which gives you tools with which to create interesting missions and captivating scenarios
which presents unpredictable situations and characters, keeping each campaign and each battle fresh and interesting
then Five Men in Normandy is the game for you.








The rules provide the following content:

Comprehensive skirmish rules, including rules for searching, patrol and stealth missions, reaction fire, mortar support, a task system for unforeseen events and persuasion rules.



Advice and rules to assist solo gamers included.



Weapon and equipment lists



Force tables to randomly generate a quick group of soldiers. Nationalities covered are British and Commonwealth, Americans, Soviets, Germans, Finland, Free French, Free Polish and Italians.



Character creation system to add that extra flavour to your campaign. Includes motivations, backgrounds and prior experience as well as a skill system.



Full featured campaign rules that link your battles together, include random events, injuries and court martials, non player characters and unforeseen circumstances.



Squad based morale system in the campaign that is influenced by your progress and success, the personality of your men and events that happen.


The rules are quick to play, use a creative dice based system to quickly resolve fire and moves through turns very quickly. The turn sequence has unexpected moments permitting players to take advantage of a situation as it develops or forcing them to react on their feet when something goes awry.
While larger forces are possible, the typical game involves only a handful of soldiers on each side, allowing you to focus on the personalities you have generated in your campaign.
Pick up games can be played quickly and efficiently as well. Simply roll up two forces, pick a mission and have a go at it.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Planetaire: The Grand Tour
description:
Planetaire is a astronomy-themed educational rummy-type card game for one to four players. This description will focus on the 2 to 4 player game, but there are also variants for one player or for 4 players on 2 teams. When playing with 2 or more people, the object of the game is to be the first player to make The Grand Tour by collecting all 9 planetary suites, including Pluto as a planet since the game was published before 2006. In case of a tie (2 or more players completing The Grand Tour in the same round), the player who completed the Grand Tour who has the most points wins. A planetary suite consists of a planet and all of its moons. For the sake of not making the sets impossible, the gas giants Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune each have 4 moons in this game. The moonless Mercury and Venus count as complete sets by themselves. The planets are categorized as inner or outer based on their position relative to the main Asteroid Belt located between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.

The game has 92 playing cards, a pad of scoring sheets, a rules booklet, and 4 reference cards, which list all the cards needed for each of the 9 suites. The set of cards are color-coded by type, and each planet is also in a different color to make it easier to see what goes together. There are 2 of each planet and the 20 moons used in this game, and 1 each of 8 asteroids and 8 comets. There are also 10 wild cards which can serve in place of other cards, 2 each of 5 different types. The two Planet X cards will substitute for planets. The other 8 wild cards can all substitute for moons, with 4 of them also being usable for an asteroid, the other 4 for a comet. There are also 8 action cards, 4 which reverse the player order and give the person playing the card an extra turn, and 4 which discard a moon card (you can either discard one yourself, or make the next player discard one before beginning their turn, which can result in some complications if they don't have any moons or moon wild cards in their hand). Action cards are played by discarding them at the end of your turn (if you choose to use the discard moon card on yourself, you get to discard that card and one of your moons, with the moon card on top in the discard pile).

During each turn, you start by drawing until you have 10 cards in your hand (at game start, you have 9). So the smaller your hand is at the beginning of your turn, the better are your chances to draw cards you need. You can then lay down any number of comets and asteroids, up to the maximum of 2 of each, but can only lay down the planet and moon cards when you have a complete set of the same color - a planetary suite, or enough wild cards to substitute for the cards you don't have. You can use any number of wild cards in making a set but cannot play 2 of the same moon in a suite - but must have 1 of each or a suitable wild card. You can also pick up wild cards or complete planetary suites if you can replace them from your hand. You don't need to replace a Wild Card in order to pick it up if it was acting as a comet or asteroid. You can use a planet you scored in a previous round, which is called Retro-Touring. Laying down a previously scored planetary suite does not earn you more points but can serve the player doing this in several ways. You end each turn by discarding a card from your hand, whether or not you laid down any cards on the table. You can not have more than 2 asteroids, 2 comets, 1 Inner Planetary Suite, and 1 Outer Planetary Suite laid down on the table at the same time. If you have all of these in front of you, you are said to "Go Out" and the round ends immediately. When one player completes all the cards to Go Out, ending the round, all the other players are then said to be Set. "Set" players are penalized for the point value of the cards in their hand. You count up the points of all the cards you laid down, with the planets and Planet X on the table being multiplied by 10, and then everyone except the player Going Out have to subtract the point value of the cards in their hand (planets are at face value for this portion of the scoring). This can result in a negative score. Most of the wild cards have a value of 0, with the exception of the 2 Planet X cards, which are worth 10. The moons, asteroids, and comets are worth 1. Action cards in the hand of a "set" player cost them two points. The planets increase in point value from 1 to 9 based on distance from the Sun (so Mercury is 1, Pluto is 9, etc). Usually one player is designated as the scorer and writes down everyone's points at the end of each round. You only score for a completed planetary suite the first time you use that particular planet.

The rulebook suggests that a different player should be dealer in each round. The Dealer rotates counter-clockwise in each round, and the players also go in this order, with the player to the right of the dealer going first. This direction is used because it corresponds with the orbits of the planets around the sun. This brings up some of the other educational aspects of this game. Each of the cards has a photograph or art of the object, and a few interesting facts about the object pictured. The Wild Cards are named after and depict other objects in the Solar System that are not in the normal cards. There is also more information and many website links of other educational resources in the rulebook.

There is a Solitaire version of the game, in which there is no point scoring or shuffling of cards within a round, the planets have to be obtained in a specific order, you deal cards and draw to a Phantom player (which are not available until you shuffle for the next round), and there are also 9 cards permanently discarded at the beginning of the game.

name: Salvage Ops
description:
A press-your-luck card game of sci-fi goodness.

You are the captain of a salvage ship. It isn't glamorous but it is profitable. The salvage of a lifetime just drifted into nearby space. Unfortunately, you're not the only salvage crew to respond. Since you all arrive at the derelict together, interstellar salvage laws apply. Within the ship are dangers and rewards alike, just waiting for you.

In this fast-paced game of risk-taking and decision-making, you and up to four additional players try to claim the most salvage from the derelict ship before its failing engines finally explode. You'll go room to room gathering up salvage and avoiding deadly hazards. Will you get out of the derelict and tuck away your acquired salvage, or press your luck against the growing threat of the deadly hazards?

This game can be played in under 30 minutes and is simple enough to be grasped by young players. Older players, however, will enjoy it even more as they weigh the odds and make their decisions.

Each player is a faction that has an immunity, and the push your luck aspect comes from flipping the top card of the deck. You can get salvage points that are evenly distributed among the players left on the ship and the left over goes to a kitty. You can also flip over a hazard, which only kills you the second time a hazard of the same type is revealed. Before you flip the next card, you have a tile that says, stay, or to back to ship. If you go back to ship, you keep the points that you have gathered and take the kitty points. If you stay, you keep going until everyone dies or leaves for their ship. There are five stages of the game. Each stage you also shuffle an artifact and a black hazard which no one is immune to into the deck. Each faction also has an artifact that will score them 20 points, whereas if you don't get your special artifact, it is only 10 points. At the end of the five stages, whoever has the most points wins.
publishers: DwD Studios, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Bumble Bees: The Nest Building Game
description:
In Bumble Bees: The Nest Building Game you are the Queen of a Bumble Bee colony racing to expand your Nest in the Spring. The only problem is you're old and dying. Will you be able to grow your Nest soon enough for a New Queen to be born, or will your colony be wiped out first?

Decide which actions to take with four unique, double sided Bees. The Queen, Worker, Nest Worker, and Drone.

Every turn Event cards are drawn that might have minor, or major effects on gameplay.

Turn you Bumble Bee nest into a resource creating factory by expanding it. You can add new chambers such as Brooding Bees, Honeypots, and Involucrum.

Each game decide where you nest came from, by picking an Origin Card, such as Rodent Nest, Hibernation Hole, or Tree Trunk.
mechanics: Hand Management, Simulation, Solo / Solitaire Game, Worker Placement

name: Vikings: The Card Game
description: In Vikings: The Card Game, 2-4 players compete to gain 'Renown' to win the game as the most famous Viking of their time. Players may earn 'renown' by exploring, raiding, and settling new lands. Players win the new lands by bidding the number of fleets they will commit to the adventure, then comparing strength totals of the fleets committed.

name: Moolers
description:
Moolers is a game where each player takes the role of a genetically modified fighter in a futuristic game where your objective is to become the best! Face several challenges and other players on thwie way to victory !!

Summarized Rules:

Each player will have one Bench, 8 traps, 1 Data Mooler, 3 Special Ability cards and 1 Scoreboard Health. The cards are shuffled, and each player receives 4 cards.

The bench has Player information, life skills and define their status, either:

Mooler, each player starts the game in this state, with all points of life; or
Controller when the player activates a Sentinel, placed his stool in this position.


The board is created by placing the various rooms in a row, until the final room is placed. The game will end after a players has reached that room. Players gain victory points for various actions; the player with the most points wins.

The game is played in turns, each consisting of the following steps:
1) Catch letters: grabs so many letters to your maximum hand
2) Move: the movement is dictated by the value you have with your state of life in the character sheet, which will increase spending power points
3) Perform up to 3 actions by playing a card from your hand:

Attacking an adjacent player
Use Special abilities.


4) Turn the wheel: Trigger a random event.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Bulwark: Tsula of the Gold Clan
description:
From publisher description:

Heroic Co-operative Deck-Building!

Runestriking is an ancient and powerful magical technique, passed down from dwarf to dwarf. It's most powerful working are jealously guarded, and some secrets have been lost to the ages when no-one worthy was found to learn them. Tsula is known as one of the most powerful living runestrikers, and she chooses to put her art to use serving the good of everyone. Many trouble-makers have made the mistake of assuming that her skills don't extend to the battlefield.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Variable Player Powers

name: Bulwark: The Princeling's Grudge
description:
From publisher description:

Heroic Co-operative Deck-Building!

Never disown a dwarf unless you want him and a couple of thousand of his mates knocking on your door with fire cannons.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Variable Player Powers

name: Bulwark: The Forbidding Fortress
description:
From publisher description:

Heroic Co-operative Deck-Building!

This recently-repopulated fortress in the deepest bowels of dwarf territory has formidable defences - but facing equally formidable armies are the stock-in-trade of heroes in Bulwark! With guards, secret tunnels and levers that pour hot lava into the ranks of the enemy, there are are lot of tools at your disposal. Its most valuable assets - the sequence of gates guarding the main causeway - would become its downfall should they be breached.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Variable Player Powers

name: Planet 313
description:
Theme - The Scientists of your world has discovered a nice planet to colonize, Planet 313. Your mission is to get your ships off of your launchpad, navigate throughout the rotating rings in the space around Planet 313, and manage a perfect landing on the planet. Ok, that sounds easy enough… except your opponents have the same orders from their worlds. Now it is a race and a battle to be the first one there with all of your ships.

Game Play & How to Win - Players blast space ships from launchpads and send them racing through the rings of space around Planet 313. Navigating and battling their way through the rings, they still need to make a perfect landing with all of their ships to claim victory.

How to make all of this happen--- Players will use 5 dice to roll on each turn. The dice will dictate how much movement the player's ship can travel, whether the rings of space get moved and which one, and finally one of the dice will give a special action that will enhance the turn with different features.

Players will also be armed with a hand of cards with special actions, modifiers for movement, modifiers for battle values, and even space ships.

The trip to planet 313 will be full of decisions for best navigation, how to win a battle you didn't want, hunting for the battles you do want, and eventful surprises along the way.
categories: Maze, Racing, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Take That
publishers: (Looking for a publisher), Roll For Surprise Games

name: Battle over the Pacific: Japan vs. United States, 1941-1942
description:
Battle over the Pacific is a complete, stand alone design that takes the Battle over Britain game system to warplanes flown by Japan and the United States in 1941-42. It is a two-player (with solitaire option) strategy game simulating plane-vs-plane dogfights occurring in the first year in the war in the Pacific after America's entry into the conflict.

Airplanes are individually rated for speed, agility, firepower, performance, and durability. All planes are compatible with all other planes in the series, so you can fly Japanese planes against British adversaries if you have Battle over Britain, for instance. Aircraft included are: American: Grumman F4F Wildcat, Curtiss P-40 Kittyhawk, Brewster F2A Buffalo, Douglas SBD-3 Dauntless, and Douglas TBD-1 Devastator. Japanese: Mitsubishi A6M2 Zero, Makajima Ki-43 Oscar, Mitsubishi A5M4 Claude, Nakajima Ki-27 Nate, Aichi D3A Val, Nakajima B5N1 Kate, and B5N2 Kate. Counters (3/4th inch square) are in color, on thick card, and must be cut apart prior to play. A new Critical Hit Vulnerability rule has been included, to take into account the fragile nature of some of the early Japanese fighters.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: FightQard
description:
Players have 100 life points. They loose points fighting with their cards making attacks, defenses and combos. The goal is to survive the fight combat.

Feel the excitement of combat in your hands

FightQard is your new entertainment that brings all the excitement, strategy, strength and surprise of the fighting to a world of cards that you can play anywhere.

Meet our complete and easy gameplay.
Ideal for those who want maximum enjoyment without complicated rules or spend the inheritance of his grandmother.
And for the advanced player that like an elaborate strategy of combat.
Generates powerful combos that can turn the balance of combat in an instant.
Aggressiveoffensive or passivedefensive? your strategy prepared by the stances.
Unblockable hits, counterattacks, fight flash and more.

name: Schollenschubser
description:
Schollenschubser is one of the games that is contained in the board game collection Die Box. It was originally announced as a stand-alone item under the name Pluff.

It is a small tactical game for in between. You are a team of Arctic explorers trying to reach your ship. Unfortunately the ice is already cracked and you need to cross floating ice sheets. Try to be the first reaching the ship with all your 4 explorers by using dice, action cards and pushing your rivals into the water.

name: The Thing from the Future
description:
From the publisher's game overview:

The object of the game is to come up with the most entertaining and thought-provoking descriptions of hypothetical objects from different near-, medium-, and long-term futures. Each round, players collectively generate a creative prompt by playing a card game. This prompt outlines the kind of future that the thing-to-be-imagined comes from, specifies what part of society or culture it belongs to, describes the type of object that it is, and suggests an emotional reaction that it might spark in an observer from the present. Players must then each write a short description of an object that fits the constraints of the prompt. These descriptions are then read aloud (without attribution), and players vote on which description they find the most interesting, provocative, or funny. The winner of each round keeps the cards put into play for that round, and whoever has the most cards when the game ends is declared the overall winner.

name: GodZ: the Genesis of Badly Dead
description:
The first expansion for GodZ, the game of creation and battles set in the world of Super Fantasy.

Introduces a new way to score points during the game, giving players more control over the scoring and the endgame systems.

Originally included in Super Fantasy: Night of the Badly Dead

name: Spinergy G-Rings: That's Amor√© and Play Ball!
description:
Two themed ring sets for the game Spinergy.

That's Amoré is a 3-ring set with words pertaining to love.

Play Ball! is a 3-ring set with words pertaining to sports.

The rings from the two sets can be mixed and matched with each other or with the rings of the base game or other expansion.

name: Duels For the Iron Staff
description:
Upon reaching his 100th birthday Head Wizard Zin has decided to step down and pass the torch, or in this case, staff. Being such an amazing instructor and father figure he has many great wizards ready to assume his position. Not wanting to show favoritism among his top pupils, he’s offered all of them a chance to face off against one another for the title.

Not only do they get the title and the coveted seat, they also get the respect that goes with being the possessor of the IRON STAFF!

In Iron Staff you will assume the role of a wizard in the Copper Claw Guild. You will also be attempting to show your magical prowess by gathering components to complete and cast spells to subdue your opponent. This is not an easy task however. The other wizards are just as skilled and cunning as you. They all have tricks and specialties up their sleeves. Each of the wizards has their own set of special abilities,variable hit points, and mastery (second ability trigger) levels.

name: Quick Backgammon
description:
Quick Backgammon is two games in one box. The first game is QuickGammon, a scaled down variant of backgammon that has fewer pieces and fewer points on the board, and uses d4 dice. Quickgammon is an introductory game to teach children and beginners the principles of backgammon.

Also included in the box is a standard backgammon board, and the game includes d6 dice and enough pieces to play the standard game.

[User summary from game box and rules.]
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Mage Wars: Leviathan Scale Armor Promo Card
description:
This promo card is given as a reward for participating on Organized play. This is part of the Menace of Runation story arc.

Leviathan Scale Armor

Equipment
Cost 6 Mana

Mage gains Armor + 2 and the Hydro - 2 trait.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Mage Wars: Sunfire Burst Promo Card
description:
This promo card is given as a reward for participating on Organized play. This is part of the Menace of Runation story arc.

Sunfire Burst

Attack (light)
Cost 5 Mana
Ranged, 2 Dice, 6-7 Daze, 8+ Daze & Burn
Ethereal, Unavoidable

+ 2 vs. Nonliving Creatures
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Cadence: Road Racing Championship
description: Cadence is a 2 player biking microgame in which players are professional cycle racers going head to head on a race circuit. Racers use their stamina, shift gears, make use of abilities like 'drafting' and 'sprinting' and strive to reach to the finish line first. The game makes use of unique mechanics like card interlocking, sliding and rotating cards, 3D like vertically folded racer cards to fit a fairly complex but tactical game in just 18 cards. The race is played on a track made up of 6 'track cards' which are either flat sections or climbs and descends of different gradients. Double sided track cards allow for a second more difficult track to be made from the backs of the cards giving replay ability to the game. There are 2 racers to chose from while they each have their own special abilities the other one does not have. You can play a big game of 3 laps or a short filler of 1 lap, so immerse yourself in the world of bike racing, micro style!
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Racing, Sports

name: Limbo
description:
After another day in the life of the young child, it's time to go to sleep. But he doesn't even imagines the existence of two mystical beings in his mind, feeding on your emotions while sleeping. One feeds on their dreams while the other feeds precisely the opposite, and therefore seeks to guide the child to the shadowy world of the most ominous and terrifying nightmares. What happens inside the confused and innocent child's mind? Only the battle between these two fantastic endless decide this. Unwary are those who think they are not plagued by such entities, they barely know that life is only a dream and we only puppets...

Limbo is a board game for 2-4 players, based on the universe created by Neil Gaiman. Players face each other for 8 rounds (the 8 hours of the child sleep), trying to influence the movement of the child in main board. For that, they should put their cards on individual boards, forming combinations of runes, skills and summoning creatures to chase the little one. Players actions must be scheduled, and the cards and creatures can be positioned in future rounds, creating a system that must be planned and thinking beyond the present moment.

name: Heaven and Hell Toroidal Checkers
description:
This is a checkers variant using an 8x8 board that is viewed as a torus: column A is adjacent to column H and row 1 is adjacent to row 8. Thus, for example, a piece on 1.a3 can move to h4.

GOAL: to be the only player with pieces on the dark squares (called "heaven," light squares are called "hell.")
