name: Whistling Captures
description:
Whistling Captures is a two player abstract strategy game played on a large hexagonal board. You win by capturing all of your opponents' pieces. You capture opponent pieces by sliding past them in an adjacent row; hence, the name "Whistling Captures."

The rules to the game can be found in a post to the Rules Forum on this page.

name: The Games: Blood and Spectacle
description:
From the publisher's web site:
The Games: Blood and Spectacle are a set of free wargames rules for gladiator games.

From the game's introduction:
Welcome to The Games: Blood and Spectacle.

In these pages you will find a game that allows you to play out the infamous blood contests between slave warriors of the Roman era. You will be a Lanista, the slave master, owner, and business man who dealt in blood and spectacle for profit. Your management and commands will lead your Gladiator troupe to glory, honor, and immortality; or death and poverty. Will you beg for mercy, or triumph for the crowds?
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Variable Player Powers

name: 4 Warlords
description:
Card game played with traditional deck of cards, with some small elements of poker.

The deck is divided in two: Red Cards & Black Cards.
One player takes all the black cards, while the other takes all red cards. They will each play with their own deck throughout the whole game - never mixing them.
Players will separate the face cards (J, Q, K) and keep them in their hands at all times. The rest are shuffled.

Both players will pick 3 cards from their own shuffled deck.
Immediately after, they will choose to play either Queen or King as their "Warlord" for that round. They will place 1 Queen or 1 King face down and reveal them at the same time.
If a player has chosen a Queen, they can (but are not obligated to) discard 1 card from their hand and take 1 new one from their deck.
If they have chosen a King, they can do this up to 3 times.
The face card is kept in front of them.

Now it's time for battle.
Each player selects a card from their hand and places it face down in front of them. They then reveal the card at the same time and lay it in front of them.
This is done until the three cards have been played.
The player with the highest ranking 'combo' wins the battle. Combos are valued similarly to poker, but only with 3 cards. Below is the ranking order:
1. 3 of a kind
2. Straight (3 numbers in consecutive order)
3. Flush (same suit)
4. 2 of a kind
5. Card (highest number)

The winning player will take the defeated player's warlord and put it aside as a trophy.
Game ends when one of the players runs out of warlords.

Players can use their Jacks to surrender in a battle. Jacks can be played instead of a number card (with the same behavior - keeping it hidden until both players reveal their card).
If a player surrenders with a Jack, he/she will lose all the number cards he/she has already laid down (not the ones in his/her hand), plus the Jack that triggered the surrender. But he/she will save their warlord.

If there is a draw during battle (or two players play a Jack), nothing happens. Players take their corresponding cards and continue to the next round.

Players must shuffle all their number cards after every round (except for the ones they have lost, of course).
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Wonderluette
description:
Wonderluette is a poker style card game that uses Aluette Card Game suits (Clubs, Coins, Cups, and Swords) and special action cards called Wonder Cards designed from Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. The game is to be played by 2 - 6 players and each round can take up to twenty minutes. The object of the game is to be the first player to get a Flush, thus winning the round.

So the story goes, after the death of the Jabberwocky the residents of Wonderland had a lot of stress off their shoulders. The game was created by the Mad Hatter to give people something to do with their newly found recreational time. With this new lack of stress, they needed something to help become stressful again, this was the answer to that dilemma. After Alice's Adventure Underground, the Hatter decided to create the game using Aluette designs, that consists of no queen cards nor the suit of hearts. He thought this best since everyone was still getting over the events, but did like the idea of the added stress. Initially the game was designed for three rounds, but that did not deem stressful enough and has been increased to five rounds. The winner of the round is simply the first to get a Flush (cards with all matching suits), the player with the most wins in the five rounds--keeps the deck. Only one deck exists in Wonderland so this was the best way to ensure everyone could own a copy.

While Lewis Carroll may not have conceptualized this game in his works, we have taken it upon ourselves to do so. The majority of the cards in the game are traditional Poker Cards, the Action Cards include imagery from the original book and the artwork in the game is originally by Arthur Rackham.

How to Play

1. Cards are shuffled and scattered in a pool in the middle of the Tabletop.
2. Each player grabs five cards from the pool.
3. During their turn a player may use a Wonder Card or Discard a Card, then draw again from the pool.
4. The object of the game is to get a flush, once someone gets a flush they win the round.
5. The best of five rounds is declared the overall winner.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Adventure, Fantasy, Novel-based, Number
mechanics: Hand Management, Stock Holding, Take That, Trading, Trick-taking

name: Amen
description:
User summary:
Amen is an abstract stone-picking game with a theme of a struggle for the king's throne in ancient Egypt.

You begin with a stone on a corner of the square-grid board. Each turn, you roll a die and extend your wall of stones by that number. When you place stones, you place the first one on a square adjacent to any one of your stones, then place each of the remaining stones adjacent to the stone you placed last. If that square, or the line of squares beyond, are occupied by opponents' stones, instead you skip these squares and place your stone on the nearest empty square beyond them. In this case, you pick up all the stones skipped over and gain victory points. But beware. When you pick up opponents' stones, you leave a gap between your walls, which is vulnerable to their counter-attack.

At the center of the board, there are large obstacles you can use as your defense, and bonus stones which can be scored like opponents' stones.

A game consists of rounds equal to the number of players, and a round ends when three minutes of real time have passed. Everything on the gameboard is held over to the next rounds, with an exception at the beginning of the final round, when the stones on four corners are removed from the board, allowing the potential of big points.

At the end of the final round, the player who has picked up the most stones wins the game.

This game comes with a sandglass to keep track of time, and an original music CD which goes well with the atomosphere of the game.

Publisher's summary:
Âè§‰ª£„Ç®„Ç∏„Éó„Éà „ÅåËàûÂè∞„ÄÇ„Ç∑„É≥„Éó„É´„Å™„É´„Éº„É´„Å®Â••Ê∑±„ÅÑ„Ç≤„Éº„É†ÊÄß„ÅåÁâπÂæ¥„ÅÆÁ†ÇÊôÇË®à„Çí‰Ωø„Å£„ÅüÊñ∞ÊÑüË¶ö„ÅÆÁü≥Âèñ„Çä„Ç≤„Éº„É†„ÄÇ„Ç™„É™„Ç∏„Éä„É´Èü≥Ê•ΩCD„ÇÇ‰ªò„ÅÑ„Å¶„Åä„Çä„ÄÅÈü≥Ê•Ω„Å®„Å®„ÇÇ„Å´„Ç≤„Éº„É†„ÇíÊ•Ω„Åó„ÇÅ„Çã„ÄÅ‰∫îÊÑü„ÅÆÈÅäÊàØ„ÄÇ„Ç≤„Éº„É†ÂÜÖÂÆπ„ÅØÊôÇË®àÂõû„Çä„Å´„Çµ„Ç§„Ç≥„É≠„ÇíÊåØ„Å£„Å¶Âá∫„ÅüÁõÆ„ÅÆÊï∞„Å†„ÅëÊåÅ„Å°Áü≥„ÇíÁõ§‰∏ä„Å´ÁΩÆ„Åç„ÄÅ‰ªñ„ÅÆ„Éó„É¨„Ç§„É§„Éº„ÅÆÁü≥„ÇíÊåü„Çì„ÅßÂèñ„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÁ†ÇÊôÇË®à„ÅÆÁ†Ç„Åå„Åô„Åπ„Å¶ËêΩ„Å°„Åç„ÇãÊôÇÈñìÔºà3ÂàÜÈñìÔºâ„Çí1„É©„Ç¶„É≥„Éâ„Å®„Åó„ÄÅË¶èÂÆö„ÅÆ„É©„Ç¶„É≥„ÉâÊï∞Ôºà2‰∫∫„Éó„É¨„Ç§„ÅÆÂ†¥ÂêàÔºù2„É©„Ç¶„É≥„Éâ„ÄÅ3‰∫∫„Éó„É¨„Ç§„ÅÆÂ†¥ÂêàÔºù3„É©„Ç¶„É≥„Éâ„ÄÅ4‰∫∫„Éó„É¨„Ç§„ÅÆÂ†¥ÂêàÔºù4„É©„Ç¶„É≥„ÉâÔºâ„ÅåÁµÇ‰∫Ü„Åô„Çã„Åæ„Åß„Å´Áü≥„Çí‰∏ÄÁï™Â§ö„ÅèÂèñ„Å£„Åü„Éó„É¨„Ç§„É§„Éº„ÅÆÂãù„Å°„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

(Using Google Translate on the above Kanji text gives us: "Ancient Egypt stage. Simple rules and deep game of a new sense of stone up game of using the hourglass features. Original music CD is also attached, you can enjoy the game along with the music, play of the five senses. Game content places the stone has only the number of eyes out by shaking the dice in a clockwise direction on the board and take on both sides of the stone of the other players. Time sand hourglass as possible fell all (3 minutes), and 1 round, (in the case of a 2-person play = 2 round, in the case of a three-person play = 3 rounds, in the case of a four-person play = 4 round) prescribed number of rounds This is the most took wins player of the stone to complete.")
categories: Abstract Strategy, Ancient, Dice, Music, Mythology, Real-time

name: Founder
description:
Founder is a table-top strategy board game that revolves around entrepreneurship. Talent management is key here. Players must decide how many and what kind of employees they need to make their business successful. Furthermore, knowing when to promote them and how to keep a balanced work force play important roles in determining the company's success.

Founder is played across 5 turns, and each turn consists of a number of phases. First, players Invest (recruit, run payroll, advertise, build factories). Second, they Produce (design products, buy resources, trade resources, manufacture). Then, they Sell (generate and fulfill demand), before Managing Talent (promote, compensate, defect). In the final turn, players Resolve (replenish resources, calculate market cap, move time marker).

In the end, the player who achieved the highest market cap will emerge victorious.

The game box will include numerous cards, a marker, pawns, cubes, paper bills and a main game board.

name: Skarb Mogorotha
description: One of the first Polish game included in young people's magazine "Swiat Mlodych" (Youths world) from 29.01.1991, no 9. Simply fantasy game based on common plot, where one player is trying to reach and find treasure chest and second one is trying to interfere with him. Players command their fantasy units, for example knights, dwarves, eagle belonging to first player, and orcs, trolls, ghost of a second player. Gameplay is high despite of ancient design and graphics.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Ostfront
description: Ostfront is H&S GAMES newest tactical infantry print-and-play project. June, 1941, as a German platoon leader you will fight your way across Russia in a tactical tour de force. Each month you will take part in engagements against a random number of Soviet squads and accumulate victory points which facilitate promotion, unit upgrades and awards. Single, tournament style engagements or one of two campaigns may be played. Designed from the ground up as a solitaire system, the game's brain is an innovative hex template that is used for unit placement. This primary system works in concert with a proven chit pull sub-system and action charts which dictate if an enemy unit moves (if so what direction) fires, or does nothing. The map is framed by a slew of information which you must keep track of including: squad action points, leader action points, sudden death track, sniper track, month track, weather, initial German deployment, expected level of enemy resistance, engagement type (three possible types), arty/air strikes, and a victory point track. The map is a generic, base map upon which terrain tiles are configured according to the given scenarios or simply your own whim! Combat is comprised of a combat results table that determines the number of step losses and subsequent pinned, suppressed or broken results. Or, you may chuck the primary combat engine for an alternative "buckets" of dice combat engine! Close combat is brutal and there are no guarantees in this game. Units will often have to roll to perform an action,and at game start, you will have to spot an enemy before you can fire at it. Finally, all of this occurs on a modest 7x9 hex grid!
mechanics: Action Points, Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Simulation

name: Devotion
description:
Play as one of the 12 gods of the Greek pantheon as you inspire your followers to build new temples and collect piety from the faithful.

Each turn players roll 5 dice to gather piety, build temples, move priests, or gather power to use special abilities. The player with the most piety collected when the end is triggered is the winner!
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Worker Placement

name: Battlefield: American Civil War edition
description:
The Battlefield 2-player card game from NewVenture Games has been popular for some time. The American Civil War edition commemorates the 150th anniversary of that great conflict, the cards being completely redesigned to depict army units, officers, and civilians from the 1860s. One player assumes the role of the Union, the other plays Confederate units, meeting on the field of battle. In skirmish after skirmish, players deploy their forces card after card, fighting gallantly for their nation's survival.

Each of the two decks contain 72 cards, from the volunteer infantry with aged muskets, to the advanced firepower of artillery and cavalry. Famous generals take to the field, supported by the Corps of Engineers, civilian support groups, and even the President may make an appearance. Hope to avoid disease and inclement weather, and hope for a prisoner exchange or timely reinforcements.

name: Many Parsecs of Space
description:
Many Parsecs of Space (working title but yes - pun intended!) is an upcoming space 4X game that reimplements Martin Wallace's innovative deck building mechanic from A Few Acres of Snow. Anyone familiar with AFAoS or Mythotopia will be playing MPoS in minutes, though it's far from a simple reskinning. MPoS takes the core mechanic in an entirely new direction by introducing exploration and trade in a multi-player science fiction setting. Location (world) cards are variable and hidden at setup and revealed only when explored. This is not only thematic, but creates infinite replayability and solves the dominant strategy issues (ex. Halifax's Hammer) that can plague low luck games with a static setup. Trading with your neighbor is essential because nearby star systems may lack the resources you need to expand your empire.

GAME FEATURES:

Unique sentient races for asymmetrical play.
Secretly customize your race beforehand so other players won't know what they're up against until first contact!
Choose a government and economy that allows you to discard, reserve, and remove cards according to your playing style.
A world suitable for your race to colonize may not be for your neighbor. One race's garbage is another race's treasure!
Technology cards function like empire cards from AFAoS but with the added wrinkle of a tech tree.
Steal resources and technology from your neighbor or trade partner with piracy and espionage.
5 scarce resources (energy, metals, military, organics, and science) must be acquired so trading is a MUST to efficiently grow your empire.
Discover ancient artifacts on dead planets and worm holes that connect distant star systems.
Terraform tide locked worlds to make them suitable for colonization.
Invade an outpost or colony to make it your own or NUKE it so nobody can colonize it!
categories: Card Game, Exploration, Negotiation, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Territory Building, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement, Trading, Variable Player Powers

name: Legacy: Time Surge
description:
A lightweight, 2-player game of Time Travel and Technology.

Players draft technology cards each round to keep them to use as influence, or to bid on later in the round.

Players then travel back in time, bidding their influence on establishing technologies to buildup the timeline.

Players return to the present day to draft new techs, and build off the old ones, carefully selecting technologies that benefit them the most.

At the end of the third round players gain victory points for techs they influenced, and dependency bonuses are paid out to the owner of supporting technologies. The player with the highest victory point total is the winner.

name: Kosmoteka 3+1
description:
This is compilation of 3 games + puzzle.

Star trails is a simple game for younger players. While playing children can learn about the solar system. The task to orbit the solar system with space shuttle and make photos of planets and asteroids.
Points are collected in two ways. The first way by reaching finish line (first gets 12 points, second 10, third 8 ...). Another way is to collect counters. Each counter brings 1 point. The winner is the player who ends up with the most points.

Flying saucers:
Figurines represent different categories of flying saucers, which differ in speed, size and power. Flying saucers destroy enemy saucers by stopping next to it. Flying saucer with more power, or joined multiple saucers can destroy enemy flying saucer. The goal of the game is to destroy the main enemy flying saucer.

Svemirska patrola:
Rude Martians come to the Moon, but they don't respect traffic rules. Space patrol from the Earth comes to charge fines.
Players move figurines and collect counters by stopping on the field next to counter. The winner is the player who collects the most counters.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Children's Game, Collectible Components, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Point to Point Movement

name: Operation: Dandelion
description:
It is the final stage of the 9th five-year plan and the oblast Odusad is still behind the expectations of the State Committee for Agriculture. After poor harvests in the prior years things finally look better and the comrades are looking forward to a bountiful harvest. The pumpkins are tall as tractor wheels and the flowers smell sweeter than ever. If only those pesky weeds will not spoil everything. The head of the Kolkhoz “Druzhba” has proclaimed the “Operation: Dandelion” in order to get rid of the weeds before they completely take over the farm.
All the comrades will have to work together if they want to save the harvest and fulfill the five-year plan. It will be challenging, but it can be done!

Operation: Dandelion is a light-weight cooperative family board game.
It is played over 5 rounds. During each round additional weed tokens will be placed onto the Farm Tiles while the players will move around and clear the fields from these weeds. They have only a limited number of actions available and as the game progresses it becomes more and more challenging to keep the weeds under control. Farm Tiles can be overgrown, the oblast government might send additional support and the players can work overtime – but will it be enough?
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Farming, Humor, Memory
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Grid Movement, Memory, Modular Board

name: DOJO game
description:
Defeat your friends to win honor become Master of the DOJO! Choose a fighting style, build your character, and crush the competition!

Dojo is a fast paced, martial arts, card-drafting, character building contest of smashing your friends and trying to earn HONOR from the MASTERS of the DOJO. Choose a Fighting Style with unique abilities and advance down the Fire or Water path.
The MASTERS of the DOJO watch over training, and if you please them, they may award you Honor. MASTERS may want you to build up your strength, and others prefer tricks!

Training Phase: Do Drills to improve your basic stats; Strength, Dexterity, and Chi. Study Techniques, which can be used multiple times during combat but expend your energy. You may also plan Tricks which are one time use and will likely catch your opponents off-guard.

Sparring Phase: Use the tricks, techniques, and drills that you've learned to take on your opponents in head-to-head or group combat. You can additionally use the abilities granted by your Fighting Style.

When Sparring begins, the combatants "Size-Up" each other, betting energy to see who will get the first strike.

Every opponent you knock out will earn you Honor and bring you one step closer to becoming MASTER OF THE DOJO!

name: The Trials of Idavare
description:
The Trials of Idavare is a card-based party game for 9–27 players. Join a fierce battle of truth and deception, a battle of conviction that threatens your very life. As your faction struggles to claim Idavare, well-chosen words are more precious than any card dealt, and a single misstep can mean certain death. Victory depends on your ability to debate, lie, reason, and – should the night call you – move silently...

In The Trials of Idavare, every player secretly receives a faction card and a skill card. At night, the evil, sneaky werewolves transform into beast form and take a villager's life. During the day, the villagers must determine who is a creature of the night and hang them before the last one of the innocent is inside a werewolf's belly. Besides their senses and wits, some villagers have useful skills at their disposal that might help in battle – just pray the skill is not used by a werewolf...
mechanics: Deduction, Hidden Roles, Negotiation, Variable Player Powers

name: Malifaux: Salvage and Logistics ‚Äì Leveticus Box Set
description: Leveticus likes undead and he likes constructs. He likes making things decay. As things decay they become undead constructs. When he has enough undead constructs he makes BIG undead constructs. When your opponent kills that big undead construct, it makes little undead constructs. Planning on killing Leveticus? Better make a good plan because he'll come back at full health if you've left his Waifs alive.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Horror, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Sea Chess
description:
A chess-like game between opposing navies. Each player receives 16 pieces which are arranged in opposite corners: 1 FLAGSHIP: moves one space orthogonally, cannot attack or be used in custodial capture. Is captured by advancement (must move in straight line towards it and stop on space before it). All other pieces can move any number of spaces horizontally or vertically.

1 AIRCRAFT CARRIER: can only be captured by custodial capture (sandwiching an enemy piece between yours and another).
2 BATTLESHIPS: can only be captured by cannonade (your piece must be separated from it by another piece [not an unoccupied space] so that it can jump over it and land on the battleship).

4 CRUISERS: can only be captured by withdrawal (your piece must move away from it in a straight line).
4 DESTROYERS: can only be captured by leaping (your piece must pass over it to an empty space behind).
4 SUBMARINES: can only be captured by displacement (landing on it); can also move underneath a piece to empty space behind (but cannot attack while doing so).

GOAL: to capture your opponent's flagship.

name: Chattanooga: The Civil War Game
description:
Civil War Game based on the campaign for Chattanooga. Published 1978, Chattanooga, TN by T&M Enterprises.

From the instructions:

"The object of the game is to strategically move your unit pieces into a position which would defeat your opponent within 63 days (21 turns)"

name: Abriss
description:
Abriss is a fast and tactical game that deals not once again with the construction of buildings but with the consequences – DEMOLISH buildings. Therefore, at the beginning of the game all 25 buildings are laid out on the table, ready to be torn down and blown up. Of course, this work is not done by itself but you need trustworthy workers like Slobodan, Leonid or Hao Wech. During each game round each player buys one of these at an auction, and thus equipped with the required devices they can demolish a building, provided the following conditions are met: the player is able to get rid of the construction waste (legally or illegally – the main point is: away with it!) and there are sufficient vacant spaces next to the building. Of course the nuclear power plant in the heart of the city is harder to break into pieces than the hot-dog stand just next to the city limits sign. This edition introduces the bureaucrats. They can be useful with their special permits if once and again there is not enough space to demolish a building. A successful demolition results in a demolition award for the player and they keep the tile for scoring at the end of the game. Who would not like to blow the revenue office to pieces and thus earn a little tax refund? That way the buildings vanish one after the other until there are only 2 or less left standing. The player who has demolished the most valuable buildings is the winner of the game.

Abriss takes about 45 minutes to play, the game mechanism is easy to understand and there is little downtime. The auction of subcontractors and bureaucrats provides interaction and is kept simple - there are only 3 possible bids. With the random set-up, each game offers a new challenge for the players.

The new edition includes bureaucrats and the expansion ABRISS-AUFTRÄGE/DEMOLITION-CONTRACTS.

name: Berlin Airlift
description:
In April of 1948 soviet forces halted the supply of Berlin in the British zone then went on to block land routes in the American zone. This was easy to do since Berlin itself lay deep in the Russian zone. Two million civilians dependent on allied supply watched delivery slow to a trickle. Requiring a daily minimum of 5000 tons of food, fuel, and other necessities, Berliners began dipping into their reserves. American officials estimated they would run out of fuel in 45 days but would run out of food long before that.
The Allies faced a difficult decision. Abandoning the city would be a huge loss of face that could lead to the eventual loss of all of Germany to the communist bloc. On the other hand, with all land routes into Berlin cut the city could only be supplied by air, and was such a thing even possible? The Soviets didn't think so. When the blockade commenced, Americans were only capable of delivering 300 tons of supply a day. Together with the British who could manage 400 daily tons. Officials admitted the tonnage still fell woefully short.

Supplying a major city by air for an indefinite amount of time? Nothing approaching it had ever been attempted. Despite the overwhelming odds, the Allies determined to give it a go. Veteran pilots and aircrews were recalled as disbanded cargo units were refitted and flown back to Europe. The effort was massive... no, it was beyond massive, nevertheless, Stalin was certain the operation would fail. His determined opponents proved him wrong. This Herculean effort is remembered as the West's most selfless accomplishment.

Over the course of 12 months the airlift provided 2,225,510 tons of cargo for the city's survival. At one point an airlift plane was lifting off every four minutes. In the end, more supply was provided to Berlin by air than could have been provided by rail. The Soviets did not stand passively by. There were 726 recorded instances of Soviet harassment involving everything from aerial buzzing, and ground fire to rockets, chemicals, smoke and balloons. In the course of the airlift 25 aircraft were lost, costing the lives of over 100 American, British and German personnel. And during the course of the airlift, many curious and heartwarming incidents enhanced the legend of their effort, including the candy bomber, the tour of Clarence the camel and the Easter Parade.

The Berlin Airlift is a historical treasure begging to be gamed and here we attempt to fit the bill. But a game is only as enjoyable as the conflict it portrays. The game pits players against each other in a race against the clock. Can players overcome accidents, miscommunication and soviet interference to achieve their goals? Who can deliver the most tonnage, and will it be enough for Berliners to survive? Naturally, Berlin Airlift is only representative of the larger enterprise, but in it, players will enjoy tense competition as they face all of the elements these brave allied aircrews faced when the war ended and - the blockade began.

Players will command either a British or American air squadron. Each squadron consists of up to three flights depending upon the number of people playing. Each flight contains from 3 to 5 period aircraft depending upon the scenario and the faction being played. Individual planes have a rated capacity and in some cases are restricted to carrying fuel. The object for each player is to attempt to carry his squadron's tonnage goals in fuel, food, medicine and spare parts into the city and carry refugees and finished products out (cargo is represented by colored cubes). Each turn the ACTIVE player rolls two dice, consults either the Personality chart, the Help & Hindrance or the Soviet Harassment Chart to determine effects, then begins drawing flight chits to determine who moves when. Strategy enters into the Active player's assignment of problems, decision making as to what to carry and who to fix, what base to return to and how to block opponents from reaching their goals. Oh, but players must be careful, for there is a cooperative aspect to the game. Players have to keep up the Berliner Morale for if it remains in the negative range after the final flight has delivered its cargo Berlin loses and so do all players.
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Simulation

name: Black Rabbit Dice
description:
Black Rabbit Dice are a set of story telling dice to help children and adults tell fun stories and stretch their creativity and brains while encouraging mental growth.

The set consists of 16 wooden six-sided dice with different pictures laser etched on all their faces. One in particular is a Black Rabbit, which is where they get their name from.

The producer of the dice has five different rulesets for the dice in order to play a variety of games with them. They also encourage you to come up with your own games to play with them to make them your own.

The rule sets are:

1. Pass. Where the players roll one of the die and they have to incorporate the image rolled into the ever growing story of the group.
2. Vacation. Which is a memory game where each player rolls a die from their pool and says what they saw on vacation based on what is on the die. Each player does this but has to remember what each previous thing rolled was. Failing to remember a previous roll forces you to give a die to your opponent. The last person with dice wins.
3. Story telling. A fake it until you make it game. You roll a number of the die and make a story with all the images rolled, trying to tell a coherent story.
4. Compound. Where you roll two dice and then you have to come up with a compound word related to the two die rolls.
5. Synonyms. A game where you roll a number of dice and then pick two dice to make a synonym based on those two dice. You score points every time you successfully come up with a synonym. Play to a agreed score or a number of rounds.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Memory, Word Game
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Memory, Pattern Recognition, Storytelling

name: Singularity Sky
description:
Singularity Sky is a sci-fi adventure game of exploration, trading and combat set in the universe of the same name, as depicted in the novels by Charles Stross, Singularity Sky and Iron Sunrise.

Players take on the roles of undercover spies and travel the Galaxy as merchants, trading goods to earn money, completing missions for the big factions, battling enemies or other players and exploring the uncharted corners of the Universe. Being successful in your ventures is rewarded with money, reputation and victory points.

The game is played over rounds, until one player wins, with each round being divided into 5 phases - Navigation, Movement, Action, Business and Recovery. During the Navigation phase, players secretly and simultaneously choose their actions for the rest of the round, then they resolve them, either one by one or simultaneously.

Singularity Sky is a victory points sandbox, where the first player meeting the victory conditions is the winner. The victory conditions vary depending on the chosen scenario. With multiple ways to win and a galaxy that changes every time you play. Singularity Sky offers a high level of replayability that will have you coming back for more.

—description from the publisher
categories: Fighting, Novel-based, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Transportation
mechanics: Modular Board, Negotiation, Pick-up and Deliver, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection, Solo / Solitaire Game, Variable Set-up

name: Das L√ºneburg-Spiel
description: German roll and move game based in the city of Lüneburg.

name: Goblinade
description:
You are a goblin entrepreneur who has just opened your very own drink stand - but you are not the only game in town! Fill your stockroom with ingredients to make the drinks customers crave, all the while scheming to destroy the competition. Do you have what it takes to thrive, or will you fall to your rivals' cunning? Find out in Goblinade!

Goblinade is a 2-4 player card game in which players collect ingredient cards in order to stock their "pantry". Customer cards lie face up in the center of the table, each with a list of ingredients. When a player has the ingredients listed on the customer card they may collect that customer. Each customer has a point value ranging from 1 to 3.

During the game players may steal use action and reaction cards to steal ingredients or customers and sabotage other players.
Players may choose to play to a set point value (suggested 7 points) or play until all customer cards have been collected, at which time players get one more turn. Whomever has the most points wins the game.

name: Long Island (fan expansion for Age of Steam)
description:
With a census-estimated population of 7.8M in 2014, Long Island is the most populated island in any U.S. state or territory. It is also the longest and largest island in the contiguous United States extending 118 miles from New York Harbor to Montauk Point. However, it's maximum north-south distance is only 23 miles.

The Long Island Rail Road (LIRR) is the busiest commuter railroad system in North America, carrying an average of 338K passengers each weekday. Chartered in 1834, it is also the oldest railroad still operating under its original name. It is also the only railroad that operates 24/7 with significant off peak, weekend and holiday service.

In Age of Steam: Long Island, players will be climbing all over each other as they struggle to be the first to get passengers to their destinations.

Significant differences:


Designed for 2-3 players, w/ few cubes and a lot of opportunities for blocking.
Each round, each player can deliver at most one passenger East and one passenger West.
Once-around auction for player order.
Locomotive/Urbanization alternate being available with only 1 (two-player) or 2 (three-player) other actions being available at all.
The Early Riser action (three-player only) bundles First Build, First Move, and Locomotive into one but restricts the player to one delivery.
categories: Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Trains, Transportation
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Network and Route Building, Pick-up and Deliver, Tile Placement

name: W≈≠ X√≠ng
description:
W≈≠ Xíng is a family friendly hand management game where players attempt to gain 15 points in each of the five elements of the Tao.

Players use the creation power of the elements during the creation phase in order to eliminate all cards from their hand. Once a player is able to discard all of their cards the destruction phase begins.

During the destruction phase all players that still have cards work together to destroy as many of the remaining cards as they can.

Once all possible destructions are made, the winner of the hand is given the points for the remaining cards, and a new hand is played.

name: The Ferrymen
description:
The Ferrymen is set in the Ancient Greek underworld. Players take the part of ferrymen carrying souls of the dead across the river Acheron to the Gates of Hades. A player's turn consists of two phases – the Souls of the Dead Phase and the Ferry Phase. During the Souls of the Dead Phase, players move souls along the Path of the Dead toward docked ferries. During the Ferry Phase, players move their ferries along the river Acheron.

Different souls (Lovers, Families, Spartans, Merchants, etc.) have different movement rates, restrictions, special abilities and delivery fares. Players vie to maneuver beneficial combinations of souls onto their ferry and detrimental combinations onto their opponents' ferries.

The monsters Cetus (a many-tentacled river horror), and Cerberus (guardian of the Gates of Hades) pose a hazard to players. Three random Gods & Goddesses are in play each game. Players who sacrifice the most bulls to a God or Goddess receive their favor; players who sacrifice the fewest bulls receive their wrath. Favor is generally beneficial and wrath is generally harmful. Effects vary by God or Goddess and have a large impact on gameplay. A key component of strategy is that nearly any positive effect can be negative in some circumstances and vice versa. For example, an upgraded ferry is larger than the default ferry, but may take more turns to load.

A player wins the game when they deliver nine souls to the Gates of Hades or accumulate 30 coins worth of money.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement

name: Werewolf Game
description:
„ÄåÊØéÊó•2‰∫∫„ÄÅÊ≠ª„Å¨„Ç≤„Éº„É†„Äç

Game 1: The original Werewolf played with a narrator.

Game 2: For 4-6 players and removes the need of a narrator; everyone plays. Each player has two cards in front of them which could make them either a werewolf or villager. Each night the werewolf kills a player by turning one of their cards face up. Each day the players each have one vote token for each of their two hidden cards. The card with the most vote tokens is killed by revealing.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Horror, Party Game
mechanics: Deduction, Memory, Player Elimination, Role Playing, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Game Over: Remix
description:
Game Over: Remix is the sequel to last year's successfully funded Game Over. It's a card game that mixes fast paced battles with dozens of video game inspired characters and items. Accommodating 2 - 6 players, rounds last 30 minutes each with gameplay specifically designed around replay value. The 198 card game is a mix between random chance and thought provoking strategy.

Game protagonists are simple creatures. They're programmed to either kill, collect points, or find treasure. So when the TV goes OFF and they're left to their own devices, they continue trying to do just that. The characters refer to these achievements simply as "Wins", and their thirst for them is insatiable. In Game Over, each player will take control of three characters to compete for a win in 1 of 3 ways.


Last Man Standing: Player's are knocked out of the game once all 3 of their characters have died. Be the last to survive for this win scenario.
High Score: Gems can be collected throughout the game for bonus points. Be the first to accumulate 25 or more points to win this way.
Quest Complete: There are 3 enchanted golden items hiding within the deck. The first player to find all of them has completed their quest and won the game.

name: El Presidente
description:
El Presidente is a game for 2 - 6 players all trying to become the next leader of the small banana republic of Savatori

This is achieved by taking on the role of one of the islands 6 people of note, campaigning around the island, rallying supporters at a variety of locations, employing agents to ensure you've the best entourage, delivering speeches and backstabbing the competition while all the time ensuring you have the longest and shiniest limo!

At the end of the game, the candidate with the highest accumulated popularity is made the next El Presidente!

Will you sink into political obscurity, or will you lead the tiny banana republic into it's glorious future?
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection, Trading, Variable Phase Order

name: Blindes Huhn: Maus & Habicht
description:
Blindes Huhn: Maus & Habicht adds mice and hawk cards to the Blindes Huhn base game, along with job cards that — if completed — provide as many points at the end of the game as the number of players who contributed.

The expansion brings two options which can be implemented to the base game independent from each other, but can be added to the game both together too right from the beginning.
Mice and Hawks: Take a mouse for every chicken card you acquire during the auction phase showing a mouse. Take a hawk for every hawk on a chicken card you get during an auction (not in case of payment by another player). At the end of the game, every hawk eats a mouse (and a blind hen, if there is no mouse in your display) and every surviving mouse eats a corn.
Mission/Job cards: draw randomly two or three of these cards and keep them secret from the other players. When scoring, prove that you have met the requirements of your mission cards and earn additional points. Missions are different, for example collect a minimum of specific cards (value 1, 2, 3 or 4) or a sequence in a common color (green 1-2-3-4).

name: Blindes Huhn: Doppelkorn
description: Blindes Huhn: Doppelkorn adds double grain cards to the Blindes Huhn base game. The four "Doppelkorn" cards replace 6 of the regular Golden Corn cards in the deck. During the end of game scoring, a "Doppelkorn" without Blind Hen does not have any effect. Accompanied by one or two Blind Hens the "Doppelkorn" scores +2 or even +4 points. The according Blind Hens score positive points as usual.

name: Blindes Huhn: Farb-Mehrheiten
description: Blindes Huhn: Farb-Mehrheiten is a mini-expansion for Blindes Huhn that consists of five colored chickens used to mark majorities for additional points at the end of the game.

name: Blindes Huhn: Viehdoktor
description:
Blindes Huhn: Viehdoktor adds two veterinarian cards to the Blindes Huhn base game. You can use a veterinarian to heal a Blind Hen. Discard the Blind Hen and add the veterinarian card to your display as a chicken card with value 2 of any color. If you do not use the veterinarian until the game ends you gain no benefit. You may only use the veterinarian for a Blind Hen immediately after the auction where you got this Blind Hen.
Essen 2015 add-on.

name: Blindes Huhn: Fr√ºher Vogel
description: Blindes Huhn: Früher Vogel adds "first blind hen" and "first grain" pieces to the Blindes Huhn base game that can be used as an additional blind hen or grain in the final scoring for more victory points.

name: 18SW
description:
18 Somewhere

A kinder, gentler 18XX designed for to play well with 2 - 4 players and with new 18XX players in mind.

1. Rusting is replaced with maintenance.
2. The inability to rust or scrap your last train combined with restrictions on train selling between companies makes company dumps not particularly painful.
3. Companies with special powers gives a euro-y feel to it.

However, so that it's also interesting to experienced 18XXers,

1. There are 3 levels of play, basic, advanced, and full.
2. The advanced level adds player controlled 2-, 5-, and 10-share companies twisting the availability of shares and the benefits of lots of early cash. It also adds an auction for starting companies which evens out the initial priority.
3. The full game adds bonds (basically loans from players to companies). Bonds do not count against the certificate limit giving early cash an added benefit and giving companies another way to raise money.
4. Although, in theory, train maintenance reduces the stress of the train rush, limiting the number of all trains (including the biggest brown trains) means the late train rush is brutal, often going from the first brown train to the last in less than one OR.

Replayability and scaling by player count is also covered:

1. Although the basic map is static, 4 of the 7 big dollar city locations vary from game to game. In addition, players choose their starting city when they start their RR. All this changes optimal routes from game to game.
2. The size of the map and the tile count scales by the number of players. This also changes which big dollar cities and which RRs are included from game to game.

Play time:
The game is designed to be from 90 - 180 minutes although it needs repeated plays to achieve.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Stock Holding

name: Bolt Action: Germany Strikes! ‚Äì Early War in Europe
description:
In 1939, Germany shattered the peace of Europe with a lightning-fast strike against Poland. The next year, it captured Denmark and Norway, before launching its famous Blitzkrieg against France, Belgium and The Netherlands. In less than two years of fighting, Nazi Germany became the master of mainland Europe.

This new Theatre Book for Bolt Action allows players to command armies of German tanks driving across the continent or to lead the desperate defense of the outgunned Allied armies. New scenarios, special rules and units give players everything they need to recreate the devastating battles and campaigns of the early war in Europe, including the fall of Poland, the breaking of the Maginot Line and the dramatic retreat to Dunkirk.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: BattleCON: Prince Elien Promo
description: A cross game promotional character from Plaid Hat Games' Summoner Wars, Prince Elien is a tactical fighter who does battle by summoning and moving around a wall marker which both protects him from his opponent's attacks and also allows him to launch certain attacks of his own from its position. With a number of ways to place a literal wall of protection between him and his enemy and to safely attack them from behind cover, Prince Elien is a defensive force to be reckoned with.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting
mechanics: Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Bulwark: Extra Wounds
description:
This deck of alternative Wounds can be used to add variety to your Bulwark games. Simply use this deck in place of the original Wounds, or shuffle together with them and use a random selection of 30.

These extra Wounds also give you the components you need to have two groups playing Bulwark at the same time without needing an additional base set.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Mastery: Become a Hero
description:
"A smell of blood, fire and electricity roams the dark and moist corridors. An epic battle is taking place! The mighty wizard lifts his staff, looking down on his fallen Warrior – we have a new fighter, a new hero, a new Master!"

Mastery: Become a Hero is a fantasy adventure card game that combines the dynamics of a three-dimensional board game with the strategy, speed and excitement of simultaneous battles.

In this world, you are an adventurer seeking fame and riches. In this first version of the game, you will have a warrior and a magician. Later, there will be several classes added to the game. When choosing your class, chose the one that most represents you as a character. Each class has its own completely unique combat style, that has some vital statistics which will influence the performance during battle.

Cards are the key element in Mastery: Become a Hero. Careful selection of the cards when constructing your deck will allow you to create complex and devastating strategies. Mastery cards belong to three types/categories:

1. Actions and Magic: these are the cards used to construct your deck, they characterize your characters combat style and skill.
2. Objects: treasures that you will collect through out Mastery – become a hero. They influence your combat strategies but you cannot include them in your deck: they are placed, face down, beside the game table.
3. Equipment: weapons and armor. They have special effects which influence your strategies. As with Objects, they cannot be part of your deck: they are instead placed, face up, beside the game table.

Each match round takes place through five simultaneous phases; Turn's beginning › Card drawing › Movement › Combat › Turn's End. You have to choose you cards for the whole combat round in advance and your cannot change any cards after the round has started. In the world of Mastery, the deck is representing your character profile. Constructing your character profile is here summarized within these three rules:

1. The character profile must be formed by no less than 30 cards and no more than 50.
2. You can only include cards marked with the class your character belongs to (exceptions are possible on some game variations).
3. Object and Equipment cards should not be part of your deck. But you can choose and bring with you to a match 2 object cards, placed down beside the board. You can freely select Equipment cards as long as the total number of occupancy (parameter written on the Equipment card) for all the equipment chosen is equal to or less than 5.

The combat rounds continue until either of the champions has fallen and the winner has become a hero!
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Grid Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Mages of Ebenor
description:
"Fight monsters to impress the King and become a Knighted Royal Mage of Ebenor!"

Brief feel of gameplay
Players use Mana cards and optional character abilities to fight a shared field of monsters in a way requiring light, but engaging strategy and careful observation of their opponents situation.

Mechanical overview
The structure of the game is for players to balance the value of cards they place down below monsters, in order to draw new cards and gain either their cards or the monsters themselves as 'prestige' (points) over multiple rounds until there are no monsters left or any player has run out of cards.

name: Vocadingo
description:
4 aliens disembark from their spaceship to study our language.

Gameplay: 200 words with their definitions, anagrams and riddles.

Give the right answers and win the most of vocabulary words.

A comical game to enrich the vocabulary of kindergardeners all the way to adults!

name: Flying Saucers Junior
description:
Flying Saucers Junior is simpler version of the game Flying Saucers. It has less fields on the board and only first level of Flying Saucers, with less figurines.

Figurines represent different categories of flying saucers, which differ in speed, size and power. Flying saucers destroy enemy saucers by stopping next to it. Flying saucer with more power, or joined multiple saucers can destroy enemy flying saucer. The goal of the game is to destroy the main enemy flying saucer.

The game can be played with dice or without it.

name: Eaten by Zombies!: Burn it down!
description:
The long awaited expansion to the hit Zombie deck builder Eaten by Zombies! The Zombies aren't the only thing returning from the grave!

This new expansion builds upon the Fuel mechanic that was introduced in the Weapons of Mass Destruction mini set. With a new Starting card (Fuel Can), now you always have fuel for your Chainsaw. With the Oil Lamp, Fire Starter you can burn your way through the Zombie Horde. Take a quick swig of the Old Jack Rye #1 for a pick-me up or just smash one of the those undead zombies in the face! You can't pass up a good hiding place even if it is under a car, or just push a zombie down there they don't climb very well. Or get the rest of the survivors to help you out and give them the order to "Fire!" everything they've got at the horde!

With the changing of the guard there are 2 new zombie sets. -The first zombies hate the world of man and they not only try to eat your face, but they will destroy any equipment they come across dwindling the already scarce Swag Piles. And the new fearsome zombies will scare the Stuff right out of your backpack! Forcing every player to discard cards from their hands and redraw, bringing even more zombies into your hand.

now on Kickstarter: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/gingeralegames/eaten-by...
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Horror, Zombies
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting

name: Wasteland Justice
description:
Wasteland Justice is a tactical board game for 2-4 players. Players choose their drivers for their collection of vehicles and then race their opponents. Vehicles are outfitted with various modifications and deadly weapons all at the discretion of the player.

Players take turns to move their team of vehicles and engage their opponents until there is either one team left with at least one unwrecked vehicle or a player crosses the finish line. The winner being the first player to complete the course, alive, or be the “last team standing." There is no second place in this Wasteland.

name: ATS Core Module: All American II ‚Äì Stand at Amfreville 1944
description:
From the publisher's website:

All American II - Stand at Amfreville 1944: A brand new take on the battle at Timmes' Orchard. The all new map for makes clear, the 82nd’s 6th June drop was into very dense terrain, where relatively little armored opposition was expected, and any armor present would be hampered by the bocage. MAP IS ALL NEW AND LINKS TO KELLAM'S BRIDGE CORE MODULE MAP!

Welcome to the ATS CORE MODULES, all new for 2014. New map, larger, on cardstock, folding with no trimming needed -- did we mention new terrain art throughout AND larger hexes? Perfect for those classic -- YET ALL NEW ATS COUNTERS -- the you'll have on the map deciding history ... all ... over ... again! This module is for owners of the ATS 2014 Color Rules plus ATS Standard Small Markers + Large Markers but may also be used easily by owners of any past edition of the ATS rules. All Special Rules and AFV Cards needed for play are included, along with ALL NEW FOLIO STYLE packaging.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Baiting the Bear: The 1942 Soviet Kharkov Offensive
description:
Baiting the Bear: The 1942 Soviet Kharkov Offensive, depicts the May 1942 offensive by Soviet forces under the command of Marshal Semyon Timoshenko against the German 6th Army. After initial promising signs, the offensive was stopped by German counterattacks. Critical errors by several staff officers and by Joseph Stalin, who failed to accurately estimate the 6th Army's potential and overestimated their own newly trained forces, led to a German pincer attack which cut off advancing Soviet troops from the rest of the front. The operation caused almost 300,000 Soviet casualties compared to just 20,000 for the Germans and their allies.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 1 day
Hex: 4 miles / 6.4 kilometers
Units: Battalion to Army

Game Inventory:
Two 11x17" full color map
Two dual-side printed un-mounted countersheet (260 1/2" counters)(mounted counters are optional)
One 6-page rulebook
One Player Aid Chart
Eight pages of 64 Event Cards

Player Provided: One 6-sided die

Solitaire Playability: Medium
Complexity Level: Low
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 1.5 to 2 hours

name: Victory by Any Means Campaign Guide (Second Edition): With a Purpose
description:
With a Purpose is the next supplement book for the modular Victory By Any Means campaign system with a focus on objectives and goals. Campaigns have a tendency to focus on goals and exclude the story element. This expansion has a more granular scope, focusing on a commodore instead of a supreme commander. Instead of an open ended campaign, players are working to achieve victory points.

This is done by defining the major objectives given to the players from their central government. Additionally, players will receive high priority missions that need to be completed. Campaign Moderators will have more freedom to explore the motivations of an empire, becoming a true 5x game (eXpand, eXploit, eXterminate, eXplore, and eXplain). With A Purpose supports a number of players and team play for those players who wish to try cooperative campaign games.

Since players represent low level commanders than a typical Victory by Any Means campaign, the scope of the degree is altered. Campaign turns represent shorter periods of time and each ship and ground unit is all the more precious to pull off the work given from their central command. The area will simply have more territory to explore as these campaigns include more minor systems that may exist between all the important campaign worlds in a normal game. Players must be ever vigilant of their actions and careful to control the amount of tension in the region.
categories: Civilization, Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Negotiation, Science Fiction

name: EcoChains: Arctic Crisis
description:
EcoChains is a multiplayer card game about climate change -- life and the struggle for survival in a rapidly warming Arctic. Players build food chains as they learn about Arctic ecosystems and how humans impact the environment (e.g. how carbon pollution and diminishing sea ice can impact Arctic species). The game was produced by Jogolabs and designed by a team of environmental scientists, educators and game designers.

Gameplay is simple: Sea Ice cards form the base of each player's food web. Each player builds food chains by connecting various Arctic species cards including polar bear, walrus, ringed seal and narwhal. Event cards such as carbon pollution occur, which melt sea ice and cause some animals to migrate or die. Players can also play Action cards in order to help protect their food chains. The player who keeps the most animals alive wins. Goal cards also provide additional Victory points.

http://www.ecochainsgame.com

name: JumPico
description:
User Summary:
This is a competitive Sugoroku (Japanese type of Parcheesi) game in which players move 4 of their own pieces from their side to their opponent's side. JumPico is characterized by the fact that players advance their pieces while blocking the movement of their opponent's pieces, as in Backgammon. The first player to move 4 of his pieces to his opponent's side wins the game. Passing is prohibited, so a player with no legal moves automatically loses. Blank pieces can always be used with no risk as they always move one space and are thus key to creating a winning strategy.

Publisher's summary:
