name: Hawai'i-opoly
description: Hawai'i-opoly allows you to collect your favorite Hawaiian properties and increase the rent by adding Waves and trading them in for Islands. We're talking beaches, canyons, and even Loco Moco. It's all fun and games... until someone gives you the Stink Eye and you're out of the game for three turns!
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Middle Creek: Folio Series No. 6
description:
In a fight that largely determined the fate of eastern Kentucky, two small armies clashed along the swollen tributary of Middle Creek. An officer of some promise, Humphrey Marshall, generaled the CSA. A relative unknown commanded the USA by the name of James A. Garfield.

At the end of the day, Marshall had no choice but to withdrawal. His supplies were thin and he was fearful of his army deserting. The battle unmade his reputation and he was barely heard from again. The Federals, conversely, celebrated a victory. Colonel Garfield earned a brigadiers star, and took the first step along the road that eventually led to the White House.

Contents:
1 28-Page Rules Book
1 4-Page Exclusive Rules Book
1 12-page Examples of Play and Glossary/Index
140 half-inch full-color, die-cut counters
1 22x17 Map/Playing Surface
Charts and Tables

About the Rebel Yell! system

Rebel Yell! is a simulation of American Civil War small-unit tactics. The playing pieces in the game represent companies of infantry and cavalry or sections of artillery Each infantry and cavalry unit has one strength point and is equivalent to between 45 and 100 men, depending upon the scenario. Each artillery unit has two strength points and equals two guns. The players of Rebel Yell assume the roles of divisional commanders.

Each game turn is broken down into segments. During an action segment, the units of a particular player may conduct a single action. In the beginning modules these actions are: Move, Fire, Assault, and Rally. During any Small Arms segment, the units of a particular player may only fire.

There are no movement phases, fire phases, etc., as there are in other Civil War games. This absence, in addition to the fact that player segments are structured reciprocally, produces a feel of simultaneity uncommon to other designs.

One of the most difficult problems faced by the Civil War tactician was the "problem of approach," in other words, how he should maneuver his unit to some objective while keeping his casualties and disorganization at a minimum. A commander who did not pay heed to the destructiveness of "modern" weaponry would find his formation damaged up to three hundred yards from the enemy. Rebel Yell addresses this problem. Within restrictions, defending units may fire at the enemy as he advances. Like a real-life commander, a player can no longer be certain that when he initiates an advance, his units will reach their objective. Players may find that even one or two companies Standing to Fire will be difficult to dislodge by frontal assault.

Although Rebel Yell is a complex design, it is not out of the reach of the novice gamer. The rules are programmed, allowing small portions to be digested first and getting players into the game quickly. Provisions are made for such factors as infantry line formations (Standing to Maneuver, Standing to Fire, Skirmishers, and Cover), volley effects, leader quality, morale, and regimental flags. The rules for cavalry and artillery are also extensive.

Although an excellent multi-player game, Rebel Yell accommodates the solitaire player, Likewise it can be played in a physically limited area. Rebel Yell is "big" only in the sense that it is detailed.

name: EtymoLinguo
description:
Do you really know the origins of the French language? Latin and Greek words are everywhere in the French language. With this family game, use Latin and Greek roots to find the corresponding French words. If you have for example MANUS, "hand" in Latin, you can find "manucure", "manual" or "manufacture". Depending on the difficulty or frequency derivative you will find, you score more points. No panic, no need to be a distinguished Latin or Greek scholar to participate! You just have to arm themselves with good humor and a competitive spirit! An addictive game for the whole family.
Etymolinguo, the game that revives the ancient languages!
Published in partnership with the site www.arretetonchar.fr

Material: 70 double-sided Latin/Greek cards, 1 hourglass, 1 pencil, 1 notebook

Rules of the game: the game master draws a card, reads the word (Latin and Greek) and his team will give as fast as possible French words derived from the Latin or Greek root. The more complicated is the word derivative, the more it gives points to his team.
Thus for GENUS ("species" in Latin), you can give: général (1 point), genèse (2 points), or gentleman (3 points).
The first team that reaches 15 points wins!

---

Connaissez-vous vraiment les origines du français ? Les mots latins et grecs sont partout dans la langue française. Avec ce jeu familial, partez des racines latines et grecques et trouvez les mots français correspondants. Si on vous dit par exemple MANUS, "la main" en latin, vous pourrez proposer « manucure », « manuel » ou « manufacture ». Selon la difficulté ou la fréquence du dérivé que vous trouverez, vous marquerez davantage de points. Pas de panique, pas besoin d’être un latiniste ou un helléniste émérite pour participer ! Il suffit juste de s’armer de bonne humeur et d’un esprit de compétition ! Un jeu addictif pour toute la famille.
Etymolinguo, le jeu qui ressuscite les langues anciennes !
Edité en partenariat avec le site www.arretetonchar.fr

Ce jeu d’étymologie est constitué d’un ensemble de cartes, d’un sablier, d’un carnet de notes et de son crayon.
Règles du jeu par équipe : le maître du jeu pioche une carte, énonce le mot (latin ou grec) et son équipe devra donner en un minimum de temps des mots français dérivés de ces racines latines ou grecques. Plus le mot dérivé est compliqué et plus il rapporte à son équipe.
Ainsi pour AMO ("aimer" en latin), on peut donner : amour (1 point), amant (2 points), ou amouracher (3 points).
La première équipe qui arrive à 15 points remporte la partie !
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Word Game

name: Pentoggle
description: Pentoggle is an abstract tile matching game for 2-6 players ages 7 and up. Players draw tiles from a bag, match them to tiles with the same number/differnt color or same color/different number, and earn points according to the numeric value of the tiles in the series. Tiles are matched not only horizontally but also vertically. The player who earns the most points wins.

name: Kama Sutra Memory
description:
Kama Sutra Memory is an adult memory game that teaches you about the Kama Sutra. The game can be played with or without clothes on.

The game includes 48 cards. It can be played as a conventional memory game, or in three official variants:

Variant 1 - The Quick One

For two players. 12 sets - ignore text.

The cards are placed face down and is turned in pairs, like any other memory game. If the cards are not the same (= two different KS positions), the player have to pick one of them and the players have to try to do this position. If it is a match the cards are removed without any trial. The most collected pairs wins.

Variant 2 - The Crash Course

2 players. 12 sets - use text, ignore points.

This game is played reversed than above; the 24 cards are placed face down, but this time the tasks first come when a match is found; on each card is a text and as a pair they make a task, which have to be tried out. The most collected pairs wins.

Variant 3 - The Super Orgie

2 or more players. All cards and texts in use.

In this variant, the players flip over four of the 48 face down cards; when there is a match, the talks are read and have to be followed. Each set of four cards is worth 50 points and each completed task gives points. The player with the most points wins.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Educational, Mature / Adult, Memory
mechanics: Acting, Memory, Set Collection, Team-Based Game

name: Nam 65-75
description: Nam 65-75 is a low-complexity turn-based hex-and counter wargame depicting the entire course of "America's war in Vietnam" (as the box states). The map covers all of South Vietnam. Cambodia and Laos are not depicted, and the Ho Chi Minh Trail is abstracted. Turns are one season (three months) and units are brigade/regiment in strength, with assets such air air support represented as separate counters. Communist units have face-down sides that hide their strength and US/Allied units must first detect them in order to attack. Combat is odds-based. The US can have a variable level of commitment, which is both influenced by and influences the US Public Support level. Soviet/Chinese Commitment is also tracked. Thus, the game tracks outside geopolitical influences on the conflict. Victory is achieved by causing (or avoiding) the collapse of the South Vietnam government, which depends on Communist capture of key towns (which reduces the Stability Level) and presence of NLF Sanctuaries (which is compared to the Stability Level). There are four scenarios: a 44-turn campaign scenario covering the entire war, and an 8-turn scenario covering just the Tet Offensive and its aftermath, a 14-turn scenario covering the Vietnamization period from 1970-72, and a Final Countdown scenario depicting the end of the war from 1973-75, which lasts 12 turns.

name: Cakes Athirst Hilarity: Volume #1  (fan expansion for Cards Against Humanity)
description:
The Unofficial, Disturbing, Illegitimate child of an expansion pack.

An unofficial, unauthorized 3rd-party expansion to the hit part game Cards Against Humanity.
Includes: 80 white cards, 30 black cards.

Semi-professionally printed on linen-finish. Premium casino-quality cards, should only be played by people who have a crude sense of humor.
categories: Card Game, Fan Expansion, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Cakes Athirst Hilarity: Volume #2 (fan expansion for Cards Against Humanity)
description:
The Unofficial, Disturbing, Illegitimate child of an expansion pack.

An unofficial, unauthorized 3rd-party expansion to the hit part game Cards Against Humanity.
Includes: 80 white cards, 30 black cards.

Semi-professionally printed on linen-finish. Premium casino-quality cards, should only be played by people who have a crude sense of humor.
categories: Card Game, Fan Expansion, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Cakes Athirst Hilarity: Volume #3 (fan expansion for Cards Against Humanity)
description:
The Unofficial, Disturbing, Illegitimate child of an expansion pack.

An unofficial, unauthorized 3rd-party expansion to the hit part game Cards Against Humanity.
Includes: 80 white cards, 30 black cards.

Semi-professionally printed on linen-finish. Premium casino-quality cards, should only be played by people who have a crude sense of humor.
categories: Card Game, Fan Expansion, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Goblins vs Zombies: Black Dragon Card
description:
In the base game you have 3 Guardians of three different colors (Red, Blue, and Green), each with the same ability.

The Black Dragon is a new Guardian with a different ability, so now you will have 4 Guardians.

At the beginning of the game each Player chooses one Guardian, or takes one at random.Ôªø

The Card text reads: When a Zombie in your field ENTERS: Destroy that Zombie. Then choose an Area in your Field, destroy up to 4 Zombies on that Area (Cannot destroy (B)). Then FLIP this card.

name: Kingdom of Elbrandt
description:
A fantasy card-game Chess supplement that transforms the classic game into a medieval fantasy adventure. Players create a deck of 15 cards that affect the game in various ways. These cards add new game setups and board variations, introduce special abilities, and provide an all-new level of strategy. Once all cards are exhausted, play continues until either a checkmate or a stalemate.

A standard copy of Chess is required to play Kingdom of Elbrandt.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Medieval

name: Gegenangriff am Kasserine
description:
GaK is a basically regiment-to-(Italian )division minigame about the Axis counteroffensive 14-22Feb43 in Tunisia. There are 9 1-day turns. The Axis have 9 units plus Rommel himself, and the Allies start with 6 U.S. (from 1st Armored and 34th Infantry Divisions) and 2 French units. At 10mis/16kms per hex, zones of control do not stop enemy movement but can interdict supply.

The U.S. (and French) must conduct a fighting withdrawal or lose victory points for losing villages/positions too quickly, to try to set up solid defenses in the hills, valleys, and (Kasserine) passes.

The game plays in an hour (or less, the instant the Germans take strategic objective Thala). There are Tiger( tanks)s. The British 6th Armoured Division is an optional, strategically costly reinforcement. The game is free to print off and play from CoatneyHistory.
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Push Your Luck

name: Hive Mind
description:
Zom Bees eating your Boo Bees before they can evade Spiders and bring Flowers back to the Hive to make HONEY! ...and stuff like that :)

Zone based battling battling Bees bent on sabotage while you try to convince everyone around you that someone else is WAY MORE threatening than you.

Get flowers from the center Flower Pots and bring them back to your Hive to be turned into Honey. The first player to successfully gain 5 Honey pots (or however many you pick at the beginning of the game) Wins the Game!

name: Fall Gelb: Storm in the West 1940
description:
(from the introduction:)

Fall Gelb is a simulation of the campaign between the Axis and the Western Allies in Europe in 1940. It consists of amalgamated components of Game Designer's Workshops Europa series of military simulations, including Fall of France, Their Finest Hour, Narvik and Spain and Portugal. It uses the current rule set from Fire In the East, with some modifications, plus completely new (unofficial and experimental) air, naval and political rules. It models the strategic and operational options open to the Wehrmacht as its focus turned to the Western Allies.
They may choose to repeat historical options, or find a new and more successful strategy. The scenario opens with the German Army redeployed after the dlsmemberment of Poland. The OA for both sides is historically accurate for that period.

Fall Gelb is intended for use by Europa buffs who have wanted to get their hands on a simulation covering the campaign in the West using available Europa components.


Contents:

Rules (v1: 11 pages, v2: 23 pages)
Orders of battle (v1: 7 pages, v2: 16 pages)
Tables (v1&v2:1 page)
Ship status sheet (v1: 6 pages, v2: 7 pages)
Strategic display (v1: 2 pages, v2: 3pages)
Port chart (v1: 6 pages, v2: 7 pages)
Air Wing Display (v1&v2: 2 pages)
Task Force Composition Chart (3 pages)
Air Units Dummy Sheets (v2 only: 2 pages)
Atlantic Chart (v1&v2: 2 pages)
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Who Am I? Music Edition
description: Party quiz game about (mainly) pop stars. Each of the 55 large format (11.5 x 8 cm) cards gives five facts about a particular pop star. A player rolls a dice and is read the clue that corresponds to the number rolled. If they correctly identify the pop star, they win the card. The sixth fact on each card is the name of the pop star, so if they roll a 6 they automatically win the card. The game is won by the first player to win 5 cards. There are 9 special power cards that allow, for example, an extra clue or the opportunity to 'steal' a card. These are kept by the 'reader' who picks them up.

name: My Big World: Europe
description:
A fun and simple geo-themed game, where players put their tokens on a map, trying to be the nearest from the monument shown on the card. But beware, i bet you're not on the good place !

First, players draw a card from a pile, that displays a monument, a famous building, or anything else related to a specific place, sometimes accompanied by a flag.

The players should guess where in Europe this place is. The first player put his meeple where he think the answer is, on the European map/board. The next player take his turn and must do the same.

When all players have placed their markers, the card is turned over, revealing the right position. Now, using the benchmarks along the edges of the map, the players should deduct how far they are distant from the solution. The nearest player from this place score more points. If 2 or more player's markers are on the same position, the token that is under the others scores more points.

Then a new card is revealed. Game ends after 12 cards revealed.

name: Malifaux Second Edition Starter Set
description:
This starter set contains everything you need to learn and start playing Malifaux! Pit the forces of the mysterious Angel Eyes against the diabolical Dr. Grimwell in a series of starter games which teach you as you play. If you are new to Malifaux and want to know more, this box is for you. In addition to being a good starting point, every model has the "mercenary" characteristic, allowing you to use them with whichever Faction you decide on. Even if you're experienced with Malifaux, you may be interested in the brand new models for the Guild and Neverborn Factions this set contains.

Set Contains:

2 Crews (8 models)
8 Stat Cards
2 Upgrade Cards
2 Quick Reference Cards

Quick Start Booklet
Free Digital Rules Manual
2 Fate Decks
2 Measuring Tapes
mechanics: Action Points, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Variable Player Powers

name: Flames of War: Overlord ‚Äì The Allied Invasion of France
description:
This book contains the forces that assaulted the French coast in 1944 to free it from the German occupation.

With this book, you can field parachute men from the famous 101st Airborne, men of the "Blue&Grey" 29Div. on bloody Omaha, british armoured spearheads heading to Villers Bocage to meet their fate or the powerful 2 Armoured Division as it crosses the Bocage breaking the front.

This book complements with Atlantik Wall, which is the book for the german forces.

name: Le zug
description:
Le zug is played on the dark squares of a 17x17 board (the four edge squares must be dark). A game starts with 12 pieces per player. Nine pieces of each color are placed on the first and the last row. In the first move (each player's first turn) the players put their three remaining pieces on the row next to their other pieces in any order they want them.
After that players move at their turn one of their pieces diagonally forward to an adjacent empty square. Players also can jump over their own pieces or over those of their opponent (even combining both colors) similar to Halma but only diagonally forward. However, they don't have to jump, if they don't want to, and they can stop a jumping move anywhere, not making the largest jump possible. After the last jump they are allowed to move the piece, which did the jump, one square diagonally forward to an adjacent empty square. Again, this is not mandatory. No pieces are ever captured and the jumped pieces remain untouched.

The first four rows of each player are called their "railway station" ("gare" in French; "Bahnhof" in German). Players are not permitted to enter their opponent's railway station, before they have vaca­ted their own one. After a player has entered all of his pieces into the opponent's railway station, he is allowed to move or jump backward to reach the final goal position, but only as long as all of his pieces remain in the opponent's railway station.

The object of the game is to place nine pieces on the last row and the remaining three pieces anywhere on the penultimate row, that is to recreate a valid start position on the opponent's side of the board.

The name of the game is French and German mixed together ("le" is the masculine French article; "zug" means train in German). The game is meant to celebrate friendship between the French and the German peoples after centuries of wars fought between them. It is related to Halma and Salta. Le zug was first described in the book "Le livre de tous les jeux" (Edition Solar), which was published in France on January 1, 1989.

name: Adijuh
description:
Adijuh (–ê–¥–∏—é—Ö) is a rather new game, which combines the rules of Russian checkers, stacking and a unique way to win. The game was created by Viktor Pankovich in 2007. It has become quite popular in Russia, where a lot of discussion is going on at several game forums. There are postal tournaments and numerous problems have been composed recently that show the beauty of this game.

The game has basically the same rules as Russian Checkers. However, captured pieces are placed beneath the capturing piece and so columns are formed (similar to Bashni). A king can only move if it captures. After the capture the king becomes a normal piece again unless it ends its turn on the opponent's back row. The game stops if a player cannot make a move. The winner is the player who has got more pieces of either color in the opponent's half of the board. The sum of all points is always 24.

Adijuh is played with a standard Chess board and Checkers pieces.

name: Volcano Cove
description:
In Volcano Cove two warring nations discover gold mines within a disputed cove. To win the game, sink all enemy ships, or be the first to earn 7 gold. But watch out for the volcano. If your opponent’s prayers to the volcano gods are successful, lava could engulf your fleet.

Volcano Cove is a beautiful 2-player game that packs a large punch. Games last 10-15 minutes while providing drama and strategic decisions around every turn. Since there are multiple paths to victory, you’ll need to watch your opponent carefully and look for weaknesses you can exploit.

Both players share a zero-sum Gold Track. When you earn 1 gold your opponent loses 1 gold, and vice versa. This means when you buy extra ships or movement, you are giving your opponent gold in exchange for the advantage. You earn gold by sinking enemy ships, occupying gold mine spaces, having 3 Battle Coins at the end of your turn, and by praying to the volcano gods and successfully causing an eruption.

You start your turn by building your fleet, sailing, and declaring any battles you’d like. When fighting, your Battle Strength is equal to the number of coins that make up your ship (ships can be built up to 3 coins high) plus any Battle Coins you commit. Three Battle Coins float between both players throughout the game. If you commit a Battle Coin to a battle, you have a higher Battle Strength for the current battle, but you must pass any committed Battle Coins to your opponent.

After the Battle Phase, your opponent decides if he or she wants to pray to the volcano gods. If your opponent prays, he or she shakes 3 Prayer Coins. The number of heads shaken moves the Volcano Track marker, which can cause an eruption. Ships within the Lava Danger Zone when the volcano erupts take damage depending on the severity of the eruption. After the Pray Phase, you end you turn by earning gold from any gold mine spaces you still occupy. Then play passes to the next player.

To create your free print-and-play copy of Volcano Cove, print the board and rules at VolcanoCove.com and find 10 pennies, 10 nickels, 5 dimes, and 3 quarters. You now have everything you need to challenge someone to your first game.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Nautical, Pirates, Print & Play, Transportation, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Push Your Luck

name: Simple Campaigning
description:
Simple Campaigning is a 48-page A5 full colour booklet containing Campaign frameworks for Ancient and Medieval warfare, which can be played as boardgames or as bases for miniatures battles. Includes Solo Campaigning (the Rise of Rome), Angevin Empire, Across the Steppes (Mongol Conquests), The Millennium Campaign (11th Century Europe), Crisis of Rome (3rd Century AD), The Wolf on the Fold (Assyrian Empire), The Calamitous Fourteenth Century (late Medieval Europe).

Each of the seven Campaign wargames contains rules for re-creating the conflicts of a historical epoch and region, with counters on a map and using either a combat results table or miniatures. They vary widely in complexity; some have minimal rules and can be played very quickly, while others have detailed political and/or economic rules. The games are designed to entertain both historical boardgamers and miniatures buffs. Several can easily be played solitaire.

The point of each game is to determine by die rolls where conflicts arise, fight the battles and compare the outcome with history. Several include victory point tables so that players can measure their success against each other or, if playing solitaire, against the historical outcome - for example, can the player outdo the Lionheart and King John in holding the Angevin Empire together?

Some of the games can easily be completed in an hour, if using a combat results table; others take considerably longer, while all can last for many sessions if the battles are fought on the tabletop.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Crecy 1346
description:
Crecy 1346 is a game about most famous battle of the 100 years war fought between Kingdom of England and Kingdom of France. The battle was fought on 26 August 1346 near Crécy in northern France and was the major victory of the English army under the king Edward III.

Game was published in the 40 issue of Taktyka i Strategia magazine, in both Polish and English versions. Is uses Medieval (Sredniowiecze) games mechanic.

name: Kuka on putkessa?
description: This game brings a whole new experience! Players write down the names of people on the piece hidden in small hose pieces. These people will then be portrayed in three different ways. The game is played in three rounds where all teams meet each other. Fast glossary, loud laughter, tongue-tied, blackout and wild gestures succeed each other in a fast pace! A brand new party game that never gets old!

name: Seizer's Chess
description:
Seizer's Chess is chess variant.

The first distinction is that the pieces are flat shapes that indicate movement more than rank. The shapes can be stacked in a way that allows players to still tell what pieces are stacked on top of each other.

The second distinction is gameplay. Instead of eliminating a piece from the game when it is captured, the player actually captures, or Seizes, it and adds it to the piece they used to capture it.

For example, if a Rook captures a Knight, the Rook+Knight can now move as a Knight or a Rook, the choice is up to the player.

If that combination piece is captured, then it transfers its powers on to the next piece - and so on. This applies to Kings as well, (as the capturing piece). Player could potentially end up with a King that can move like a Queen and leap like a Knight.

The creator claims that the game is so volatile that a computer cannot defeat a human player in this game.

name: Escape From Lunar 7
description:
A cooperative game of survival.

Your lunar prospecting mission has gone horribly wrong! Aliens have arrived and destroyed your ship and are attacking the lunar bases. You have evaded them for now, but need to get back to Earth. You head to Lunar 7, an old abandoned lunar base, hoping to find a still working ship.

Just as you all manage to reach the landing pad and start moving into the base, the Alien ship finds you. It begins dropping aliens all over the base trying to find and prevent you from escaping. Now you must find the supplies you need to repair your ship and escape, all while trying to hold off the ever growing hoard of aliens.

Game is played as a cooperative game, with everyone helping to make sure all of you escape.

Basic game play: Each turn you have 3 action points which you use to move and explore (placing tiles), picking up and dropping off resources (energy cells) to power factory tiles that build repair parts. You collect the parts and take them back to your ship to repair it and escape the aliens. At the end of each turn you will draw an Alien card that tells which tile an alien lands on. When moving to a tile with aliens the player 'pushes' the aliens off that tile onto surrounding tiles. Anytime a tile has 4 or more aliens, the aliens destroy that tile (flip it over) and scatter to the adjacent tiles. This can lead to chain reaction where one tile being destroyed causes more tiles to be overloaded with aliens and destroyed.
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Pick-up and Deliver, Tile Placement

name: Luna Park Keys
description:
The 6 friends know that the guard has fallen asleep. They will sneak inside the Fun Park. They will run as fast as they can.
Who is going to unlock the more games?
Who is going to be the winner of the day?
Who is going to find the more Luna Park Keys?

The players move across the terrain by rolling the dice. They have to find the keys that shows which game they unlock by picking a "games" card. Now they have to go and unlock the game to win the "Trophy" card. The player with the more Trophy cards when all games are unlocked is the winner of the game. Be careful, because your keys and Trophies are in danger. If a "friend" steps on your tile can take from you either a key or all your trophies!!!
The game has an augmented reality app that allows players to see the Luna Park games come to life. Also, when a player wins a "Trophy" card, he/she can see an extra prize through the app.
(The app is not necessary to play the game)

name: Balkan Gamble
description:
Balkan Gamble explores hypothetical invasions of the Balkans during WW2. There is also a scenario depicting a hypothetical Soviet invasion of Yugoslavia to unseat Tito in 1950.

This is not the same game published in Strategy and Tactics #298, Balkan Gambit, 1943-1945, though they share almost the same title (and the same designer). Instead, it uses the Autumn Mist / Summer Lightning / Winter Thunder system where formation are activated by chit-pull which uses an almost-diceless combat with a mission matrix.
Headquarter chits are randomly drawn, and HQs can activate units for movement and combat. After 12 turns, both sides total victory points, which are gained for occupying cities and for eliminating enemy units (depending on the scenario).

Only 30 copies of this game were produced, by BTR Games.

(source: designer)

name: Dust Tactics: Kampfgruppe Christoph
description:
From the publisher:

The Neue Deutsches Afrikakorps (NDAK) has arrived in the Middle East! Along with the rest of Operation Babylon's forces, the Korps is now fighting the Allies and the SSU in this part of the World.

Dust Studio is very proud to present this new starter with slightly revamped rules for Dust Tactics! The very beginning of a new era starts now with an amazing box full of treasures!
We're certain that it will appeal to new players and veterans alike. Whether you're new to the World of Dust or have been hanging out with us for some time now, you'll love the NDAK Starter Set: Kampfgruppe Christoph.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Otsukimi Fukurou
description:
„Åä„Å§„Åç„Åø„Åµ„Åè„Çç„ÅÜ (Moon Viewing Owls)

In a forest where no one knows about, there are owls that are kind of unusual, who are anxiously waiting for the perfectly round full Moon.

“Let’s go view the Moon tonight”
The owls work very, very hard to prepare for the dango.

However, the dango are so delicious, tempting the owls to steal and eat them when no one knows about.
